DEBATE.TITLE: SALES TAX LAWS AMENDMENT BILL 1990SALES TAX (Nos 1 to 9) AMENDMENT BILLS 1990

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 21 May, on motion by Senator Button:
That these Bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are quite suddenly today back on debate on the Sales Tax Laws Amendment Bill and the Sales Tax (Nos 1 to 9) Amendment Bills. It goes to show that one has to be prepared at all times. The Sales Tax Laws Amendment Bill is about increasing from 30 to 50 per cent the sales tax on so-called luxury cars and four-wheel drive vehicles that are above $28,000-odd wholesale or $42,000 retail. I believe that this tax, or levy, has no economic rationale about it. It was announced during the lead-up to the election as a measure to raise an extra $100m for roads. But I believe that it is nothing more than an extension of this Government's consumption tax which is imposed rather selectively. An expenditure of $100m on roads will not go very far, but I know that any extra funding on roads is a good move because of the way in which the road systems in Australia have been run down particularly over the last six or seven years.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government raises ample taxes in the name of roads. In fact, it raises from fuel levies and other measures five times in excess of what it puts back into the roads and yet it is using this tax on luxury cars as an excuse to gain extra road funding. It is nothing but a jealousy tax. It is a tax to enable the Government to show its supporters that it intends to sock the rich. We on this side of the House have said for a number of years that the Government has got a consumption tax in another name, that is, sales tax. To illustrate what I mean I will quote from a speech given in the House of Representatives by Mr Snow, the member for Eden-Monaro, who said that the Government had had a series of taxation measures over the years and went on to say:
They include the measure that we have tonight, the Sales Tax Laws Amendment Bill.

As with a lot of other measures that have been taken by the Government, the Bill takes away the need for a consumption tax. We need to look at whether we should go for a sales tax on luxury cars or the consumption tax . . .
That shows what this Government is all about when it comes to a consumption tax. It has a consumption tax and yet it denies it.

What I am most annoyed about with this Bill, and the reason why I have taken part in this debate, is that this increase in sales tax on so-called luxury vehicles includes four-wheel drive vehicles. That is the aspect that I am most worried about. What is the definition of a luxury car? One man's luxury is another man's necessity. These vehicles are more of a necessity in remote areas than in urban areas. In remote regions there is a necessity for safety and an ability to use certain roads in certain regions. The only luxury cars built in Australia are the LTD Ford and the Holden Statesman Caprice, which I do not believe has been totally released. They make up only 7.24 per cent of total luxury cars; the rest are imported.

The vehicles that are used in suburban and urban areas can be a lot smaller and lighter than those needed in remote areas where rough roads, corrugated roads, flooded roads, dusty roads and sandy roads mean a heavier, more substantial vehicle is needed. In most cases a four-wheel drive is needed. In remote areas those supposed luxury four-wheel drive vehicles double up as a work vehicle as well as a private vehicle. The average yearly mileage in remote areas is far greater than in suburban areas. Motorists in suburban areas would probably average around 16,000 kilometres a year. The minimum average in remote areas would be nearer 50,000 kilometres. The engines in lighter vehicles, mostly four-cylinder, which are used in suburban areas would wear out far more quickly if they were used in the rougher remote areas-that is, if the vehicles did not shake to pieces structurally in the meantime! Heavier vehicles are required on corrugated roads. I have already said that bigger vehicles in remote areas double up as not only work vehicles but as vehicles to take children to school.

Then there is the safety angle. Heavier vehicles are needed in remote areas as accidents are more likely to happen because of potholes and sudden flooding at night time, and a person could finish up in the bush against a tree. Over the Easter break I had the great misfortune to see a fatal accident outside my own gate. A small car got into difficulty in gravel and hit a tree. It disintegrated and unfortunately the passenger was killed. A heavier, more substantial vehicle would have stood up to the impact. This is true not only of four-wheel drives but of other standard two-wheel drives as well.

This tax puts these classes of cars needed for work and safety in remote areas into the luxury class. The Range Rover is an example of such a vehicle, noted for its independent four-wheel suspension, as is the Toyota Landcruiser station sedan; although it is nowhere near as comfortable, nevertheless it is very sturdy in accidents. I know that Range Rovers are termed by detractors-supporters of the Australian Labor Party and others-as Toorak trucks or St George's Terrace tractors but unfortunately they are lumped into a luxury class. As I have already said, someone's necessities are termed someone else's luxuries.

The proposed sales tax is nothing but a jealousy tax, as far as I am concerned. It is being used as a measure to belt the rich and, unfortunately, the people living in remote areas. What annoyed me at the time was that it was introduced by press release. Now we have retrospectivity as well. Car dealers now have a law by which they cannot charge more than 30 per cent of sales tax on these so-called luxury vehicles and yet when this Bill, if it is passed, receives royal assent, it will be introduced retrospectively. That means that the motor dealer is caught between two lines of fire. He cannot legally charge the customer who buys the car between now and then yet, if this tax is introduced, the Australian Taxation Office will charge that dealer who will have to collect it from his customer. If the customer pays, that is one thing; if he does not pay, it is another-the dealer will be caught with the bill. I am asking: who is going to pay the difference?

In summary, these are my conclusions. There is a lack of sound economic rationale for introducing this new tax. It is simply a political manoeuvre which will have no ultimate benefits for the Australian economy. The nature of the introduction of the change to the legislation by press release is wrong as a matter of principle. There is concern that the new level of tax may not raise anywhere near the amount of revenue claimed by the Government.

This Government has calculated, on the basis of present sales, that it will raise $105m in one year. It also assumes that the buyers of these so-called luxury vehicles will buy at any price. That may be so the first time they buy such a vehicle, but the Government will find out that, as with most other commodities that are bought, after a price rise purchasers make sure that those vehicles or other commodities are used for a longer time before trading them in. So I believe that there will be a downturn in the sales of these so-called luxury vehicles and that the Government will collect only a fraction of that $105m.

There is also a concern about the likely negative impact on employment and business viability in this sector of the car industry. The car industry is depressed enough. We have only two manufacturers in Australia, as it is, and I believe that with reduced sales of these cars we will see a further downturn in the industry which will cause more lay-offs of car industry workers. Unfortunately, those factories are in cities where unemployment is already at too high levels.

The practical effect of the increase will be to impose a de facto tariff on imported vehicles in direct contravention of the Button car plan. That has been expounded well in the press. It is opposed to our beliefs with respect to the reduction of tariffs an the micro-economic reform that is needed to keep Australia competing with the rest of the world. The new tax may also impinge on the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade negotiations.

Those are my reasons for opposing this legislation. It is an ill thought out tax. It was thought out on the run to pick up a few votes. We can lump it with other on-the-run measures that were made leading up to the election, such as the Kodak bail-out, the supposed buy-back of North West Cape in Western Australia, and all of the promises made to the greenies and radical groups. Incidentally, the Government cannot afford to keep those promises. I hope it does not keep them over the next few years because the economy could not stand it. I lump this measure with those other measures and I believe it is certainly a backward step for the car industry of Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chapman Sen H.G.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Sales Tax Laws Amendment Bill, in itself, is severely detrimental to the interests of Australians and the Australian economy, contrary to what we hear from the Government. The legislation, in the way in which it was announced and, indeed, the way in which it is now being handled in this Senate, simply demonstrates the state of confusion of the Government since the last election.

SPEECH.PARA: This legislation was supposed to be debated in this chamber on Thursday, yet we found that because the Government was not prepared to consider the Estimates committee reports last night, it was brought on suddenly just before we adjourned. Again, the Estimates committees began today, but the Government found itself totally unprepared to consider those Estimates so this legislation was brought on again at short notice.

That is not the way to treat legislation of this significance to the Australian motor industry. But it demonstrates the state of confusion in which this Government finds itself at the moment. Sharing in that confusion in no small measure is the Minister responsible for the motor industry, the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, Senator Button. Of course, it also demonstrates the low priority which the Government gives to the implications and consequences of this legislation.

When I spoke briefly last night, I referred to the fact that this was a tax on so-called luxury cars. I asked really what was the definition of a luxury car and whether price was a determinant. If a luxury car was to be defined on price, the Senate needed to be reminded that the price of the cars to which this tax will apply is largely fixed by the Government, not by the market, because a large segment of the retail price of these vehicles is caused by massive tariffs and also the past effect of quotas applied to the bulk of these vehicles, with the exception of two that are manufactured in Australia.

It is also worth noting that the level above which this tax will apply, the retail cost of a car, is $42,910. This is the inflation adjusted figure which was originally introduced by a previous government some years ago to apply to the limit on depreciation of motor vehicles. As I said last night, that was an unjustified initiative and this proposed hefty increase in sales tax on these particular vehicles is likewise unjustified. Of course, the only reason that it will apply to a couple of Australian-made vehicles is that the retail price of those vehicles has escalated faster than inflation over the last few years.

That further indicates the way in which this legislation is an additional protective measure for the domestic industry. The prices of the two Australian-made vehicles to which this tax will apply increased faster than inflation over the last few years. That demonstrates the inefficiencies of the Australian industry, inefficiencies which are not being solved by the Button car plan. So, in effect, this is an additional protective measure. As I said, you cannot define a so-called luxury car on the basis of price because that price is due only to the effects of tariffs.

I then asked whether it was the quality of the car that determined what was a luxury car, whether it was the standards of safety, performance, equipment and finish of a car. If that is to be the definition of a luxury car, surely it is the lack of equivalent quality in Australian vehicles which is one of the major problems of our domestic industry-its inability to reach that standard. But surely because a car has a particular quality to which the Australian produced vehicle ought to aspire is no reason for calling a car a luxury car. As I said, clearly the use of the term `luxury' is a pejorative attempt by the Government to rouse the politics of envy to justify this iniquitous charge. It simply cannot be justified. It is an arbitrary imposition at an arbitrary price level, just as is the limit on depreciation. Neither of these can be justified.

As I said last night, far from increasing the present rate of sales tax on these particular cars from 30 per cent to 50 per cent, the Government ought to reduce it to 20 per cent-the level that applies to other motor vehicles. At the same time it ought to abolish the limit on the depreciation value for motor vehicles, particularly as we now have in place a fringe benefits tax and substantiation requirements to ensure that depreciation claimed is validly claimed only for business purposes.

As I concluded last night, there are three questions that the Government has to answer before it can justify the introduction of this tax. Firstly, is an increase in what I have already shown to be a discriminatory tax justified? Secondly, is it consistent with the direction supposedly provided for the Australian car industry by the Button plan? Thirdly, are the revenue assumptions of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) correct? The clear answer to each of those questions is no. Firstly, the tax on quality imported cars is already discriminatory at a rate of 30 per cent and to raise it, in isolation, to this absurd level of 50 per cent puts it totally out of line with taxes levied on any other consumer items. The result of the legislation will be that these vehicles will be taxed at 150 per cent above the rate at which most other cars are taxed. This is a very dangerous, short-sighted policy for such quality cars to be singled out as the sole source of additional revenue with which to fund what are, in essence, social programs.

To suggest that some of this revenue could also be used to build new roads really makes a mockery of the aims which the Treasurer has for this money. We are all very much aware that the Australian motorist is greatly short-changed in terms of the revenue paid to benefits derived ratio. That is true for motorists in general, but it is even more true for motorists who buy vehicles at the quality end of the market. Motorists already contribute disproportionately to Government revenue. We have seen the price of fuel rise by 20 per cent in recent times and most of that rise is a result of government excise duty. In the last financial year the excise duty on petroleum products amounted to about $6.3 billion. There are, therefore, ample funds within that revenue to be tapped in order to build additional roads.

The Australian motorist already contributes some 12 per cent to all Federal Government revenue and 14 per cent to all State government revenue, and that excludes revenue received from such things as speeding fines and other motoring offences.

An increased tax on quality motor vehicles will have a significant impact on the pricing of these vehicles. It has been estimated that there will be a cost increase of some 13 per cent, and that will have a devastating effect on that market segment which is already in decline as a result of the effect of high interest rates and the economic recession into which this Government had led us.

TALK.START.PARA: —It provides a profit to existing owners.

—My colleague is quite right. Of course, another detrimental effect of the legislation will be that it will threaten employment and investment in property, buildings and equipment by vehicle importers and the distributors and retailers of these vehicles. The protection of the domestic industry is often justified in terms of the investment and employment that it encourages. This claim completely ignores the investment and employment that is generated in the distribution and marketing of imported vehicles. This is a further impost which will directly threaten that employment and investment.

SPEECH.PARA: It also raises questions about this Government's commitment to free trade. No doubt we will be viewed askance overseas for introducing what is, in effect, an additional protective measure. It may not strictly conflict with the terms of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, because it is a tax, but there is no doubt that, in terms of the effect of its application, it is a protective measure. Certainly, overseas countries looking at our trade record will view it as such and view this Government as hypocritical.

The second issue I raised concerns whether this tax is consistent with the aims of the Button car plan. Of course, after the events of last week we are not quite sure what the Button car plan is all about when we hear from the Treasurer that Senator Button has been dragging the chain in reducing protection for the motor vehicle industry in order to make it more competitive. As I understand it, the fundamental aims of the Button plan used to be to bring the price of cars down, to use imported vehicles as a pressure point on local manufacturers to make them maintain productivity and quality of vehicles and thereby ensure that Australia developed an efficient automotive manufacturing industry which was capable of exporting quality vehicles at a competitive cost to world markets.

This tax increase is totally inconsistent with those aims. It raises the ceiling price up to which the price of domestic manufacturers' vehicles can move and therefore relieves them of competitive market pressures in any realistic sense. It also makes it harder for Australians to afford quality motor vehicles and enjoy the safety which such vehicles provide. Furthermore, it places the latest automotive technology beyond the reach of the average Australian motorist by making quality imported vehicles even more expensive and, again, by relieving market pressure on local manufacturers to develop similar technological advantages in domestic vehicles. This, in turn, has a negative impact on Australia's capacity to develop an export market for motor vehicles because the technology and quality which manufacturers will offer will not be up to world standards.

If people question the protective effect of this tax, they need only remember what happened in 1986-87 when, because of the devaluation of the Australian currency, the prices of imported vehicles were forced up dramatically. The result was that the retail price of locally manufactured vehicles also shot up in order to fill the vacuum left by imported vehicles. This dramatically shows how imported vehicles, when they are allowed to be priced competitively and do not have unrealistic tariffs and these sorts of unrealistic taxes applied to them, can keep price pressure on local producers. The events during that period also showed what happens when this price pressure is removed. Again, we see the lack of justification for this tax.

The third question concerned whether the Treasurer's numbers were correct with regard to the revenue that this tax might raise. Clearly, the answer to that question is no. The market for the cars to which this tax will apply was running at a going rate of around 15,400 units during the 1988-89 financial year. However, during the last quarter, as a result of the recession into which the Government has plunged us due to its high interest rate policy, the going rate declined to under 11,000 units-roughly a 30 per cent decline. If the legislation is passed and the tax is introduced, this increase will indeed be the straw that breaks the camel's back with regard to this segment of the market.

The fact is that this segment of the market already pays its way with regard to revenue raising in Australia. Under the current tax and tariff duty structure, Government revenue taken on imported cars in this segment of the market is roughly equivalent to the landed cost of bringing those cars into Australia. In other words, Government tariffs and taxes double the price of these cars in Australia. To put it another way, the Government revenue, through taxes, gains half of the retail price of these cars for its own coffers. As I said, this segment is already contributing more than its fair share to Government revenue. There is also additional revenue through the fringe benefits tax, stamp duty and registration fees.

Let us look at the assumptions of the Treasurer with regard to the revenue implications of this tax. We can assume that the average cost of an imported car to which this tax will apply will be around $86,000. If one assumes a going rate of 15,400 vehicles, which it was in the 1988-89 financial year, the total revenue collected would be approximately $200m in duty and $247m in sales tax-a total of $447m.

If the market remained at that level, then the additional revenue the Treasurer predicted would indeed be raised. That ignores the real world situation of sensitivity to price in the marketplace. The Treasurer also seems to have ignored that this segment of the market has already declined to a going rate of about 11,000 units per annum. That gives a significantly lower revenue figure. That number of vehicles would provide tariff duty of $142m and sales tax of $174m, a total of $316m. So the Government has already lost $130m in revenue compared with last year, simply because of the fall off in the market as a result of the current recession. That represents more than the additional revenue the Treasurer is hoping to raise.

Further than that, we need to consider what will happen to that going rate of 11,000 units once the additional tax applies. It would appear now that that will drop back to at best an annual rate of 9,800 units; the most likely result is a going rate of 8,000 units. Between May and October of this year it is estimated that the going rate will fall, indeed, to 5,100 units, because of the pull forward effect which the application of this sales tax from 1 May has had on the market, but then will rise to about 8,000 units per annum.

So we see from that that there will be significant loss in revenue-something of the order of $60m or more. In fact, at best the introduction of this additional sales tax will be revenue neutral, but the most likely result will be a loss of revenue for the Government. That further ignores the loss of additional revenue from the fringe benefits tax, stamp duty, and so on through the lower number of vehicles sold.

So those three main questions are all answered in the negative when an analysis is done of this proposed tax. If the Government deems it necessary to raise additional revenue from the motor industry on top of all the revenue which I earlier mentioned is currently raised-some 12 per cent of total revenue for the Commonwealth Government and 14 per cent for the State governments-if the Government wants to be even more rapacious as far as the motor industry and motorists are concerned, then surely the best decision would be a modest increase in sales tax on all motor vehicles. This would give a much more secure revenue base and would not be as disruptive to the market as this proposed tax. Of course, it would avoid those three specific problems that this tax will cause. This tax really is more in keeping with a Third World country than with a highly industrialised country.

The tax particularly penalises imported vehicles. This may be seen by some people as helping to restore the balance of payments. I recall last night in the brief debate that ensued on this legislation that Senator Maguire interjected about the balance of payments when I was speaking. The simple fact is that this segment of the market has minimal detrimental effect on our balance of payments. I understand that it is something less than one per cent of our total imports and, therefore, has virtually no effect on our balance of payments whatsoever. So that is simply a fallacious argument.

There is no doubt that it will have detrimental effects on the quality of locally manufactured vehicles. That not only relates to keeping competitive pressures on the domestic market and improving the safety of motoring in Australia, but it also has environmental impacts. So there is a greenhouse issue involved in this matter. We need in Australia, as Senator Button himself has recognised, continual competition from imported vehicles. That simply will diminish as a result of this legislation. None of the assumptions on which the Government has based this legislation can in any way be sustained. The legislation is totally unjustified.

In summary, imported cars in this segment of the market are not a problem as far as Australia's balance of payments difficulties are concerned. The tax is certainly unjustified in terms of Australia's general approach to free trade and the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. It works directly against the principles laid down in the Button car plan. It is directly discriminatory against a segment of the automotive industry which, as I have indicated, is already overcontributing to government coffers. It is in danger of eliminating from the industry some participants and dealers. The consequence of that will be a loss of investment and a loss of employment in the industry. Of course, that will throw many more families on to the dole queues. It is not only those that sell these vehicles, it is also those that service them and those that repair them that will lose their jobs.

In terms of revenue, the best result will be that it is revenue neutral. The Treasurer will not gain the extra tax he is seeking from this measure, but the most likely result is that it will be revenue negative. Because of the decline in the market for these vehicles there will be a direct loss of revenue. It will also distort the market and the capacity of Australian consumers to buy freely the best, safest and most environmentally sound and fuel efficient vehicles available on the market. It will really make this country a joke in terms of international regard for us. It will make us look more and more like a Third World country that simply relies on heavy protection to sustain an inefficient domestic industry.

It is worth considering, before I conclude, that it was the Treasurer who last week criticised Senator Button for dragging the chain with regard to the reduction of protection generally and in particular with regard to the motor industry, for his failure to reduce tariffs quickly on that industry. Yet it is the Treasurer who introduced this legislation, this 50 per cent sales tax on a particular segment of the import market, which will have a significant protective effect on the domestic industry. So who can believe the Treasurer when he criticises Senator Button for dragging the chain on protection when it is the Treasurer who, in the same week in another place and this week in the Senate, seeks the passage of legislation which will have perhaps an even greater impact on the price of these vehicles and, therefore, a reduction in competition for domestic industry than tariffs have?

So on all these grounds I personally strongly oppose this legislation, as do my Opposition colleagues. We will be opposing it when the various questions are put. I urge the Government, even at this late stage, to withdraw this legislation and, while it is doing that, also to withdraw the depreciation limits which apply to the same vehicles.
Debate interrupted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I call the next speaker, it might be useful to have an update on what delayed the business of the Senate earlier today, that is, the distribution of the Estimates committee reports. The situation is that the reports of Estimates committees D and F have been distributed; the distribution of the reports of A and B is about to commence; C is currently being printed and should be completed in an hour; and E has only just gone for printing and should be available in a little over an hour.

DEBATE.TITLE: SALES TAX LAWS AMENDMENT BILL 1990SALES TAX (NOS 1 TO 9) AMENDMENT BILLS 1990

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to speak very briefly in support of this amendment for two reasons. One is that with our current balance of payments imbalance, we need to clamp down on unnecessary imports, especially luxury goods-not just motor vehicles, I would say, but other luxury goods as well. I add for good measure that there are a lot of other things we do not need to import, particularly military equipment, which through the last decade has cost this country over $1 billion a year.

SPEECH.PARA: The other reason for supporting this tax is that we need to discourage the purchase of expensive and luxurious cars. Nobody really needs a luxury car, any more than anybody needs a $20,000 high fashion outfit or a million dollar house. We have looked askance at communist bureaucrats in their limousines in Moscow and Beijing; we laughed at the Bhagwan's 83 Rolls-Royces; and some of us remember Lady Docker's gold-plated Bentley in England-a cast of gross extravagance. In East Africa, the new middle class is known as the wa-Benzi, or the people who show their newly acquired wealth by getting a Mercedes Benz-a particularly crude display of extravagance which is singularly inappropriate in countries where many live in poverty.

However, in a democratic society such as Australia we cannot stop people buying luxury cars, so the best we can do instead is to tax them as heavily as possible. If people can afford $42,000-a conservative estimate for some luxury cars-they can either pay a few thousand dollars extra by way of the tax or buy a more sensible, cheaper vehicle. I cannot agree with Senator Chapman's assessment that jobs will be lost. In fact, the purchase of more Australian made vehicles might be a healthy step in the right direction for the Australian industry.

The future of the car in Australia needs a drastic reassessment. The emphasis now needs to be on small, fuel-efficient cars and not expensive gas-guzzling vehicles bought for pomp and show. In a society where many people cannot afford a car or choose rather to walk or to use a bicycle or public transport, the import of luxury cars is a gross display of unnecessary extravagance.

With concern over the depletion of the ozone layer, increasing pollution, the run-down of our oil reserves and growing demand for improved public transport, Australians will soon have to think again about the way we relate to private motor vehicles. We are all concerned about the carnage on the roads and the destruction of our inner cities to make way for freeways and car parks. That has to be reassessed and has to stop, too. We have been a servant to the private motor vehicle for far too long. There will have to be a combined effort, based on public education and legislation, as we change over to greater reliance on walking, cycling, taxis, buses and trains. Linked to that we need a major effort, at both the Federal and State levels, to improve our railway system. In the meantime a tax such as this is a good way to reduce the purchase of luxury cars, and it will help to slightly reduce our balance of payments deficit as well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise today to speak on the Sales Tax Laws Amendment Bill 1990 and the Sales Tax (Nos 1 to 9) Amendment Bills 1990. Hopefully, as the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) is in a private hospital bed in a metropolitan Sydney hospital and not in a hospital in a remote area of Australia, he may be able to hear this Senate broadcast if he is tuned in at the end of the dial. If he is bothering to or is well enough to listen, I send him a cheerio call and wish him a speedy recovery because I fear for Australia with the Treasurer, Mr Keating, at the helm, for even a very brief time, given the way in which this legislation was introduced by press release and given Mr Keating's total disregard of the process of parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: The pros and cons of the legislation to increase the sales tax on luxury cars from 30 per cent to 50 per cent has been debated in this chamber and in the other place at great length by the Opposition. The concerns about that tax have been more than adequately argued. I would like to add my voice to the concerns about the way in which this legislation was introduced. Mr Keating constantly demonstrates his total disregard for this process, for this place, for the other place, and for the parliamentary process. We should never forget that the Treasurer does not even bother to get his tax return in on time. He has a disregard for one of the committees of this chamber that is held in high regard throughout the Westminster system-the Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills.

For those who are not aware and those who are not in this chamber at the moment, that Committee comprises three Government and three non-Government members who look at each Bill to make sure that the clauses contained in them do not infringe on the rights of individuals and do not take away the rights and powers of elected parliament. The Committee looks at some other things but, basically, those are the issues which the Committee addresses.

Recently four of us from this Senate went to Great Britain to take part in the Third Commonwealth Conference on Delegated Legislation. At that conference, countries such as the United Kingdom and Canada, as well as other Commonwealth countries, were very interested in this process and in the Scrutiny of Bills Committee. This Committee was set up to protect the rights of citizens. Almost all Ministers respond to that Committee when concerns and queries are raised about Bills.

The 1987-88 annual report of the Scrutiny of Bills Committee-its latest report-reports that only one Minister had not responded to comments made to him that year. The Chairman of that Committee-a Government member-had the unenviable task of bringing this to the attention of the Senate. In that report the Chairman said:

It is an unhappy situation when a single minister, responsible for some of the most important legislation that comes before the parliament, decides that he cannot respond to a parliamentary committee about whether legislation could undermine personal rights or parliamentary prerogatives.

It ought to be of concern to all Australians that someone who is a pretender to the throne of the prime ministership holds in such blatant disregard a committee which is considered, by this chamber and by the other, as one of the most important committees in protecting the rights and privileges of Australian citizens. And it was the Treasurer, who introduced this latest bit of legislation by press release. The last time I spoke on a tax Bill was in November 1988. I am not given to speaking on tax Bills very often.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are doing very well.

—I thank Senator Baume. I got up to speak on that occasion because it was some taxation on non-cash business benefits. In February 1985 the Treasurer issued a press release telling people that non-cash business benefits would be taxed. Whether we agree with the taxing of non-cash business benefits or whether we agree with increasing sales tax on cars above a certain cost is irrelevant when we see the way in which Mr Keating has introduced these pieces of tax legislation. In February 1985 the Treasurer announced that there would be tax on non-cash business benefits. I would like to remind the Senate that that legislation came into this chamber 3 3/4 years later. So people who had won prizes selling Tupperware and people who had won trips for various achievements in business were left with a degree of uncertainty as to whether they would be taxed retrospectively on those benefits. I think that is intolerable.

SPEECH.PARA: It is intolerable, too, that the Treasurer announced in February the tax level on cars costing more than $42,910 would increase from 30 per cent to 50 per cent on 1 April. Then, for some reason, he changed the date to 1 May-presumably, as he said, to make it easier for the car dealers. The problems caused by that announcement and the change in the date of effect left dealers in what Mr Michael Delaney, the Director of the Motor Traders Association of Australia, has termed as an impossible situation. He said that while Mr Keating has claimed that the change of date was intended to assist motor dealers in administration, it did not do that and it resulted in the dealers being in a situation which was unacceptable.

TALK.START.PARA: —It would make them law-breakers.

—They did not know whether they should collect the tax, and if they did so, under the legislation that existed then, would they be law-breakers-as Senator Michael Baume has said-or if they did not collect tax would they be likely to be subject to having to contribute or find this tax payable. It also placed the Commissioner of Taxation in the unacceptable situation of not being able to implement existing law.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not believe that we, as a parliament, should accept this process. Mr Keating, the Treasurer, should be subjected-as citizens, we are subjected to putting in our tax returns on time-to the need to respect the traditions of this place. He should reply to committees such as the Standing Committee on the Scrutiny of Bills and not abrogate the role of law, issue press releases and then bring in legislation retrospectively. It is not acceptable.

Irrespective of the argument about the tax itself-that is another debate-the process by which this legislation was introduced should be enough to convince someone like Senator Vallentine, who has now left the chamber having made her two-minute speech, that the process itself is wrong. That is why she should vote against it; that is why the Australian Democrats should vote against it. It is totally unacceptable to have this process and the sooner Mr Keating learns this, the better. Therefore, I cannot support this legislation for the reasons that have been outlined by Opposition senators, but in particular because of my grave fear and concern about Mr Keating's method of introducing this legislation and his total disregard for this place.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that in my capacity as the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer it is not appropriate, at this stage, for me to respond in detail to the points raised in the second reading debate. All I intend to do is thank honourable senators for their contributions to the debate, to which I listened with interest. I urge honourable senators to support the second reading of the Sales Tax Laws Amendment Bill 1990, essentially for the reasons outlined in the second reading speech by the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button).
—by leave-I ask the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Mr McMullan) whether at any stage a Minister will be available who can answer the questions that we may have regarding this Bill.

—by leave-During the committee stage, I will be happy to answer questions that are raised. A procedural question has been raised with me-I understand that this is a concern of the Opposition-about the way in which second reading debates are conducted. This does not apply to the committee stage.

—by leave-I think it was somewhat remiss of the Government not to provide the Parliament with the opportunity to hear the Government's response to the issues that have been raised by the Opposition and other parties in the Parliament. I call upon the Government to make that facility available through any mechanism that it believes is appropriate to fit the forms of this chamber.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-If members of the Opposition are saying to me that they actually do not have any objection to my responding to the matters that have been raised on behalf of the Opposition, I would be delighted to do it. As I say, my understanding is that the concerns were not raised by the Government but by the Opposition. I think this is a matter that needs to be clarified, not just for this Bill but for future legislation. Some matters were raised which seem to me to warrant some response. A lot of useful general attitudes about tax matters that were raised were standard and appropriate and do not require a specific response from me.

SPEECH.PARA: The three specific points raised concern the date of operation of the legislation and the implications of that; the revenue estimates; and the implications for our trading position overall, particularly in relation to the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT). I will address the date of operation question first. It is not correct to say that there are no provisions to deal with a taxpayer's obligation during the period between 1 May and the day on which the Bills are enacted. Sales tax amendments always have a date of operation, typically the date of announcement. They are not usually announced outside the Budget, but that is not unique. The explanatory memorandum sets out the situation that applies in the relevant sales tax procedures legislation. It deals with the implications that arise when a car is sold before the amendments are formally enacted.

People are entitled to raise their concern about what they call legislation by press release. The point of whether or not the law covers adequately the arrangements which an individual needs to make to protect his or her position as a taxpayer in relation to the Australian Taxation Office is adequately addressed in the explanatory memorandum and is set out in the normal way with regard to the sales tax procedures legislation.

Senator Chapman raised the issue of revenue estimate. I am not sure whether other honourable senators did likewise because I was not able to hear everybody's contributions. I know that he did so and I assume that others did so too. This is a matter which is not capable of proof in advance. We all know that they are estimates and history may prove us all wrong. The figure may be different from that which any of us have calculated-the low figure that Senator Chapman or, as I understand from his indication, Senator Watson calculated, or the $105m that the Government has calculated. Obviously this is not the first time that these concerns have been raised in the Senate chamber. They have been raised in public discussions by politicians, economists and others. That is not unusual, of course.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government has completely ignored the price elasticity of demand.

—I am about to come to that. When tax changes are made we nearly always come to the question of price elasticity of demand, which is a very inexact measure, prospectively or retrospectively. But nobody knows for sure and certain assumptions are made. There seems to be some evidence that the price elasticity of demand of these higher priced products is much lower and that it tends to respond much less significantly to changes in price than would be the case with a similar tax change on lower priced products. I cannot prove that in advance but there is a fair degree of evidence that that is the situation with products such as this. It is reasonable to assume that such will be the case again. All I can say is that when these concerns were expressed publicly, the revenue estimates were rechecked and came essentially to the same conclusion. Therefore, the Government remains satisfied with the revenue estimates and does not wish to vary them in any way. Certainly the different estimates of what might be the appropriate revenue outcome are not a basis for rejecting the legislation. But the Government remains confident that that is the appropriate measure. It is a pity that Senator Watson is not in the chamber at the moment, but I welcome his support and that of everybody else for the reduction in the tax on vehicles used by people with disabilities-the so-called metrocab part of the legislation. I appreciate that and merely acknowledge that agreement.

SPEECH.PARA: With regard to the GATT principles and this legislation, I have seen some press statements based on an assumption that this legislation will somehow undermine our position in the GATT. It is true that some overseas delegations have raised with Australia a concern that this legislation may have a potential impact on the import of their cars. But those people substantially represent countries which have luxury sales taxes on cars. They have very similar taxes to that which is proposed.

The tax which we are proposing applies to domestic and imported products, not only theoretically but also in fact, and is, therefore, consistent with the GATT principles. Although it is true that most of the cars which are affected will be imported, it is also true that most imported cars will not be affected. Less than 20 per cent of imported cars will be subject to the 50 per cent tax.

The Government's overall tariff policies and the decision to abolish the tariff quotas on cars in April 1988, which did seem to escape some people in the debate, have led to a situation where we are quite confident that there is nothing in this legislation which is in any way inconsistent with the GATT principles or with the position we are arguing in the GATT.

The key argument is the date of operation of the tax. The evidence remains that this is the usual procedure for dealing with legislation which is necessarily announced with a date of operation in advance of the date on which the legislation passes the Parliament. The interpretation is straightforward and standard, and the law is clear and set out in the explanatory memorandum. As far as we can tell, the revenue estimate is satisfactory, appropriate and accurate and there is no breach of the GATT principles.

Although I welcome the debate and many of the sensible points that were raised by people in general discussion about the possible implication of this legislation and the concerns which they expressed from their philosophical viewpoint, I do not accept any of the arguments for the withdrawal of the legislation, and I will deal with the detail of the amendment when we get to the committee stage.
Question put:
That the Bills be now read a second time.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: Bills read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The Bills.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-To the Sales Tax Laws Amendment Bill 1990, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Page 1, clause 2, lines 7 and 8, leave out the clause.
To the Sales Tax (Nos 1-9) Amendment Bills 1990, I move:
That the House of Representatives be requested to make the following amendment to each Bill:
Page 1, clause 2, lines 8 and 9, leave out the clause.

I commend my colleagues on this side of the chamber for their very valuable contributions to this debate. I draw the Committee's attention particularly to the very moving and sensitive speech about freedoms and the rule of law by my colleague Senator Patterson. This is the thrust of our amendments to clause 2. The amendments will delete the operative date of 1 May. Our understanding is that the Bills will then come into effect 28 days after royal assent.

I will put to the Committee our grounds for moving these amendments. First, there is the rule of law problem. Secondly, there is a lack of sound economic rationale for the introduction of this tax. Having lost the vote on the motion for the second reading, we have moved these amendments. In that second reading debate, we brought to the Senate's attention the nature of the introduction of these changes to the law. Legislation by press release is wrong as a matter of principle. Our amendments seek to overcome these fundamental objections that we, and I understand the Australian Democrats, have. There will also be a negative effect on long-term employment in the industry.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition has moved amendments relating to the starting dates of the Sales Tax Laws Amendment Bill 1990 and the Sales Tax (Nos 1-9) Amendment Bills 1990. Starting dates are a particular problem in quite a number of pieces of tax legislation. Over the years we have debated how to best deal with these matters. Normally, the Government makes an announcement, usually on Budget night, as to when laws are deemed to commence.

SPEECH.PARA: There are a number of very good reasons for that. Changes of one kind or another to taxation law can cause problems if they are known beforehand. Hence, the normal exercise of secrecy on the Budget. Obviously, people would be able to make windfall profits and gains if there had been an announcement of the changes to be introduced as from the Budget. In those circumstances, it is obvious that the Parliament would then introduce retrospective legislation in as much as the date of commencement of that piece of legislation would predate its passage in this place.

I took Senator Patterson's comments during the second reading debate to refer to an almost total prohibition on that type of action. I find that strange. I was here during the last Fraser Government and that was the normal course then; it is the normal course now. As a means of operation I think it will continue.

However, there are other changes to taxation legislation that do not fall within that category. For a number of other reasons, it is often advisable that the starting dates of these pieces of legislation precede the dates of their passage in this chamber. For example, if the Government has alighted upon a rort in the income tax system, the Treasurer (Mr Keating) has usually made an announcement that the particular loophole will be closed as of that date. That legislation has normally been passed by the Parliament. It is not acceptable to say, `This rort has been discovered. When we get round to passing the legislation it will apply as at that particular time'.

Senator Patterson-and indeed it was contained in some of Senator Watson's comments-verged on suggesting that the Opposition would no longer support that type of proposition. I find that strange. It is important to accept that the Government needs to be able to make legislation operative as from the date of its announcement.

Some years ago we were sufficiently concerned about the Government's action on taxation measures that we wrote to the Treasurer and to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) setting out the criteria that we would accept in the future regarding legislation which had been announced by press release. One of the criteria was that the legislation ought to be introduced within six months of the date of its announcement, and when the announcement was made it was a detailed announcement so that people could operationalise their taxation measures concerning that announcement.

This has not always been the case. Indeed, in the last few years there have been some celebrated instances where announcements of changes of dates to legislation were made but the legislation did not appear in this chamber for more than a year. In one case I think it was 18 months. This is completely unacceptable. The government cannot say to people, `You will arrange your taxation measures with regard to this press release' and then not give them the necessary details.

I will not go into the other criteria in that statement that we sent to the Prime Minister because they are really not relevant to this issue. But this matter falls outside our announcements and the statement that we made to the Treasurer and to the Prime Minister as to how we would operate. However, it relates to income tax changes or company tax changes. Of course, the strict legal liability of both those taxes does not come into effect until 30 June-the end of the financial year. Pay as you earn taxpayers, and others of course, were paying in instalments over time.

The area which we are now dealing with does not relate to that. We have a difficulty in telling people to collect taxes-in this case a third party; people who were wholesaling vehicles to retailers-for which there is no legal basis to collect. The Treasurer said, `Go ahead and collect it, and at some stage we will get some legal support for you'.

In other cases, the people who are collecting the income and company taxes are not a third party as such but, legally, the Executive Government through its departmental structures. That is really quite different from a private individual being required to collect tax as a result of legislation, but with no law under which he can operate. It is a very difficult situation in which to put a private citizen.

As it so happens with regard to this legislation, the amendment probably does not make a great deal of difference to Government revenue because, as everybody already knows, one cannot buy a car now without the sales tax already having been paid on it. If one looks at the sale of luxury vehicles in the last couple of months, it is fairly obvious that any luxury vehicle anywhere in Australia technically has already been bought by somebody. Normally, most of the cars one sees in showrooms are not the property of the retailer. Every luxury vehicle that one now sees in a showroom in Australia is the property of a retailer. The reasons for that are fairly obvious. Marketplace pressures have forced people into undertaking that commitment, which is unfortunate for many retailers who now carry very large loans, which they had to raise to be able to pay for the vehicles that are sitting on their floors. I suppose that they are hoping that the sales will continue. One could not sell a luxury vehicle with the new sales tax on it either this month, next month or probably for the next few months, because such vehicles are still available at the old sales tax rate.

Hence, whether the amendment moved by the Opposition is passed or not will make no difference to Government revenue. Since there is no revenue difference, my Party, having supported the principle of increasing the tax on luxury vehicles-it has been a policy of my Party for many years that these taxes be levied-believes, however, that it needs to be done correctly. We believe that the correct manner in this case is that the tax is increased in a fashion that does not leave a private individual in the community exposed to engaging in tax collection without legislative support for such collection. Hence, we propose to support the Opposition.

We would have preferred to put in a date. The reason for that is that I have spent quite some considerable time over the last few years arguing that we ought to have dates in legislation as to when it commences. I find it a bit strange that we are actually supporting the taking out of a date. The trouble is that it is the wrong date. I would much prefer to have inserted a date because I do not believe that this chamber should any longer simply agree to the passing of legislation, as it used to, allowing the bureaucrats to set the date as to when legislation should start. As honourable senators will know almost every piece of legislation that has come in in the last six months starts either on the date of proclamation or six months from the date of passage of the legislation. So, essentially, there is a time frame in which we give the bureaucracy the chance to get together any regulations that need to be in place at the time we proclaim legislation.

I had hoped that the Opposition would have moved an amendment to put a date in the legislation. Unfortunately Senator Watson, who moved this amendment, is not listening. If I can speak to him on this matter, perhaps he may consider my suggestion that he has actually perpetrated another difficulty in the way he has structured this amendment by not putting in a date.

As I was just setting out, the Senate has now insisted dates be put in legislation. The Government, acceding to the wishes of this chamber, has issued instructions to the drafting officers that they do that. We would have preferred that a date had been entered-either the date of proclamation or six months after the date of the passage of the legislation, whichever is sooner-as a way of dealing with the matter rather than just simply leaving it wide open. Nevertheless, with that caveat I indicate that we will be supporting this amendment because it regularises a situation that we think is important. In future, we hope that the Government, in this area, deals with these taxes in a more acceptable manner and structures their operation in such a way that individual citizens are not imposed on in the absence of any supportive legislation for undertaking action for the collection of tax on behalf of the Commonwealth.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chapman Sen H.G.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the indication by Senator Macklin that he and his fellow Australian Democrats will be supporting the amendment and the request for amendment made by the Opposition. I also welcome the fact that at least he recognises the administrative incom- petence of the Government in the way it has introduced this legislation. That administrative incompetence only compounds the policy incompetence we have seen with the introduction of this 50 per cent tax.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Macklin has just raised with the Opposition the matter of why we did not put in a specific date for the legislation taking effect. The reason is quite simple. This amendment and the request for amendment, which, it appears, will now be passed in the Senate with the support of the Democrats-they have indicated support for our amendment-will have to be considered by the other place. We do not know what that process will be, what time consideration will take, whether the House will be recalled or whether this matter will be left to be considered in the Budget session. Therefore, it would be most unwise to put a specific date in the legislation, and it will take effect as from 28 days after the legislation receives royal assent. Therefore, we are not bound to a specific date which may become irrelevant if the other place has not dealt with the legislation before that date. I hope that Senator Macklin will accept that reasoning on our part.

Of course, one of the main reasons for moving this amendment is that, under section 70d (1) and (2) of the Sales Tax Assessment Act 1930, it is a clear offence to require payment of an amount in excess of the amount of the sales tax which may be properly charged. It would be an offence for a wholesaler of vehicles to seek to charge the 50 per cent sales tax before an Act to levy such a rate was passed by this Parliament, received royal assent and took effect 28 days later. As Senator Macklin has said in his remarks, this tax announcement is not the same as other tax announcements which are often made in advance of legislation where the tax is collected by the Government itself. In this situation, the dealers-that is, private business persons-will be required to collect the tax on behalf of the Government and, as I have said, would be acting illegally in doing that. For the Government to apply legislation in a way which makes private citizens act illegally is simply not good enough. That is quite a different situation from the Government acting illegally by collecting tax in advance of legislation. The dealers would clearly be acting illegally and would be subject to heavy penalties for doing so. On the other hand, if they charge customers only the 30 per cent tax which the existing legislation provides, they would later be hit retrospectively by the Australian Taxation Office for the additional 20 per cent and possibly penalties as well and they would not in any way be able to recover legally that additional 20 per cent from their customers.

It is simply not good enough for the Government to put dealers, private citizens and private business people in this double jeopardy situation by trying to force them to collect from consumers taxes which are illegal and remain illegal until the appropriate legislation is passed through the Parliament to change the existing law. That is why the Opposition has moved this amendment. I urge the Committee to support the amendment, and I welcome the indication of support from the Democrats.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to express some pretty grave concern about the step which the Opposition and the Australian Democrats appear about to take on this matter, not because the Senate does not have the right either to make the request or pass the amendment in whichever way it is appropriately couched-quite clearly, it is a matter within the authority of the Senate, so I am not raising a concern in terms of proper rights-but because I think we are acting in ways the consequences of which are not going to be desirable, based on some information that is less than adequate. It is going to cause problems, not for the Government or the Australian Taxation Office, because the money has not been forwarded to the Taxation Office-the consequences of this change are not going to be refunds which the Taxation Office has to make-but for wholesalers and retailers. It is going to have very odd effects out in the marketplace, and it has some consequences in terms of proper political process that I think have not been considered.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Macklin outlined more adequately than I have heard anybody else do the essential rationale under which sales tax legislation always takes effect from a date before that on which the amendments to the tax are formally enacted. He quite correctly outlined that principle. It is a proper principle and one that has been applied by governments of all political persuasions for many years and will continue to happen.

As far as I can tell this legislation is not unique, but I am not in a position to cite chapter and verse, so for the moment I will assume that it is, although I think that is not the case. What distinguishes this legislation is that we had an incumbent government saying, `If we are re-elected we will change that sales tax legislation'. If the Opposition and the Democrats say that that is a variation to the normal procedure which a government is not entitled to make, they are saying that sales tax rates are not matters which effectively can be issues in the election, because the date of operation will have to be some time at least two months after the date it is announced, possibly more. In fact, if this procedure is undertaken, it will be four months. The commercial, political and electoral consequences of that are absurd. I ask Opposition senators to just think about that.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are not claiming a mandate for this, are you?

—That is not the point, but I did not expect Senator Chapman to understand. The point is that, in terms of proper process, it is entirely appropriate and normal, and the practice of all governments of whatever political flavour, carried by this chamber on many occasions, to have dates of operation that are prior to the final enactment of the legislation. That is necessary and, as far as I know, unchallenged, although some of the things honourable senators said in the debates seemed to challenge it, but I am sure that is not what they meant.

SPEECH.PARA: The rights of taxpayers, as I outlined in the somewhat belated response I made to the second reading, are protected in the proper discharge of their duties under the Act by the Sales Tax Procedure Act 1934. So that problem does not really arise. What we have is a slight variation on the usual practice of Budget or economic statement announcement of sales tax changes and the introduction of legislation. That would be a problem if this were a Bill introducing new definitions into the sales tax legislation, saying, `A new category of goods is going to be defined and, therefore, the tax on that will be different and, therefore, you have to guess what we mean by this new category'.

That is not the case on this occasion; an existing, precisely defined category which everybody knows and understands is being shifted to a new rate. There is no question of details which the taxpayer might reasonably be required to know being unavailable. There is no missing detail because there are no changes of definition. There is no doubt about which products are affected.

We have to think about the consequences should these amendments and requests be carried. We are saying that such distortions that have taken place in the marketplace caused by the lapse of time between the announcement by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and 1 May, the consequences of which for certain retailers seem to be a cause of concern, at least to the Democrats, are going to be exacerbated. We are going to have, certainly for a short time, uncertainty about what is going to happen at all because the Government will take some time to say what it is going to do in response to this. Even if the Government is prepared to accept this proposal, we then have a situation where it is some six weeks of further delay in the application of this change.

Intelligent, informed senators on the other side of the chamber are concerned that the delay that has taken place in trying to get legislation has caused some adverse consequences to people who may have excessive stocks and that now we are saying that they have to do it for a further six weeks; that we are saying, `Here, we will make this problem more difficult for them'. It is very straightforward, and it is a serious problem. Even Opposition senators, senators who hold the balance of power, have an obligation to think about the consequences of their actions, and I ask them to do so.

It is not that this is a big administrative problem for the Government. It is almost certain that none of the money that has been collected has been forwarded to the Government. It is likely that the first effective date on which it would need to be forwarded is 21 June. So I am not saying that the Government is going to be caused great difficulty; I am saying that the market and the operators out there are going to be caused great difficulty-it is a very straightforward point-and for no net gain.

I do not understand the great point of principle that distinguishes this from the normal sales tax procedure. I do appreciate that we may have found ourselves in a new situation-in the experience of those of us here, though I think not unique-with regard to how, when an announcement about sales tax policy is made in an election context, the date of operation is determined. I do not think we want to create the situation where that is not a matter that can properly be debated in an electoral context and such announcements cannot be made. It seems to me to be a perfectly proper democratic process that it ought to be able to be debated, but if it is the desire of the Opposition or the Democrats that there be some discussion, some dialogue, about how such matters ought to be dealt with in an election context, I am very happy to participate in that dialogue-this does not seem to be the best place or context in which to initiate such discussion-so that we can have a clear and, hopefully, agreed enunciation of the principles.

I have always understood that the principle that sales tax operates from the date of announcement has been an agreed principle in the past. If we need to say, `Let us look at how that principle applies when sales tax is an issue in an election, when the Parliament is not sitting and there is no capacity for the Government to take such an initiative', let us do so. But let us not try to do it after we have made a change, the consequences of which are adverse. Some people say they are minor. That might be the case, because we do not know, in terms of tax collection, but the market consequences are not irrelevant.

To some extent I think the Opposition is putting an imposition on the people it is trying to help. I suggest that with all those arguments compounded by the drafting matter which Senator Macklin has raised, it would be much more appropriate if the legislation were to be passed as originally introduced by the Government. If people do detect a new element of principle about dates of operation of sales taxes, let us have a debate about that principle separate from this legislation and try to come to some agreement about how proper practice might be pursued in the future, but not at the expense of this legislation and with the consequences that will follow from this proposal.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to take this opportunity of welcoming Senator McMullan to his new post as a Parliamentary Secretary, particularly with his involvement in taxation legislation. I believe that his thoughtful mind will bring a refreshing change from some of the dogma that has pervaded debates on these matters in the past. I believe it is indeed refreshing to hear from Senator McMullan, as the spokesman in this area, his concern about the consequences that will be felt by some of the people who are going to be affected by this legislation. I only hope that this concern is not confined to this particular legislation. I hope that Senator McMullan's interest, enthusiasm and concern will be translated into Bills that are yet to be debated during this session of this Parliament, because similar issues about the effect of Government legislation on particular people will undoubtedly be raised.

SPEECH.PARA: I remind Senator McMullan in relation to the setting of this date, 1 May, that it is the Government that has control of the parliamentary calendar-when parliament sits and when matters are debated. It is no use Senator McMullan appealing passionately to the Opposition, saying, `We are sorry, but we now appeal to the Opposition to try to get the Government off the hook, not to embarrass it'. After all, it is the Government's responsibility for its present dilemma. It got it wrong. It is the Government's proposed legislative amendment that offends this principle of the sanctity of the rule of law. It is the Government's legislation that offends its own principles, as explained in the Legislation Handbook issued by the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet. That handbook outlines the sorts of issues that should be subject to press release but not those as manifested in this sort of legislation.

We are in accord with the principle laid down in that Prime Minister and Cabinet handbook, that where there is significant lost revenue, or abuse, the sorts of procedures that the Government has adopted today are not necessary under those guidelines. But there is absolutely no excuse for adopting the procedure and the particular date the Government has chosen in the circumstances under review.

I do not want to repeat, but I would like to acknowledge, the explanation that has been given by my colleague Senator Chapman as to why, as an opposition, we did not put down a specific date in replacement of 1 May. Again, we as an opposition, have no charge for or control over the parliamentary calendar and, if we had put down a date, the Government could very conveniently had led the Opposition into the same situation as the Government has found itself in. We are not going to be led into that trap.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have only a couple of comments. I accept a number of the points that were raised by Senator McMullan. I think they are correct. But, as Senator Watson has just pointed out, the Senate did not come up with this legislation. It did not actually timetable it, and it did not organise it. It is now dealing with it in the time frame in which the Government wished it to deal with it.
—It wasn't even supposed to be on today.

—No, it was not. It would probably have come on in a couple of days time, so the Government is getting this debate early. With regard to the uncertainties that may arise, again, they are not caused by this chamber; they are caused by the Government. It was not required to engage in this type of operation. I am not sure why we have had the long discourse about the election; possibly there is something in the second reading speech which I did not hear. I think that in an election campaign it is perfectly open to a government to say that if it gets back into power it is going to raise taxes on luxury cars and so on. That is the essence of an election. It has nothing to do with how the legislation is finally dealt with, however. The Government may suggest the starting dates it wants, but it is up to Parliament to determine which starting dates it gets.

SPEECH.PARA: This particular instance is quite different, as I suggested before, in terms of the Budget context. The whole exercise has been dealt with in a very expeditious manner. But it is turning into a very dragged out matter and, as I understand Senator McMullan, it is likely to be dragged out even more as the Government contemplates what to do about it all.

With regard to that, there is one issue that sometimes gets a run in the press-and if Senator Walsh were here undoubtedly he would be out of this chamber in a flash, raising it again-and that is the bit about the House of Representatives. I will state very clearly my party's position with regard to the House of Representatives. We will deal with legislation as it is presented in this chamber. I am terribly sorry, but I cannot say that we will do any more. We will deal with it as it is presented in this chamber. Whether the House of Representatives is sitting is irrelevant to the legislation.

I understand that the Opposition will not take that position on other Bills which we may be debating in a few days time, such as the wool tax legislation, but our position is very clear: whether the House of Representatives is sitting is irrelevant to amendments which are presented to Bills which come before this chamber, from our viewpoint.

If the Government wishes to reorganise the sittings of the House of Representatives to take account of what happens in this chamber, that is fine. But it is in the Government's hands. If the House of Representatives comes back again it will not be a massive imposition, considering it has sat for seven days in the first half of this year. Members of the House of Representatives are not likely to be worn out by that particular exercise. It will only take them a minute or two to dispose of this legislation, as they never have a committee stage and do not debate legislation anyhow. Dealing with this in the House of Representatives will not stretch anybody's brain power or endurance.

I wanted to make that very clear. Senator McMullan did not raise this, and he may feel I am getting overwrought. He did not raise the House of Representatives as an excuse but I thought he was about to get to it so I thought I would pre-empt it in case he was coming back to it. The legislation can be dealt with by the House of Representatives returning, if that is deemed to be an efficient way of dealing with it. I suggest, in terms of a cost benefit analysis, it would be an appalling way to deal with it. I have here motor vehicle registrations for the month of February compared with March. We find that BMWs have gone up by 112 per cent; Jaguars and Daimlers by 264 per cent; and Rolls Royces by 300 per cent-that is only from four registrations to 16, but considering the cost of those cars, that is extraordinary.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about a poor man's car, like the LTD?
—That might be Senator Panizza's working man's car, but it is not mine. Mercedes cars went up by 197 per cent, Saabs by 176 per cent, and Volvos by 127 per cent.

SPEECH.PARA: It is fairly obvious that there is no way in the world that those types of volumes could be sustained in a normal market. In fact, the market has already had a hiccup built into it, and that hiccup will take six to 12 months to be ironed out. In fact, the dealers do not expect that to be sustained. They expect a fall-off in retail sales not only back to the February mark-which, in itself, was historically on a high because of a number of factors such as transport strikes-but much lower. The effect of this tax, of course, is also likely to depress the market, although the length of time over which this will occur is difficult to predict.

Nevertheless, I think there is unlikely to be any revenue collected from this exercise for quite some months. Hence, I think it is probably a matter for the Government to deal with in the House of Representatives in the Budget session, without any loss of revenue. I do not think there is an issue involved here. If any tax has been collected and I would find it strange if there has-that is, if any comes through-there will be a small number of items which will be able to be dealt with with administrative ease.

I am sorry that already Senator McMullan seems to have fallen into the Yes Minister exercise of saying that it will be administratively difficult. We might hear about the constitutional difficulties shortly and a number of other problems. It is not administratively difficult; it is administratively easy. There are, in fact, no hitches or problems with changing the date. The whole thing will be capable of being worked out in a very easy, simple and straightforward fashion.

There are no problems with the documentation of this whole exercise. People would not pay in the order of $300,000 for a car and then not want the dealer to know where they were. They want the dealers to know precisely where they are, because all the cars will still be under warranty. Therefore, everyone's whereabouts will be easily ascertainable. I think it was a good try in terms of Senator McMullan creating a few problems, but there are none. It will be a simple, straightforward matter. It can be dealt with either when the House of Representatives returns next week, as has been foreshadowed, or, if it does not come back, in August when, in terms of the revenue, the situation will be identical.
Question put:
That the amendment and requests be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

Sales Tax Laws Amendment Bill 1990 reported with an amendment and Sales Tax (Nos 1 to 9) Amendment Bills 1990 reported with requests; report adopted.
