DEBATE.TITLE: SUPERANNUATION BILL 1990SUPERANNUATION LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1990SUPERANNUATION BENEFITS (SUPERVISORY MECHANISMS) BILL 1990OCCUPATIONAL SUPERANNUATION (REASONABLE BENEFIT LIMITS) AMENDMENT BILL 1990

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 17 and 21 May, on motion by Senator Robert Ray:
That these Bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition welcomes the recently discovered community recognition that a properly structured superannuation scheme provides the best opportunity to enjoy the increasing longevity which most of us can look forward to. However, there are a number of salient statistics that I think make it imperative that we address the issues sooner rather than later. There are currently some 1.9 million persons over the age of 65 and about 2 per cent of the population are currently over 80 years. The Bill for age and veterans pensions is around $10 billion per annum and the tab is currently being picked up by six persons in the work force for every one elderly person. Within 30 years the position will be quite different. Those over 65 will have more than doubled to 3.9 million, almost 20 per cent of the population, and there will be only three persons in the work force to support each one of them. The number of persons over 80 will have trebled to approximately 6 per cent of the work force.

SPEECH.PARA: This rapidly growing army will be the most intensive users of a vast range of health and community services. Our capacity to provide proper care to contribute to their enjoyment of life will be significantly diminished if the numbers of those dependent upon welfare, as almost 78 per cent are today, remain at current levels. It is therefore imperative that we put in place as quickly as possible an effective retirement incomes policy which will give the vast majority of the population a proper retirement incomes policy for their later years.

I want to refer to some of the remarks of Professor Bettina Cass, who in many ways has been a leader in the debate in this area. In June of last year she set out the basic principles of an equitable and sustainable retirement incomes policy. We do not cavil with the bulk of those. Certainly to the extent that it is necessary to have economic security, psychological security and stability we fully recognise that need. The adequacy question, as she describes it, requires sufficient income to meet not only basic needs but the requirements necessary to participate fully in the social life of the community. Superannuation pensioners, as she points out, currently provide only about 10 per cent of people's income in retirement. In many ways that is the nub of the problem. It is therefore profoundly significant that the ageing of the population is a challenge to all taxpayers. The Superannuation Bill 1990 is one that our descendants will have to face up to in the same way that current taxpayers are finding that their liabilities are ever increasing.

The savings investment gap, that is, the shortfall of domestic saving compared with investment, is currently of the order of 5 per cent of gross domestic product, which is about the current proportion constituted by the current account deficit. It is clear that substantial increases in savings must be the top priority. People must be encouraged to save for their own retirement. In order to do that it is a matter of ensuring that there is a higher lever of productivity in order to contribute to higher levels of funding. It simply solves nothing if we attempt to address the problem by transferring funds from employers to employees or on to superannuation funds.

Our gross foreign debt at present, as we are all acutely aware, is approaching $150 billion. Australia now has a downgraded credit rating and higher risk premiums. As a result, domestic interest rates are much higher than they ought to be because of the shortage of savings. All of those factors make it imperative that we should attempt to boost the savings ratio as much as possible. Again, one of the significant difficulties we will have to face is that simply transferring funds into superannuation funds will not necessarily solve the problem because there is likely to be a significant substitution effect which will simply mean that savings are being transferred from one vehicle to another. It is imperative that we get the total level of savings much higher than it is at present.

The principal package which the Senate is currently addressing involves the introduction of a new Commonwealth superannuation scheme which is said to bring the Commonwealth superannuation arrangements `substantially into line with the private sector'. To some extent this is a euphemistic description which disguises the fact that the Commonwealth has been exceedingly generous in the past and is now exceedingly anxious to reduce its commitments under what has to date been a totally unfunded scheme, currently costing some $896m, just to maintain current levels. It has been estimated that there is something in the order of $50 billion of unfunded liabilities in existing Commonwealth, State and statutory authority schemes. The new scheme, which will be optional for existing employers to join-optional for a period of 12 months; it will be compulsory for new members-will be funded only as regards future liabilities.

There are a number of positive aspects to the new legislation. Employer contributions will fully vest after four years, although we take the view that that ought to be a much faster timetable. This is in stark contrast to the existing regime, under which employer contributions do not vest at all until retirement, causing many thousands of contributors over the years to miss out altogether. It also allows temporary employees to join the scheme after three months as of right and not, as under the old scheme, after one year and then only subject to approval. It also adopts the new reasonable benefits limits (RBLs) which will be based on highest salary over three consecutive years, a much fairer system than the current final average salary and one which is designed to ensure that those who choose to scale down their employment prior to retirement are not disadvantaged.

Under the old scheme the employee contribution was fixed at 5 per cent, compared to an employer contribution of up to 18 per cent. Whilst this imbalance certainly delivered bonanzas for many, it did little to encourage responsible saving by employees. The new scheme introduces a new flexible approach which allows employees to contribute between 2 and 10 per cent depending on the current economic circumstances.

However, whilst this has a superficial attraction of being geared to capacity to pay, I would strongly suspect that for many workers it will simply provide an opportunity to scale down to the minimum and thereafter never have the discretionary income or the savings will-power to make up the difference later, thereby simply compounding the inadequacy of the scheme as a serious attempt to replace the current arrangements. It will be necessary for employees to average something of the order of 5 or 6 per cent of their contributions over their lifetime in order to maximise their entitlements under the reasonable benefits limit regime.

I think the Commonwealth hopes that in this area employees will take that on board as a self-imposed discipline. I would have thought it is very likely that human nature suggests that they will do that only with a much greater level of incentive or, indeed, discipline than is currently provided to them.

The new scheme effectively endorses 55 years as the de facto retirement age. That is the outcome of a deal between the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) and the Government. The former, the trade union movement, is to be commended for embracing superannuation and accepting the logic of deferred earnings in retirement as an outcome very much in the best long-term interests of the work force.

But the gap between this early retirement norm and the current pension age, especially for males, who are the major recipients of superannuation payments, is very substantial and will inevitably constitute an overwhelming temptation for many to celebrate their departure from the work force by a round of short-term consumption expenditure items. To the extent that this involves paying off the mortgage it can be defended to some extent, although the preferred course may be, at that time in life, to trade down to a smaller home.

But the most disturbing aspect of the new scheme is undoubtedly the dramatic movement away from compulsory pensions to lump sums, a move which makes us almost unique in the Western world, and I suspect uniquely irresponsible, because that is what this move is. Whilst it is dressed up in pious rhetoric about providing incentive to encourage retirees to prefer pensions-and it certainly does that-the reality is that, as the Government well knows, the vast majority are likely to grab the honey pot every time, dissipate it to varying extents and then get into the double dipping trough, one of the greatest rorts in the welfare system, to which this Government is prepared not only to turn a blind eye but actually to encourage.

This becomes very obvious when one reads the contribution of the honourable member for Capricornia (Mr Wright) in the debate in the House of Representatives. He professes to be an expert in the field. He might get high marks for initiative in trying to make a quid out of the exercise by flogging his own publication but his primary responsibility ought to be concern for the national interest, and in this area he has lamentably failed. I invite honourable senators to listen to this for the height of irresponsibility:

We want the right for people to have a lump sum because when they retire they want to pay off the home. The want to buy the new car. They want to take the holiday. They need the dollars in the pocket.

This is surely an invitation to profligacy. There is not one word about the true purpose of superannuation. It is not to update the kitchen, take the trip to Fiji or Ayers Rock; it is to provide a rest-of-life alternative to the aged pension. As usual, the Government-and one can treat Mr Wright as its leading advocate in this area, if only by default-is simply pandering to the short-term self-indulgences that tempt us all.

The Government ought to be endeavouring to put in place an effective retirement incomes policy that will increase savings and provide a secure base for rest-of-life independence and self-support instead of effectively perpetuating the outdated notion that somehow it is the birthright of all taxpayers to pick up a pension in their old age.

The Government has totally abdicated its responsibility in this area. It has made no attempt to respond to the views of Professor Cass and others that it should not be permissible to take more than 50 per cent by way of lump sum. After all, such a proportion would allow for plenty of squandering. But to condone a situation where it is possible to take one's full entitlement in lump sum form despite the taxation incentives not to do so is a grave disservice to the taxpayers of this country.

As my colleagues in the House of Representatives, Mr Braithwaite and Mr Connolly, rightly pointed out, this Government's retirement policy is tax-driven. It was originally the trade-off for lowering the corporate tax rate. Now it is the milch cow on which the Government will increasingly rely to solve its revenue equations. In the last Budget the anticipated receipts for superannuation funds were $885m, and this does not include capital gains and other taxes.

Whilst we certainly support the community desire to move increasingly towards superannuation, we hope that that will be in lieu of the aged pension and we are concerned that there are very many shortcomings in the Government's present approach. An ideal retirement incomes policy has been spelled out by Eric Mayer, Group Managing Director of National Mutual Life Association of Australasia Ltd, and it certainly seems to us that there are many positive aspects to his agenda. He says, in summary:
Further changes are needed to produce an ideal retirement incomes policy, that encourages private provision for retirement:
Common pensionable age for men and women after a suitable transition period . . .

I pause there; to date the Government has done virtually nothing in this area other than to talk about a timetable that is very much out on the distant horizon. But it is not prepared to bite the bullet, which it thinks might somehow upset those who have had long-term dreams. I think we have to find a compromise in this area, we have to be prepared to say that there is a period of notice that is sufficient, and that beyond that people ought to have to change their retirement plans.

Further action is needed to reduce poverty traps, particularly in respect of pensioner concessions. I seem to recall that the proportion of those at least partly reliant on the pension is something like 78 per cent of those of pensionable age, and three-quarters of those are wholly dependent upon the pension.

The eventual extension of preservation to age 65-earlier for special needs cases-is again, I think, a very desirable long-term objective and one which ought to have a short-term approach. Whilst we have talked about the year 2000 as being the starting point for such an approach, the Government again simply prefers that this problem will go away. That is because of the deal that it has basically done with the trade union movement to ensure that people are able to take all of the benefits at age 55. Indeed, many schemes allow earlier retirement ages and the taking of entitlements before that time. Whilst we retain that gap between that retirement age and the pension age, the longer the gap is the greater the incentive for people to double dip.

The Government well knows that. The answer has to be to extend the preservation age. It can be done in stages, it can be done by giving proper length of notice, but unless something is done about that then I think all we will find is the usual mirror and beads trick of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) so that some five or ten years down the track we will be looking at the statistics and saying, `All those great promises you made have not come to fruition'. But it is a bit late in the day to have the recognition at that time. It ought to be obvious to all those who plan in the area-and there are many experts in the field-that unless we take steps to extend the preservation age we will not really be able to cope with what I think is probably the greatest problem in this area.

There is certainly capacity to extend tax deductability for all superannuation contributions up to the extent allowed by reasonable benefits limits. The RBL regime was necessary to ensure that people were not able simply to pile up all their income in their last years, when presumably they had much greater access to funds, and then take out huge entitlements at the end. But in striking a compromise between what is reasonable in terms of concessional deductions and what ought to be then taxed at the marginal rate I would have thought it is in the community's interests that everyone, not just a load of middle income earners, ought to be encouraged to rely much more heavily on their own retirement funds.

There ought to be a much greater pension RBL than the lump sum RBL. the extension of superannuation tax concessions to allow people not in the work force to provide for their own retirement is again something that gets scant recognition from the Government simply because its primary clientele is the trade union movement, and by definition those are people in the work force, although some 60 per cent or more of those in the private sector do not belong to the trade union movement.

It is our view that much more ought to be done to cater for those, often women, who leave the work force, either to have children or for other reasons, and who then are not able to return to the work force, sometimes for a period of years. There seems no good reason why others, be it a spouse or someone else, ought not to be able to contribute on their behalf. Obviously once the contribution is made it ought to then vest in the hands of the beneficiary, the wife in the instance I have quoted, and ought to be fully portable. In that case the position of the person who may be out of the work force for some years is properly protected. That person has been given a head start prior to the return to the work force and has been given a very real prospect of having a nest egg at the end of the day. At the moment that category is simply ignored.

There are a number of other concerns that ought to be expressed about the Government's approach to superannuation. The continuing distinction between a retirement age for men and women does seem to be one that needs to be urgently addressed given that married women not only tend to be younger than their spouses by three to five years but also have a greater life expectancy, which may alter marginally as more and more married women enter the work force. I think the figure currently is in excess of 50 per cent. Nonetheless, it does seem an outmoded distinction in this day and age. We certainly take the view that steps ought to be taken to regularise that position.

In the same way we believe that there ought not to be a compulsory retirement age. In fact, it ought to be illegal as constituting discrimination against the elderly. We understand that there are those in the trade union movement who are keen to see people move on and allow for others to enter the work force. To the extent that it reduces unemployment, I suppose the Government would have an interest in seeing that situation continue. But the reality is that with an ageing population there are many people who wish to remain in the work force as long as possible. Professor Cass dealt with this when she quoted from an Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) survey carried out in 1986 which showed that:

. . . one quarter of those who had reached the compulsory retirement age in their job would have liked to have continued working full-time. In addition, about 25 per cent of full-time employees over the age of 45 would have preferred tapered or gradual retirement . . .
She goes on to say that a proper policy requires:
. . . two fundamental policy changes:
the end of compulsory retirement ages and the introduction of phased and flexible retirement provisions;
anti-discrimination legislation on the basis of age in Commonwealth and States' jurisdictions.
We certainly believe that the Government, for its own client base reasons, has chosen to ignore those recommendations.

There is also concern that the case for increased remuneration in any form ought to be justifiable on the grounds of productivity. In that context I think it is very disturbing, despite the grand rhetoric of Senator Cook as quoted in today's Australian Financial Review, that in the second round of the 3 per cent award negotiations there is no mention of productivity. I noticed that Mr Crean claims that the actual accord agreement between the parties made mention of productivity, but there is absolutely no doubt that the Treasurer's February economic statement made no such mention. That is not only highly symbolic but it is clearly indicative that the Government has thrown in the towel on the productivity pretence. Even the first round has been quite unsatisfactory in terms of progress to date.

The Government is fond of saying that 77 per cent of the work force is now covered, but the fact is that the ABS statistics as at August 1989 showed that the proportion of employees receiving a superannuation benefit is now 47 per cent. That increase includes `the impact of the spread of occupational superannuation following recent national wage case decisions'. Whilst there is a certain degree of humbug already in relation to the first round, I think it is absolutely crucial that the second round ought to be more properly addressed than it has been to date. Probably the major concern in that regard is that there are some schemes that are very generous, some people who do very well under the current arrangements and some people who have good retirement benefits but poor resignation benefits and vice versa.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Before we suspend the sitting for lunch, Senator Alston, do you wish to move your amendment?
—Yes. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: At end of motion add ``, but the Senate:
(a) deplores the determination of the Government to support a mandatory second 3 per cent employer contribution unrelated to productivity or capacity to pay;
(b) condemns the Government for its capitulation to ACTU demands for deferred wage increases in the guise of superannuation payments and its refusal to link preservation to pension age; and
(c) criticises the Government's double standards in preferring pensions in the private sector and lump sums in the public sector'.
Sitting suspended from 12.45 to 2 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs. Is it not the case that Operation Alpha conducted by the Australian Bureau of Criminal Intelligence (ABCI) into the Mafia established Adelaide and its environs as being as important as Griffith in the nationwide network of Mafia families? Did not the ABCI report make a direct connection between Mafia families and political lobbying in South Australia?
—What report did you refer to?

—I referred to that of the Australian Bureau of Criminal Intelligence. Do these established nationwide links not demonstrate why the Commonwealth should cooperate and be a party to a royal commission rather than force New South Wales into a less effective geographically constrained inquiry?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I cannot comment on the Australian Bureau of Criminal Intelligence report under the title Operation Alpha which Senator Hill refers to, but I should remind him that, in relation to links between the Mafia and particularly the growing and distribution of marijuana in this country, all Australian jurisdictions on the mainland-that is, the Federal Government and all State governments-have agreed that the National Crime Authority should conduct an investigation under the title Vigilante. It is that particular investigation which has resulted in many charges being made against a wide variety of persons throughout the Australian community.
—With very few convictions.

—Some charges are still pending rather than having been processed through the courts. The fact is that the various Attorneys-that would include successive Attorneys in the New South Wales Government, for example-have seen the National Crime Authority's investigation into Mafia related matters as being an appropriate response to the various sources of intelligence, including the Australian Bureau of Criminal Intelligence's holdings. They have been an important source of information, no doubt, to the investigators involved.

ANSWER.PARA: Even Mr Greiner in his letter to the Prime Minister concerning his request for a joint royal commission acknowledged the work of the National Crime Authority and, as I recall, dissociated himself from the attack on the National Crime Authority made by Mr Hatton. He refused to adopt that particular denigration of the Authority by Mr Hatton. I believe that the National Crime Authority's reference is an appropriate response by all Australian jurisdictions on the mainland to the phenomenon to which Senator Hill and the Australian Bureau of Criminal Intelligence have pointed.

I have made it clear, nevertheless, that if at the end of the inquest being conducted by Mr Cahill there are matters which require further investigation that would be an appropriate time to decide whether indeed the mechanism of a royal commission was required rather than continuing with the type of inquiry which is based on legislation fostered by and passed by this Parliament in setting up the National Crime Authority.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories aware of statements made by Dr Alan Moran, an executive of the Industry Commission, at a seminar on sustainable development yesterday in Melbourne? Are Dr Moran's opinions on sustainable development, ocean dumping of waste and land degradation representative of the Government's policies on these matters.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of the article, as is the Minister, Mrs Kelly. Dr Moran's cavalier, cowboy attitude does not reflect the attitude of the Government on this question. I was disappointed to read the views that Dr Moran put yesterday, but honourable senators would be aware that Dr David Smiles from the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation put a very different view to the same seminar at which Dr Moran spoke. I think it is worth noting that Dr Moran's expertise lies in the field of economics. In his haste to dispose of waste in what he describes as `the cheapest way', by dumping it in oceans, I think he is disposing of some of his economic knowledge as well. In fact, he seems to have exhibited a complete lack of understanding of the issues he raised. As I understand it, for the last few years Dr Moran has been the head of the Government's Business Regulation Review Unit.
—He has done a good job, too.
—He may well have done a good job, but that does not qualify him as an expert on the ecological implications of ocean dumping-far from it.
—He is not as good as you are!

—I have never classed myself as an expert, but I, like the rest of the world, know a lot more about it than Senator MacGibbon does. Dr Moran appears to be completely ignorant of what is meant by the term `sustainable development'. That is perhaps the most regrettable part of his statements yesterday, because sustainable development will be one of the key issues facing this country over the next few years. He has failed to come to grips with the fact that economic development over time will continue only if it is ecologically sustainable. That is a sad reflection of Dr Moran's views.

ANSWER.PARA: Sustainable development is about the integration of economic and ecological values so that we can ensure that future generations can do as well, or better than, we are doing. I doubt very much that, in seeking to dump all sorts of pollutants into our oceans, Dr Moran is taking great account of the future of those who may well have to seek sustenance from those oceans. The Prime Minister stated in a publication entitled, Our Country, Our Future something that is worth repeating today. He said:

There is increasing evidence that human activity is degrading the oceans through exploitation of marine resources and pollution by organochlorines, heavy metals and plastics. The Government recognises that no country acting alone can protect or manage the oceans. The Government will therefore be using every opportunity available at international forums to pursue effective international measures aimed at the protection of our oceans.
The Government's commitment remains that and we regret Dr Moran's statements. They do not in any way represent the views of the Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs to his answer to a question yesterday from Senator Hill in which the Minister referred to the powers of the Australian Capital Territory Coroner and the Director of Public Prosecutions to prevent self-incriminatory evidence being given in subsequent criminal proceedings. I ask the Minister: In view of the fact that the prosecutions arising out of Operation Seville failed because the principal witness refused to testify, despite the fact that he had been granted immunity from prosecution by both the New South Wales and Commonwealth Attorneys-General, does the Minister still maintain that the coroner's inquiry into the death of Mr Winchester will be able to obtain all the evidence which would be obtained by a royal commission?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is clear that the coroner's inquest is designed to look into those matters relating to the manner and cause of the death of Colin Winchester. The question of how evidence might be obtained, including by way of giving an assurance of indemnity or a section 57 certificate in relation to self-incriminating answers, is a matter for the coroner in any particular instance. But I remind the Senate in relation to the inquest that, if at any time the coroner considers that a prima facie case is revealed about the commission of an indictable offence, he can charge the person and, after a certain preliminary procedure, commit that person to trial. It does not have to be an indictment in relation to the death under investigation.

ANSWER.PARA: It is for that reason, amongst others, that I have been cautious about the idea of having a royal commission running at the same time as a coroner's inquest. I believe it is important that the coroner's inquest continue, particularly as the coroner has indicated that he will look at Operation Seville matters in the next round, and that the inquest be allowed to run, given all of those powers, particularly the coroner's ability to commit a person to trial, that could come out of his investigation into the manner and cause of Colin Winchester's death. I acknowledge that the coroner's terms of reference are different from those that would be the case in a royal commission, but the question of whether a royal commission may be required is something that can best be ascertained at the end of the coronial inquest.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade whether he is aware of reports of a recent bomb attack in Chile. Were any Australian citizens injured in the bomb attack, which took place at a building housing the Australian firm of TNT International Transportation Co. in Chile? Have any steps been taken to protect other employees of Australian firms operating in Chile? If so, what safeguards have been put in place to protect Australians working in Chile?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware that bomb attacks took place in the Chilean capital of Santiago on 14 May at various locations, including the United States consulate, a Jewish community centre, a Mormon church, an army parking lot, and offices of two foreign owned firms, one of them being the Australian company TNT International Transportation, as Senator Jones said. One person, a Chilean security guard at the United States consulate, was slightly injured during the attack. Although there were no Australian citizens involved in the attack, the Australian Government is concerned about the safety of Australian citizens and businesses in Chile. Our embassy in Santiago is working closely with them and the Chilean authorities to ensure their security.

ANSWER.PARA: At this stage no-one has claimed responsibility for the attacks, although some suggest that the left wing Manuel Rodriguez Patriotic Front, FMR, was responsible. The Front is known to have provoked a series of incidents over recent months, apparently with the objective of destabilising the new Aylwin Government in Chile. Extreme right wing organisations in Chile have also been engaging in terrorist activities. I know that the Aylwin Government is extremely concerned about this continuing violence and is making concerted efforts through policing and through political dialogue to bring it to an end. These efforts include cutting off the sources of weapons and funds for terrorist groups. I also know that many of the international firms operating in Santiago, including TNT, have made private security arrangements to supplement these efforts.

Needless to say, Australia views with concern such use of violence, especially the attempts to destabilise a democratically elected government which is publicly committed, unlike its predecessor, to the preservation of human rights. We do support very strongly the efforts of the Chilean Government in bringing the violence to an end and thus ensuring, amongst other things, the confidence of Australian investors and businessmen in Chile.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce and relates to the remarks attributed to Dr Moran. Does the Minister recall an Australian Democrats amendment, accepted by the Government, to the Industry Commission Bill which required the Commission to take the environment into account in relation to every recommendation and to have at least one commissioner experienced and knowledgeable in environmental matters? Is he aware that Dr Moran is reported as representing a `first assistant commissioner to the Industry Commission' when he made his remarks to the Sydney Institute and in another place as a `senior Federal Government official'? Was Dr Moran therefore speaking in his official capacity? I ask the Minister whether he agrees with Dr Moran's assertions, firstly:

QUESTION.PARA: Concerns about Australia's soil degradation problem were completely unfounded.
The world's oceans were too vast to be spoiled by pollution.
Preservation of endangered animals was best left to private ownership rather than to government.

Finally, if the Minister does not agree, does he not agree that inadequate criteria have been set to select assistant commissioners-particularly in view of those amendments which are in the Act-to carry out the important tasks of the Industry Commission, and that Dr Moran is an unsuitable person for that job?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have no idea whether Dr Moran was speaking in an official capacity or not. To my mind it does not matter terribly in the context of a seminar of this kind because I always took the view when Dr Moran was head of the Business Regulation Review Unit, for example, that he should publish such reports as he wished, although I did not necessarily agree with them on many occasions. If that is an important part of the honourable senator's question, I will try to find out further details for him.

ANSWER.PARA: The substance of this question has already been responded to by Senator Richardson and I have little to add to what Senator Richardson said. He made the point that Dr David Smiles of the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation Soils Division was also a contributor to the seminar. One could ask whether Dr Smiles also was contributing in an official capacity. The important point in Senator Coulter's question which was not answered by Senator Richardson relates to the adequacy of criteria for selecting Industry Commission commissioners. In that sense I point out that Dr Moran does not speak for the Industry Commission, as an institution, on environmental matters. He is head of the Business Regulation Review Unit, which now falls within the Industry Commission.

Senator Coulter may not be aware that last Friday the Treasurer announced new appointments of commissioners to the Industry Commission, including that of Dr Tor Hundloe. He is currently Director of the Institute of Applied Environmental Research at Griffith University. He has written extensively on environmental impact assessments, the economic and social impact of development and cost-benefit analysis. He has also undertaken consultancies for State and Commonwealth governments and the United Nations.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Social Security to the home equity conversion scheme initiative which was announced by the Treasurer, Mr Keating, in the August 1989 Budget. Will the Minister give details of the implementation of the home equity conversion scheme, which States in the Commonwealth have a scheme operating and how many retired persons are now enjoying the benefits of the scheme? Can the Minister confirm whether the Commonwealth Bank is participating in offering a home equity conversion scheme?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator Colston would be aware, home equity conversion schemes are financial products offered by the private sector and, therefore, are not offered by the Government. Those schemes permit older people to borrow against the value of their homes, to receive that money either as a lump sum or in payments over time and, as it were, to repay that amount upon their death or upon permanent departure from the home. For that reason the scheme has had quite some acceptance. The Commonwealth does not operate a scheme. However, because it recognises the interests of many pensioners in these schemes, it has provided the opportunity to make use of them.

ANSWER.PARA: In the 1989 Budget, we announced that from 1 November 1989 the first $40,000 received under one of these schemes would be exempted from our income tests on the pension. The income test free limit was established to prevent the loans becoming a way of avoiding the income test and the assets test, but we still have to allow pensioners to borrow enough money to cover their major expenses. We have continually stressed to pensioners that they ought to be careful about these schemes and the operation of them. We have made sure that our own financial information service provides information to pensioners about those schemes. The implementation of the changed income test treatment of these schemes has proceeded very smoothly but we have no figures available for the number of pensioners using the schemes because we are not administering them. So I cannot help Senator Colston with that, although I will attempt to find out more information. As I understand it the Commonwealth Bank does not operate one of these schemes, but commercial schemes are available in three states: New South Wales, Victoria and South Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Small Business and Communications. Is Senator Button aware of the published forecasts that business liquidations and receiverships will reach 10,000 this financial year-or more than double the 4,836 of two years ago and 60 per cent more than the 6,189 of last year? Why have business bankruptcies in Australia increased by 27 per cent to 2,142 in the March quarter, according to statistics recently released by the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs, Senator Tate? Why have bankruptcies in States with Labor governments increased far more than in the coalition-governed New South Wales, which reported a rise of only 13 per cent while Western Australia's bankruptcies increased by 74 per cent, Tasmania's by 54 per cent, Queensland's by 35 per cent and Victoria's by 33 per cent? Is it because of the large number of government backed ventures going broke in these Labor States, taking multi-millions of taxpayers' dollars with them?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —First of all, I will respond to the last part of the question. If there were any truth in that, it might be true in respect of Western Australia and it might be true in respect of Victoria but it certainly would not be true in respect of South Australia. So I do not think the honourable senator can derive any comforting argument from the last part of his question.
—Except that South Australia is the least worst of them all.

—Senator Baume and Senator Boswell can have a discussion about this after Question Time. I do not propose to enter into it now. Senator Boswell suggested in his question that there have been a high number of liquidations and bankruptcies. I have no doubt that there are a variety of reasons for that. The first is that interest rates have been high for some time. That is a factor which undoubtedly has some impact on the performance of, particularly, small businesses. There are other factors which I would broadly describe as cultural. In the period of very high demand, as there was throughout 1986 and 1987, a lot of people went into business who probably should not have done so.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —All those who interject ought to know, because most of them are drop-outs from small business themselves, that for many years every published report about small business in Australia, irrespective of the government of the day, either Federal or State, has identified an enormously high level of small business failure in Australia, much of which is due to poorly trained management, inadequate financial advice and so on.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not know why Opposition senators are interjecting. This is why half of them are there. They have been through all that and they ought to know that that is right. Look at Senator Baume who was interjecting a moment ago. He will interject about Patrick Partners in a minute, I suppose. I want to make the point--
—Tired, tired! Go to London.

—Senator Hill says `tired'. I am not tired at all; I am bored out of my brain by this Opposition and the silly questions to which members of the Opposition ought to know the answers. Senator Boswell can recycle his question in any year he likes and he will get a different result State by State. There is no doubt about that. I share with him concern about a higher level of business liquidations and bankruptcies. But apart from that, I really have nothing to add to what I have already said:

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Senator Button has enunciated his reasons why small businesses are going broke. Could he tell us: What policy can the Government offer to small businesses in their hour of need that will help them get out of the trouble that the figures indicate they are in?
—What sort of assistance was offered under your scheme?
—Oh, shut up, you clown.
—Order! I take it that last interjection was not part of the supplementary question.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, it might not have been part of the supplementary question but it might have been an alternative policy offering from the Opposition. There are two things which are particularly difficult for smaller businesses at the present time and that is the reduced demand in the Australian economy, the very substantial--
—What about the effect of capital gains tax?

—Oh, Senator-stop going on about capital gains tax. Senator Walters could have asked that question two years ago when small business was doing better than it had ever done in the history of this country.
—This is a tired old government.

—Mr President, people talk about tired governments. For God's sake, listen to that sort of interjection. What a tired old interjection that is. Two years ago Senator Walters could have made the same interjection and it would have been equally silly as it is now. Capital gains tax has nothing to do with the major problems.

ANSWER.PARA: Before Senator Boswell's vociferous friends got into the act with tired interjections I was just about to say that there are two issues-fall in demand and high interest rates-which have had a particularly significant burden on small businesses. In respect of both those matters I have said on numerous occasions in this place, and every Government spokesman has said, that it has been important that we reduce demand in the Australian economy, and monetary policy has been part of that process. In the last month or two we have seen some relaxation of monetary policy, not all of which has been reflected in interest rates charged by the banks, but there has been some reflection-

TALK.START.PARA: —Kick the banks.
—The honourable senator should have a look at Mr Nobby Clark's speech the other day. Have a look at what he had to say about it.
—He spoke of a recession.

—Have a look at what he said. He did not just say that the tight monetary policy was responsible for their problems. He also admitted that their conduct was responsible for some of their problems. I will quote my erstwhile ministerial colleague Senator Walsh. I think he made a very important speech prior to the election. He said that, if the Australian banks had been as diligent in their lending practices as Tiny Rowland was when the Bond Corporation sought to buy and did buy a shareholding in his company, we would not have had half the problems we have today. I agree with that.

—Has the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade seen press reports that a ceasefire in Cambodia has been agreed or is close to agreement by the Cambodian parties? What is the current position on a ceasefire? What can Australia do to assist further the peace process in Cambodia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are a number of press reports this morning suggesting that a ceasefire proposal sponsored by Thailand is close to agreement between the four Cambodian parties and may be unveiled at the meeting of Cambodian leaders which is proposed to be held in Tokyo on 4 to 6 June. Those reports are based in turn on an article which appeared yesterday in the Bangkok Post. At this stage we do not have a great deal more detail about the Thai proposal than appears in that article.

ANSWER.PARA: The Bangkok Post article does, however, spend some time linking and comparing the Thai proposal with a separate one that has been advanced in recent weeks by Australia. I can say a little about that, although in the present highly fluid situation it would not be appropriate to say very much on the public record at this stage. The situation is fluid with major discussions pending among the Permanent Five members of the Security Council of the United Nations in New York later this week and in the run up to the Tokyo meeting in early June, to which I have referred.

The Australian proposal evolved in the course of a recent extensive visit to the region in late April and early May by the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade Deputy Secretary, Michael Costello, in which he was asked by me to explore the prospects for a confidence building strategy which would hopefully give something of a kick-start to full scale negotiations.

The Australian proposal involves in essence an agreed military standstill under the good offices of the United Nations with accompanying verification of the withdrawal of Vietnamese forces from the country. It has a specified time limit and is expressly designed to lead to the negotiation of a full-scale comprehensive settlement. As I said, it would not be appropriate for me to go into any further detail or to describe reactions to that proposal except to say that the reaction generally has been encouraging. I think it would be appropriate, however, and helpful for me to add just a few words in conclusion on the underlying rationale for any military standstill, whether it be one crafted by Australia, by Thailand or by anyone else.

I have always taken the view that a cessation of hostilities could contribute very much to the objective of a comprehensive settlement, an objective which, of course, we share with other governments closely concerned with the Cambodia problem. In a statement to the United Nations General Assembly last October our Permanent Representative, Dr Wilenski, said:

Indeed, my delegation believes that the international community should be quite unequivocal in supporting any measure that would reduce the misery being inflicted on the Cambodian people. Thus not only must we do all we can to prevent an escalation in the fighting, we must also do all we can to promote a ceasefire while the search for a comprehensive solution goes on.

After more than a decade of hostilities, Mr President, the lack of trust and the suspicion among the Cambodian parties are very deep. An agreement to stop the fighting, even an agreement of limited duration, would be a compelling contribution to the building of confidence among the parties and, if that agreement were carefully formulated, it could unquestionably enhance the prospects of concluding a comprehensive settlement.

But, one last word: while a military standstill will be enormously important, it is crucial that it not be seen as an end in itself. Recent history in Lebanon I think demonstrates clearly the fragility of ceasefires which are not themselves an integral part of a long-term settlement. To be durable, any ceasefire or military standstill must form part of the overall settlement process and be directly linked to a comprehensive settlement. It is to the achievement of a comprehensive settlement that Australia's efforts will continue to be overwhelmingly directed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, my question is to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Communications. I ask: What assurances of support or understandings were given or conveyed by the Prime Minister or any other senior Ministers to the principals of the commercial television networks implying that there will be no significant reductions in the current limits on foreign equity in their ownership? Has Mr Kerry Packer, who was so enriched by the Government's last round of changes to television ownership rules, been lobbying Government Ministers to reduce foreign equity levels to around 20 per cent, and has Mr Peter Barron, a former senior prime ministerial adviser, been in direct contact with the Prime Minister, Senator Richardson and other senior Ministers in this regard? What were the nature of recent discussions between Mr Sam Chisholm and the Acting Prime Minister on this question? Did they relate to assurances or understandings conveyed by the Prime Minister or his colleagues prior to the election? Finally, will the Cabinet be announcing a decision on this matter this week, or has it been laid prostrate in its final decision making by direct order of the Prime Minister?

—In relation to the first part of the question, the answer is, `None that I am aware of'. In relation to the rest of the question, nobody has been lobbying me but I would hardly expect that as it is not my principal area of responsibility within the portfolio. I am happy to refer the other aspects of Senator Puplick's question to the Minister principally responsible, Mr Beazley. In answer to the last part of the Senator's question, the Government is in fact actively addressing this issue at the moment, and will make a decision on it in the near future.

—I have a supplementary question, Mr President. Senator Collins says that he is himself unaware of any assurances of support or understanding given by the Prime Minister or other senior Ministers. I therefore ask: In the answer which he is going to provide, will he reply to the Senate as to whether in fact any such assurances or understandings were given? Can he also refer those parts of the question to Ministers other than Mr Beazley which relate to the lobbying activities of Mr Barron, and refer to Mr Keating the questions related to Mr Chisholm and his activities? Can Senator Collins assure the Senate that he will personally take responsibility to ensure that these questions are answered as expeditiously as possible?

—As far as I am aware, I have so far given three undertakings during Question Time that I will reply promptly and fully to questions that I have been given. I have so far discharged every one of those obligations and, in respect of the last one which was on the substantive issue of why the ITA magazine was withdrawn by Australian Airlines Ltd from its Flight Deck lounges, I replied, as I promised I would, to Senator Bishop on the same day that I received the question. I will discharge my obligations in respect of Senator Puplick's question in the same assiduous manner.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. Given the importance of issues concerning women for economic development and recovery in all countries, for example, employment, development, health and population, can the Minister inform the Senate of what representation of women the Government has on any international delegations and negotiating teams?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I fully recognise the importance to women of many of the issues currently on the international agenda. Certainly, I am fully committed to proper representation of women in official Australian delegations to international meetings. However, I am afraid that I am not able to provide detailed statistics on the number of women included in or associated with all official international delegations and negotiating teams. Such a register would change very rapidly and would, of course, need to cover a number of different portfolios apart from my own.

ANSWER.PARA: Within my own portfolio, female departmental officers are involved in a number of international negotiations. Three of the officers dealing with international negotiations in our mission to the United Nations (UN) in New York are women. There are two women in our General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade delegation in Geneva, one in our Geneva disarmament delegation and one in our mission in Vienna dealing with international negotiations. These are all responsible positions dealing with substantive policy work of importance to the Government and the country. As Senator Crowley would be well aware, it is also the case that women members of parliament have participated in Australian delegations to the UN General Assembly.

Women officers have been among those who have worked in Australia and at overseas posts on the many high profile international initiatives in which we have been engaged in recent times. These include Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation, southern Africa, chemical weapons, Cambodia, and Antarctica. There are several women officials involved with the Uruguay Round and Multilateral Trade Negotiations. There are a number of women legal officers who work on important treaty and other international negotiations, such as the Timor Gap Agreement.

There are a number of women officers dealing within national organisations including, naturally enough, the Commission on the Status of Women. The Australian delegation to the annual session of the Commission of the Status of Women regularly includes women officers of my Department as well as from the Office of the Status of Women. I am not suggesting that the extent of involvement by female officers is perfect in terms of our equal opportunity program objectives. I think that all our departments have a long way to go before those objectives are fully implemented. But as far as representation of women from my Department is concerned, taking a longer term perspective, I am certainly encouraged by the pattern of recruitment. Men and women are now being recruited in approximately even numbers, which over time should lead to an even more balanced representation than occurs at the moment.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security. Did the Minister tell Laurie Oakes on the Sunday program that social security spending constitutes about one quarter of gross domestic product (GDP)? Did the Minister mean to refer to Budget outlays, and does he acknowledge that there is only about a $40 billion difference?
—It is a bit more than that.

—I will let Senator Richardson clear that up in due course. Did the Minister tell the Senate last Friday that, under the Government's new approach to unemployment benefits, there will not be unemployment benefits as such; there will be those on Newstart and there will be another benefit for the very young. In view of the fact that the Treasurer's February statement made it clear that the length of unemployment rather than age will be the critical determinant, would the Minister explain whether Friday's answer was meant to herald a fundamental change in policy or once again did he simply get it wrong?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —My answer is no on both counts. In the case of the Sunday program, I confess to a terrible slip of the tongue for which, no doubt, I must be whipped by a feather. I greatly regret this. I did say `GDP'. It should have been `Budget outlays'. That is a real worry, but a slip of the tongue I can live with. In terms of Newstart--
—Ask `aNiMaLS' about that.

—I think it is a question of quantifying the gaffe. In the 1987 election, Senator Baume did us enormous good. Given his triumphant return to the front bench, the one thing we do not want to do is silence him. The more Senator Baume talks, the more we love it. He should keep it up. As I said the other day, Newstart is a program designed to help the long term unemployed and get them back to work. Encouraging them to get back into employment is something that the Government has been working on for quite some years. We shall continue to do so.

ANSWER.PARA: As far as our Jobsearch allowance is concerned, we will continue to make sure that those who have been out of work for less than 12 months get an opportunity to receive some training and get back to work as well. So we have two programs working. Most of the Jobsearch recipients, if one looks at the figures in the first instance, will probably be somewhat younger, obviously, as it is much harder for those in the older age brackets to get work. If one looks at the profiles of those who are long term unemployed, who have been on benefits for more than 12 months and, in some cases, more than five years, one finds very often that these are older workers because they are the ones that are harder to place.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I have a supplementary question. I am not quite clear on the extent of the concession the Minister is making. Is it a fact that the Minister did not mention the Jobsearch allowance on Friday? Is it also correct that the Minister said this, in explaining the concept: `I should point out that at the moment we have got three benefits-one for the young, one for the youngish, and then an unemployment benefit generally. Now, as of next year, there will only be two. There will not be unemployment benefits as such. There will be those on Newstart and there will be another benefit for the very young'? Does the Minister concede that that dichotomy is wrong and that the game is all about short term and long term unemployed and not about the age of the recipient?

—I have just said that it is about short term and long term unemployed, and I have explained that if one looks at the profile of long term unemployed they tend to be older; if one looks at the profile of the others then there is much more of a chance that they are going to be younger. I said it once; I have now said it twice. I will say it three times if it helps. If Senator Alston wants to look at the long term unemployed and their profiles, quite obviously they are those in the older age bracket. It is much harder to get back to work when one is in one's fifties than it is when one is in one's twenties; that is not going to change.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health and relates to the Government's treatment of the psychiatrically disabled under the provisions of the Disability Services Act. I remind the Minister of the statement made by Senator Grimes, the responsible Minister at the time of passage of that Act, that-and I quote from Hansard of 20 November 1986-`the world will not change' and `the way I administer the legislation, in fact, it will not cost anything at all'. This statement was made during debate on the successful Australian Democrats amendment which included, as a target group, the psychiatrically disabled. What is the Government's current policy on funding of services targeted for people with psychiatric disability?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Powell was kind enough to give a little preliminary notice of this question, and I have received an answer from the Minister. There is no question that people with psychiatric disabilities are eligible for services under the Disability Services Act. At the present time, policy is that new services primarily targeted for people with psychiatric disabilities will receive a lower priority for funding under the disability services program. However, they are not excluded from services, and some are already receiving services.

ANSWER.PARA: There is considerable potential for overlap between responsibilities of State and Commonwealth governments in this area, as provision of services for people with psychiatric disability has traditionally been the responsibility of State governments. With the aim of delineating respective responsibilities, the disability services program has commenced bilateral discussions with State and Territory governments.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: SECRETARY TO DEPARTMENT OF IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate, representing the Prime Minister. As the Prime Minister has recently defended the Government's record in relation to the recently introduced Migration Regulations, despite widespread community concern about them, can the Minister explain exactly the nature and cause of the Prime Minister's personal intervention to secure the removal of the Secretary to the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs and his replacement by a former member of the Prime Minister's personal staff?
—I have no information about that matter. I will endeavour to obtain an answer as soon as I can.

—Has the Minister for Industrial Relations seen the report in today's Australian quoting a spokesman for Mr Barry Coulter, the Deputy Chief Minister in the Northern Territory and the person in the Territory Administration responsible for the trade development zone, which attempts to blame the Department of Industrial Relations for award breaches by the Hengyang company? Is this true?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen the comments attributed to a spokesman for Mr Coulter. I have also seen comments in the Sunday Territorian of 20 May directly attributed-at least, in quotation marks-to Mr Coulter himself on the same subject. In the Sunday Territorian Mr Coulter said that the Hengyang company had agreed to meet its responsibilities to its employees three months ago, and that it had been standing ready to do so for the past month.

ANSWER.PARA: If that comment were true there would be no need for the Department of Industrial Relations to have conducted an exhaustive investigation of the under- payment of wages. It would simply have been the case that the company would have paid the right rate and it would not have been necessary for us to discover that the total amount of underpayments came to $574,000. There is no responsibility on the Department of Industrial Relations to ensure the right rate of pay is paid. There is every responsibility on employers to pay their employees the award rate, and if they do not do that they are open to prosecution and should be so prosecuted. Whatever Mr Coulter wants to say about the Department, the obligation rests firmly with the company.

I turn to the Australian newspaper article referred to in the question to me today. Mr Coulter's spokesman said, according to that article, that it is the responsibility of the Government to monitor the situation there. I inform the Senate that in November last year a representative of my Department went to the trade development zone management and reported his belief that the award was not being properly observed by this company. That representative was told by the trade development zone management, which is directly responsible to Mr Coulter, that that was not so, that the award was being observed and that all the conditions were proper.

At that point, innocently and naively as it turns out, we terminated our inquiry. It was not until February of this year when the Clothing and Allied Trades Union made a formal complaint that we went and investigated the company and found massive underpayment. The point is that Mr Coulter's authority-the trade development zone-turned away our initial inquiry. If there is a degree of ministerial responsibility here it rests firmly with Mr Coulter in ensuring that his trade development zone, when it receives inquiries from a body such as the Department of Industrial Relations, properly investigates those inquiries. If it had done so it would have found the massive underpayment we later found in February.

I reject the allegations of Mr Coulter. I say, once again, that if the Northern Territory wishes to continue the support of the trade development zone-a concept, in itself, that is an admirable one-it should root out of it the offences of this nature that are occurring and allow genuine business to get on with promoting trade in a proper way.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Communications. I preface my question by suggesting that the Minister would especially appreciate the importance of local content in rural and regional news broadcasts. Therefore, given the oft quoted commitment by this Government and, more particularly, the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC) to the provision and expansion of services to rural and regional Australia, can the Minister explain why in Tamworth, New South Wales, in other areas such as Tasmania, and in some places in all the other States of Australia, services to rural listeners have been cut? In our particular case in Tamworth, the popular local rural news broadcaster lost his job, and that means there is a loss of local content. The Minister should not grimace and put on a face about this. Given that the ABC's Chairman, David Hill, told the Senate last year that funding was proceeding to provide two ABC signals to country listeners, are not the reductions in regional staff defeating the ABC's stated objectives to upgrade and improve country services?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was not making a face; in fact I have to confess I was dropping off to sleep. The ABC has been carrying out a full review of its services around Australia for some time in order to provide the most efficient service possible to all Australians. That has involved, I freely concede, some readjustment of staffing allocations in various centres around Australia-including, I might say, my own home base in Darwin, and Alice Springs-and that has led to criticisms such as that made by Senator Brownhill.

ANSWER.PARA: I think the ABC has carried out this readjustment in an extremely responsible manner. By and large there has been a distinct improvement in the quality of the broadcasts that have emanated. I am not personally aware of the difficulty attached to the announcer at Tamworth. That has not been brought to my attention, but I am happy to refer the question to the Minister for Transport and Communications, Mr Beazley. I will endeavour to get an answer to the honourable senator no later than this week.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct a question to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade and take this opportunity to thank him for the message he sent to the Chernobyl telethon, which I attended in Moscow recently. Is the Minister aware of the extent of ongoing medical care and research needed following the Chernobyl nuclear power station disaster in 1986? What form of medical expertise can Australia provide to the Soviet Union, particularly in relation to the many thousands of child victims who American doctors have estimated may not live beyond 15 years of age?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —That was a very gentle question, but I can assure the Senate that it was all Senator Reynolds's own work; it was not a dorothy dixer. On 26 April, the fourth anniversary of the Chernobyl nuclear accident, I sent a message to a television marathon organised in the Soviet Union to help the victims of Chernobyl, noting that Australia shared fully the international concern for the victims of this very tragic accident. Australia firmly believes that the suffering and the loss caused by the accident should not be in vain and that there are lessons which must be learnt from it.

ANSWER.PARA: In this context, we have cooperated with the Soviet Union in efforts to prevent such catastrophes in the future or to minimise their effects. We have joined with it in acceding to two international conventions designed to facilitate assistance and early warning in the case of a nuclear accident. We also continue to support fully the work of the International Atomic Energy Agency in the field of nuclear safety.

The Soviet authorities now state that the scale of the disaster caused by Chernobyl was much greater than was originally claimed, particularly in terms of the long term damage inflicted on the health of many of the inhabitants and on the environment in areas of the Ukraine and Byelorussia, neighbouring Chernobyl. The Ukrainian and Byelorussian governments, as well as Soviet representatives abroad, have appealed to the international community, including multilateral agencies such as the World Health Organisation and the United Nations Environment Program, UNEP, for assistance in dealing with the consequences of Chernobyl.

The Australian Government supports the effort of UN agencies to provide a constructive and coordinated approach to this question. The UN Economic and Social Council is considering the issue of international cooperation to deal with the consequences of Chernobyl at its current session, and these discussions should provide a helpful framework for handling this issue in the UN system.

As to the last part of the question, the Australian Government has not received any request for specific medical expertise from the Soviet Union. Therefore, it is difficult to get a precise indication of what relevant Australian expertise the Soviets might seek to draw on. A practical consideration of how this might be approached would obviously depend on the nature of any requests that might be made by the Soviet or international agencies.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Northern Australia. I draw the Minister's attention to the decision yesterday of the Queensland Government to abolish the Cape York-north Queensland enterprise zone at a time when it was finalising three significant projects. In view of the Minister's public support for regional development, can he give any indication that the Federal Government will offer particular assistance to growth in north Queensland, where the State Government has failed to do so? Will the Minister countenance the creation of a joint Federal and State trade development zone (TDZ) to prevent the further economic deterioration of an area already in recession and additionally suffering from the downturn in the tourist industry?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Of course the Government supports the development of northern Australia but, unfortunately, from my experience it has been the tendency of State and Territory governments for a very long time to consistently blame the Federal Government for all the alleged shortcomings of northern development and then to attempt to take the credit for anything that does fortuitously happen to go right in northern Australia which in most cases, at least in my own patch, has been entirely financed by Federal Government money. That is hardly surprising.

ANSWER.PARA: The reason I have provided that background to Senator O'Chee's question is that the question of setting up trade development zones, which is what Senator O'Chee is talking about, is absolutely and unarguably the province in the first instance of a State government. Very little case could be made for the Federal Government taking on the obligation and responsibility for setting up such a proposal. There are considerable shortcomings and dangers inherent in such proposals, exciting and innovative as they are.

No doubt Senator O'Chee has been paying some attention to a number of questions that have been asked in the Senate in respect of the TDZ that is currently operating-it is the only one operating-in Darwin. I was extremely interested to see the advertisements that were placed by the Queensland Government announcing its original intention to locate TDZs at both Cairns and Townsville. I was aware from its advertisements that the Government was intending to base its proposals very substantially on the same basis as that which was run by the Northern Territory Government at the TDZ in Darwin.

There is no doubt that in respect of the existing problems at the TDZ-they are significant problems, I regret to say-and as a resident of northern Australia I profoundly regret the appalling mismanagement of the Northern Territory Government in respect of this TDZ, and I do not say this to make any political points--
Opposition senators-No!

TALK.START.PARA: —In fact, I do not. If honourable senators would bear with me for one minute, I will give the reason why. I am sure that Senator O'Chee would agree with this. By the very nature of the communities that we are talking about-isolated communities in northern Australia-it is always a high risk proposition to try to establish what the TDZs are principally aimed at, that is, providing a manufacturing sector for northern Australia, which it currently substantially lacks. Northern Australia has significant resources in terms of mineral wealth and tourist potential but profoundly lacks any major manufacturing infrastructure. One of the reasons for that, as Senator O'Chee knows, is the cost of establishing that infrastructure and particularly energy costs, which predicate against it. The entire point of establishing trade development zones is to give a government supported edge to enable what are essentially high risk enterprises to get off the ground.

ANSWER.PARA: It is a substantial matter of regret to me, not just as the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Northern Australia but as a Territorian, that in what is known to be a high risk area the profound mismanagement that has occurred in TDZs creates a dreadful atmosphere of indecision and lack of confidence in terms of potential investors. That is precisely what has happened in respect of the TDZ in Darwin. I regret to say that there has to be some question mark placed on whether the 15 companies that were about to establish in the zone will proceed.

I can assure Senator O'Chee that I am very alive to the developments that have happened in Queensland because I have been watching them with some interest. Despite the fact that it is clearly a State responsibility, I am extremely keen to take up with Mr Goss-I will be meeting him to discuss this subject this week in Canberra-the reasons why the Queensland Government took the decision that it did. But I must say that it is probably not entirely unrelated to developments, regrettably, in Darwin.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a supplementary question, Mr President. I am very grateful to Senator Collins for his comments. Would he also have particular consideration for the people of Ravenshoe as well, who have suffered as a result of the downturn in the logging industry whereas the Prime Minister had previously given an undertaking that those people would not suffer at all?

—Because of the interest that Senator O'Chee has expressed in this matter, after my discussions with the Queensland Premier this week I will contact Senator O'Chee and I would be more than happy to discuss with him in detail the reasons the Queensland Government has taken the decision that it has and any ideas he might have in order to promote such an industry in north Queensland at some future date.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you seek leave to continue or are you going to speak to it now?
—Yes, I seek leave to continue my remarks.

—I am afraid that the message I am getting from a number of senators is that you would not then have got leave. You can move to take note of the answer, which you did. You then sought leave to continue your remarks, which you were given. That adjourns the debate. Senator Coulter, did you wish to speak?
—I wish to speak now, that is correct.
