SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Then, Mr President, pursuant to contingent notice and on behalf of Senator Macklin, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That so much of Standing Orders be suspended as would prevent me moving a motion to provide for the consideration of a matter, namely, a motion to take note of the answer provided by Minister Button.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you going to speak to it or will I put the question?

—Mr President, the reason that I seek the suspension of Standing Orders is that in this matter we are dealing with the creation of a new Industry Commission to which, according to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, Senator Button, the commissioners are currently being appointed. The particular matters which the Commission will consider are also now under consideration and, in view of the state of the development of this new Commission, which replaces the Industries Assistance Commission, it is appropriate and urgent that the contents of Dr Moran's comments and Minister Button's response to those comments be debated at this time.

SPEECH.PARA: Because of Dr Moran's comments it is not a matter which can be left to a later date because that would clearly lock the Commission into a situation which I believe it is possible to show will not be in conformity with provisions in the Industry Commission Act, the Act creating the Industry Commission, which were included as amendments by the Australian Democrats and which were approved by the Government.

Those amendments go to the heart of some contents of the considerations of the Commission, namely, that the Commission must take into account environmental matters and that the Commission must contain a person who has experience and knowledge in the environmental area. Without debating Dr Moran's particular comments, it would seem to me self- evident from any cursory examination of those comments that he has shown himself to be a person incapable of fulfilling that task. In view of the incipient nature of the Industry Commission, it is therefore appropriate that Standing Orders be suspended now so that this matter can be debated and the membership of that Commission by Dr Moran can be settled at this time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not necessarily quoting the editorial in yesterday's Australian on this matter, I just briefly add to the sense of urgency which the Australian Democrats feel by simply saying that it is a fact that this week the Treasurer (Mr Keating) has referred as a matter of urgency to the Industry Commission some very important inquiries as part of the Government's micro-economic reform. These inquiries will be taking place during the recess of this Parliament. We are very concerned about the position of Dr Moran on the Industry Commission, in that we believe this is in conflict with amendments which were made to the legislation setting up the Industry Commission, and particularly because of these inquiries which are under way. I remind the Senate that these are inquiries into micro-economic reform in the areas of electricity, railways and rural marketing.

SPEECH.PARA: The area of our concern relates to the ability of the Commission to take into account the very important environmental, social and economic effects on particular areas of the economy in its reform. We are concerned because of the reported comments of Dr Moran who believes there is no such thing as land degradation, that indeed the oceans can soak up as much pollution as we want them to, and probably does not believe in such a thing as global warming. Yet he is on a commission which is currently to undertake with all speed a review of the generation of electricity, and a review of railways and rural marketing in this country. We believe that this is a matter of urgency for the Senate here today because the Commission is so important and because those inquiries were recently and urgently given to the Commission and speeded up on the advice of the Treasurer.

We have obviously taken note of the question, as have others, from the Government member earlier in Question Time. We are concerned about the influences that exist on the Commission. We note that Dr Tor Hundloe has been appointed, among others, and that is a matter that we are pleased about. But we are concerned about Dr Moran and his reported statements. We believe that this issue is worth the time of the Parliament, as these inquiries will be taking place in the first instance while this Parliament is not sitting and therefore it would not be able to be debated.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, not only does Senator Coulter not know the procedures here; does he not know that the leadership ballot is over for the Australian Democrats? There is no need to be hairy chested here today; they are already counting. That is what probably prompted Senator Powell into the field.

SPEECH.PARA: The point about debating questions after Question Time is that it is very much a reserve weapon, to be used fairly sparingly; otherwise a precedent will be set and every question will be noted and debated afterwards and this chamber will become a farce. There is ample opportunity to raise these issues. As that particular person will not be sitting on an inquiry before 10.30 tonight, there is ample opportunity for the honourable senator to raise the issue on the adjournment or on matters of special interest or public interest on Thursday. If we were to set a precedent, as a government, to always agree to have a little speech after Question Time on a whole range of questions, we could see where the precedent would take us.

The Democrats' job today was to stress the absolute urgency for the contingency motion to succeed. They failed to do so, or at least they have failed to convince me that it is more urgent to do it now than in 7 3/4 hours time. That is really what it is about. It is very much a reserve weapon. The ability to take note of a question and debate it should be kept in the Standing Orders. It does keep those on the front bench circumspect sometimes in their extravagance, and that is how it should be-but not just because it is of a special pet interest to Senator Coulter.
Question put:
That the motion (Senator Coulter's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the Senate that I have received the following letter, dated 22 May, from Senator Boswell:

INTERJECT.PARA: Dear Mr President,
Pursuant to Standing Order 75, I give notice that today I propose to move-
`That, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:
This government's failure to provide small business with the necessary economic climate in which to survive, as evidenced by the record number of business failures and bankruptcies.'
Yours sincerely,
Ron Boswell
Senator for Queensland
Senator the Hon. Kerry Sibraa
President of the Senate
Parliament House
Canberra ACT 2600
Is the proposal supported?
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:
This government's failure to provide small business with the necessary economic climate in which to survive, as evidenced by the record number of business failures and bankruptcies.

The crescendo of criticism of this Government's economic policies is matched only by the escalation of business bankruptcies right throughout Australia. The powerhouse, the dynamo, the engine room of the Australian economy, is small business, and it is failing while this Government plays semantics with the recession that is on the small business agenda at the moment.

Today I asked Senator Button a question, more in hope than in expectation, that he would be able to offer some solutions to the small business community. I asked him why people were going broke and he could not give an answer. I asked him whether the Government had any policies or hope that it could offer the small business community in its hour of need. The short answer was no. Senator Button thought that everything would be all right if the Government reduced demand in the economy. That was the Australian Labor Party's way out of this impending disaster which is almost upon us. We have seen up to 10,000 businessmen go broke since Christmas.

I moved today's urgency motion because for many small business people the term `recession' has no meaning. They have receded as far as they can. There is no further retreat possible. Their only alternative is to close up shop and walk away from a lifetime's work and savings or be put in the hands of a receiver. That is why the question that this motion asks has to be answered today: what is the Government going to do about the number of people that are heading into bankruptcy?

We have seen the big players, Qintex Australia Ltd and Hooker Corporation Ltd, go down. There has been much public attention focused on the spectacular corporate collapses and we have seen the number of corporate collapses escalate dramatically between 1987-88 and 1988-89-from 4,836 to 6,189. They are massive figures. But small business has suffered even more under this Government's economic mismanagement. According to the Attorney-General's Department, in the January-March quarter this year there were 2,142 small business bankruptcies-450 more than for the same quarter last year, an increase of 27 per cent. Those business people have been put out of work and if they employed four people, that means that approximately another 8,000 people are on the dole queue, dependent on some type of welfare for their survival.

We are finding now that the 2,142 businesses that went broke are only the tip of the iceberg. The Australian Small Business Association put out a press release saying that even those figures are inadequate in depicting a true picture of what is happening. Whilst statistics on bankruptcy show a steady increase in business failures, that is only a very small part of the larger picture. Many businesses close down before they actually go bankrupt-before they become a statistic. The owners simply close their doors, sell their remaining assets, shoulder their debts, send their wives off to work, try to find a job in order to pay off the debt and, nine times out of 10, lose their home.

It is obvious that statistics can never truly paint a picture of the hurt and suffering caused by business collapses. They do not explain the years of hard work which have gone into building up the goodwill and assets of a business, often secured against the family home, or the heartbreak of people who know that they are going broke and try to work their way out of it and pull out of the dive by trying to extend their own working time or their wives' working time, only to find that bankruptcy is inevitable because of Government policies.

Small business is the yardstick by which to measure the whole country's economic performance. All people have to do today is walk down to the shopping centres, their local factory or business and ask the business people how they are going. They will all say that it has never been tougher. We had an expression when I was in the trade that we used when things got tough. We used to say, `Even the liars are complaining'. That is the way it is at the moment. Not one person out in the community-not even the most optimistic small business person-is saying that things are good. Things are crook, and, according to Senator Button, this Government does not have the answers to the problems, or if it does have the answers, Senator Button is not prepared to tell the Senate about them.

I believe that there has never been a more arrogant government in its attitude to small business. The Government wants small businesses to be de facto tax collectors and red tape merchants, to bear the brunt of a hopelessly complex tax system, to pay the Government's sales tax before they have received it themselves, and to be well-resourced advocates of industrial relations and the very poorest of relations when it comes to combating the abuse of market power by big companies. The Government wants small business people to offer it capital gains tax after they have worked all their lives, established a nest egg and then want to sell their business. The Government comes in for its share after years and years of hard work by small business. For many small business people the only way that they can retire is by selling their business, thereby having some form of comfortable living after years of hard work. But even that is being denied the small business community.

Small business is supposed to be the great innovator and centrepiece of our economy and the largest private employer and taxpayer. Yet one would think that, because this Government requires small business to be all of those things, it would show some sympathy. But the economic climate for small business provided by this Government is like Delilah was to Samson-it has robbed small business of its strength and vitality. How can any business sustain the loss of incentive to make profits in the way that this Government has forced on small business? How can small business compete when faced with the prices and interest rates that the Government has imposed upon it? Cost increases, like those achieved under the accord, will increase the cost of workers' employment conditions by up to 22 per cent. Employer groups have worked out that the costs will increase by up to 15 to 20 per cent on such things as the increasing cost of superannuation, shorter hours, second tier wage increases, and a training levy to be now imposed on businesses with payrolls of over $200,000-which is really only a very small business with seven or eight employees. It is really just another tax.

Someone has to tell the Treasurer (Mr Keating)-and I hope it is Senator McMullan-that he cannot flog a dead horse; or he can, but it will not take him very far. This Government has flogged small business for all it is worth and it cannot be flogged any more. The Government cannot bring the economy to its knees by forcing it to pay more for labour while demanding competitiveness. It cannot abolish trade tariffs without making progress on labour tariffs. Australia's dismal manufacturing importance cannot be improved while the Government's high interest rates, labour costs and array of taxes discourage investment in plant and equipment and labour.

It is no wonder that the manufacturing sector of this nation has lost 31,000 jobs in the last 12 months. The Government has replaced our manufacturing sector with the import sector. Senator Lewis put it very succinctly the other day when he said that our main exports now are empty containers which are sent back to the country from which they came. That is what we are reduced to. The Government has increased costs for small business and small manufacturers by adding all of those costs-training levies, shorter hours, second tier wages and increased superannuation-to the cost of employees' wages and it has reduced the Australian manufacturing industry to almost nothing.

The Government and Senator McMullan have missed the vital link which will restore our competitive fortunes-the true labour market reform that delivers on productivity. The Government has to stop theorising about it. It cannot keep increasing costs for small business and expect it to be productive. The Government has to be able to stand up to the Australian Council of Trade Unions and say, `Listen, we cannot inflict any more costs on small business because it just cannot carry them any more'.

The Government has talked about deregulation of the transport industry, the communications industry, the shipping industry and the rural industry but it has never talked about deregulation of the labour industry. It has missed the whole point. The Government will never increase Australia's productivity while it imposes those centralised wage costs on small businesses, whether it can pay them or not. We are facing record bankruptcies in this nation because of the Government's twin policies of high interest rates and high costs on small business through this induced centralised wage fixing system.

There has been no significant interest rate relief for small business, and this is the other part of the equation of the small business collapse. Many are still paying 18 to 20 per cent interest and some are paying even higher. No business can survive the infliction of these interest rates. As one who had a successful small business for 18 years before I came into this place, I do not believe that there are very many small businesses that can pay those interest rates and survive. Yet we find that this Government has nothing to offer the people.

I have continually questioned Senator Button through the course of this week, pleading with him to give some ray of hope to small business. He cannot come up with any answers except, `We are going to reduce demand.' We have tried that and it has not worked. The Government has reduced demand all right, but it has almost reduced every small business in this nation to bankruptcy. The Government's tight monetary policy is having a snowballing effect. Even if high interest rates were to come off, we would still see many small business people overstretched and going into voluntary bankruptcy or liquidation. It is not only the Opposition that is demanding that the Government do something; it is not only the Opposition that is saying the Government's policies are not working. Retailers are also saying it and the banks are warning that worse is ahead.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have been saying that for years.

—Even the Australian Democrats are saying that the Government's policies are not working. Everyone is screaming from the rooftops that the policies of this Government are failing. They are failing small business and they are failing Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: Even Senator Walsh, who had the decency and the courage to come out and say something because he was so frustrated, believed Labor's policies were not working. He believed that the Labor Government was leading this nation into the greatest financial disaster of all time. Government members would not take any notice of him from the front bench so he went onto the back bench to see whether he could give a lead there. He stood up there and tried to direct operations from the back bench. He is a very honest man.

TALK.START.PARA: —He is now. Where was he when he was in government?

—He is an honest man. He stuck to Cabinet solidarity, but at least he got out there and said something. He knew the policies of this Government were going to lead this nation to bankruptcy. I say that he is an honest man, and I find myself in agreement with Senator Walsh on a number of issues now-post-election.

SPEECH.PARA: Even the Minister for Small Business and Customs (Mr Beddall) is telling the Government that small business is going through a tough cycle, that there is genuine hardship, that people are feeling the pinch, that there is a further possibility of more bankruptcies that things are going to get worse before they get better. Mr Beddall has announced that his small business report is a blueprint for the next few years and that his main aim is to get the Government off the back of small business. His report contains medium and long term solutions. I have read that report and it is a very good report. I must say that it is not just his report, it is a report supported by all the parties in this Parliament.

I suggest that the new Minister is going to have a hell of a battle to have capital gains tax reduced. I think Mr Keating has said that through his Department it will be almost impossible, although Senator Button has lent some support, saying that on rollovers a reduction is important for small business. We will see who wins on that issue. Last time Senator Button spoke up he got not a slap on the wrist but six of the best from the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Keating).

There is also criticism from Barry Jones, another ex-Minister. What he suggests is that Government members spend six months in opposition because they need a bit of rest and recreation and they are losing their commitment to getting on with the job. They squabble, they break ranks, they engage in public pay-backs and brawls. Generally they act like small kids who have been allowed to stay up too late and are overtired. We can make fun of this, but it is a very serious problem. It is even more serious when one is out there trying to battle to hold a business together.

I want to touch on the comments of Nobby Clark, the Managing Director of the National Australia Bank. He says that this is the worst time for small business in 45 years. I hope that when Senator McMullan gets up to answer my criticisms he will give small businesses some hope, some idea of the Government's plans to get them out of the absolute mess that they are in. Every indicator is pointing to the loss of jobs and the downfall of small business. The primary producers are suffering up to a 250 per cent increase in bankruptcies. The number of houses being built has dropped by 23 per cent. The Master Builders Association believes non-housing construction will drop by up to 15 to 20 per cent. Liquor stores and retail associations say sales are dropping. With Mr Clark's admission that this is the worst time in 45 years, some people are going to have a cataclysmic landing. It will not be a hard landing, he says, it will be a terminal landing. Every possible indicator is telling this Government that the small business sector has had enough. Its problems have got to be addressed immediately.

My urgency motion states that this Government has failed to provide small business with the necessary economic climate in which to survive. The Government has failed 750,000 small business people and two million families that depend upon small business. We believe it is imperative that action be taken which will help soften the impact. I look forward to Senator McMullan's explanation of how he is going to help small business in the near future.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I certainly do not blame Senator Boswell for looking forward to these remarks; they are going to be worth every bit of it. In the process, I want to make a couple of comments about those things which he did say-and there were not a lot. Essentially, most of the things that were recounted-it was strained logic-were things that have not changed at all over the last five years. It is hard to understand, as a matter of logic, how that can be the explanation of the changed circumstances that small business faces. There have been some changes, and I want to refer to those, but most of those matters to which the blame was attributed are matters that have been constant over the past several years.

SPEECH.PARA: I also found it a little surprising that we had stories about the collapse of manufacturing production and new capital expenditure. Any graphs produced over the past five years will show a continuing trend of substantial increase in manufacturing production and new capital expenditure. If those are the criteria indicating a good climate for small business, then over the past four years the climate has been tremendous. Manufacturing production increases over the past four years have been 2.5 per cent, 1.5 per cent, 6 per cent, and 5.5 per cent; and over the first two quarters of this financial year, 6.6 per cent and 2.8 per cent. Those are the most recent figures as published in the monthly economic and social indicators.

New capital expenditure is where this crisis apparently exists. There is a terrible climate in which people are not prepared to invest. Over the past four years, the annual rates of increase of new capital expenditure have been 10 per cent, 8.5 per cent, 10.5 per cent and 13.4 per cent. They really are indicators that if the signposts Senator Boswell is trying to mark out are the appropriate ones, then of recent times there has been an extraordinarily good climate, and I did not hear words of congratulations on those occasions.

Essentially, the Opposition through this motion is trying to say, `We wish the business cycle would go away'. Economic management and business management would be a lot easier if things did not change. Let us turn our attention away from a wish list to the role of government in relation to small business. I retain the view, which I think Senator Boswell would share, that the best people to run small business are small business proprietors, not the Government. We do not want to start creating a situation in which the Government runs around saying, `We are going to show you how to run your business'. I acknowledge that and, as I said, I think Senator Boswell would share that view. He may run small business slightly better than some other members of the Opposition who were not quite as successful as he was; nevertheless, it is a proper principle.

The Government's obligation is to create an economic climate in which there is demand for the products of small business, in which demand is growing, in which the cost of supplying those goods or services from small business are as low as possible, and in which small business is assisted-to the extent that it is within the realm of government to assist-to have the capacity to run businesses efficiently and profitably. From time to time those circumstances of growth and restrain of costs do lead to that capacity to run a business profitably but from time to time it is inevitable that there will be some economic downturn. In every country in the world, in every economy in the world, and in every decade, the rate of growth changes. It cannot always be maintained at the peak. We need to provide training and assistance to small businesses to allow them to cope as best they can with the downturn.

Let me refer to some statistics about the economic climate which I alluded to when rebutting some of the points Senator Boswell made. If we look at the first obligation of the Federal Government in dealing with small business, which is to create a climate of economic growth, a climate in which the demand for the products of small business might be increasing, we find a record of sustained growth for many years-a record indicating an extraordinarily strong climate of economic growth and demand. I will use calendar year statistics because it makes comparisons with other countries easier, although Australians are used to using financial years. The statistics would not be significantly different.

In Australia in calendar year 1985 the growth of gross domestic product was 5 per cent and in subsequent years, 2.1 per cent, 4.3 per cent, 3.7 per cent and 4.1 per cent. So up to calendar year 1989 there was an average rate of growth over those years of 3.85 per cent compared to an Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development average of about 3.6 per cent and a European Economic Community average of about 3 per cent. In the 12 months to June 1989-this is the cause of a significant part of the problem which we confront-the growth in domestic demand in Australia grew by 8.6 per cent whereas, unfortunately, production grew by only 4.2 per cent.

Those supply side constraints were what blew out our balance of payments and have necessitated the slowdown of demand, which is the changed circumstance creating the difficulties for small business. I want to come back to the question of supply side constraints, but it is necessary at the beginning to acknowledge that domestic demand significantly exceeding domestic capacity to meet that demand and the consequent balance of payments problems have forced a tightening of monetary policy. That has eased off the pace of demand growth. The majority of indicators would suggest that demand is slowing without pulling the economy up altogether. The Government recognises that high interest rates are biting in both the business and the household sectors. However, if we do not moderate demand we run the risk of a burgeoning in our debt to a level that neither we nor, more importantly, our children will be able to sustain without dire economic hardship. We have to recognise and deal with the economic circumstances with which we are confronted.

Supply side constraint is not new. It is not something that has emerged since June 1989. It is not something that has emerged since March 1983. It is a product of 30 or 40 years of industrial policy failure in Australia. We do have to deal with it through this jargon term of micro-economic reform. I am not very enthusiastic about that term. I think that if we talk about efficiency, most people know what we mean. It will take away some of the jargon, the aura or mystique and we will get down to some of the things that people can understand. If time permits I will come back to the issue of micro-economic reform.

We have had to cope with the consequences of that supply side constraint. The growth has existed over the last five years and it is the responsibility of all governments to try to keep generating that growth. As to the question of cost controls, real unit labour costs have fallen consistently over the last seven years. Inflation has fallen-but not enough; it is still too high. It will fall further, but it remains a major problem in the Australian economy and nobody can ignore that.

TALK.START.PARA: —When is it going to fall?

—The Government's predictions about the rate at which it will fall and the point to which it will fall-about 6 per cent by the middle of next year-is about right. That is not excessively optimistic but it is also not a cause for great complacency. It is a very poor effort. But inflation is a very difficult problem to bring under control. Australian governments since the war have not had a successful record in dealing with it. If we get inflation down to 6 per cent, that will be a 5 per cent fall since we came to office. But it is not a cause for opening the champagne and saying that it is a victory; it is just a step along the road. Over the last six years some of the cost circumstances have been very suitable for small business. Real unit labour costs have fallen, real wages have remained tight yet, because of the growth in employment, household disposable income has increased-that is, costs tight and demand growing.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn briefly in the time available to the Government's obligation to provide assistance to business so it can be as well geared, as well structured as possible to cope with the inevitable swings of the business cycle. One of those areas relates to training. I reiterate my initial point that I do not think it is government's job to run small business. Small business proprietors are better at doing that. The Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce and the Department of Employment, Education and Training are currently involved in a joint study of the training needs of small business. It is important; it is overdue. Nobody has done it before. This is the first Government that has addressed training, and it is time that it was addressed.

Substantial initiatives are also being taken in the provision of government advisory services to small business through the establishment of a small business council-which was set up by this Government, not by any of its predecessors, not by the conservative governments of the past. It has provided a series of advisings and has suggested initiatives. For example, the Government has agreed to provide support for a consultancy to develop a national small business foundation and the establishment of a national industry extension scheme, with which I have been somewhat involved in the Australian Capital Territory and which has provided a lot of assistance to many small businesses in terms of creativity and coordination. It has also provided support for the establishment, in conjunction with key private sector organisations, of a joint Commonwealth-State national small business information and awareness program, and for research into small business matters which is carried out by the small business research unit in the Bureau of Industry Economics and the publication of reports.

Those things are only creating the potential for small business to succeed. It is not the Government's job to run them but it is the Government's job to provide the advice and the infrastructure. It should have been provided by previous governments and was not. To some extent that obligation is being met. Many changes have also been made to the taxation system to assist small business, the most fundamental area of all. People talk about tax in a very complicated way. Basically, people understand tax in a much simpler way. The rates of tax have come down. The top tax rate has come down; the rate of corporate tax has come down.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tax overall has gone massively up.

—But the tax rate for small business and others has gone down. In fact, tax as a percentage of gross domestic product has not gone up either, but that is not the point of this discussion. For an individual small business trying to succeed, the key statistic-when one peels away all of the Opposition's rhetoric about the taxes it wishes did not exist-is `what percentage of my profit do I have to pay in tax?'. The rate has gone down and division 7 tax on so-called excessive retentions has been abolished. Imputation has been introduced. They are all things that any small business proprietor will tell us have been a substantial benefit to him.

SPEECH.PARA: We also have the commencement of the very important tax simplification project. It is a very long haul. There are no miracles in the simplification of tax. It is a big and complex task confronting not just the Tax Office and the Treasury, but business, the professions and the community at large. When the discussion paper comes out, we will be looking for comments from all of those people. Many of the interim stages during the development of the simplification process will be substantial benefit to individual men and women running small businesses.

I do not have the time to go into the substantial improvements to the tax level; and the provision of information, inquiry services and pilot programs to assist in rural and isolated communities; and the question of the ability to carry forward tax losses indefinitely, rather than in the limited way that was possible before. All those things are important.

Obviously, I cannot fail to address the question of capital gains tax. Senator Button addressed this question perfectly adequately in a substantial way at Question Time by saying that when small business was doing very well, the capital gain structure was exactly the same as it is now. So it is hard to claim that the capital gains tax is the cause of the current problem. There seems to be a logical flaw in such a claim.

The Minister for Small Business and Customs (Mr Beddall) was quoted somewhat out of context and selectively after having spoken on the Walsh Report about some of the issues that he perceives regarding capital gains tax and small business and the roll-over question. But I have not seen quoted his comment that, `I would like to achieve that in the long term. There are some benefits in that'.

This is a difficult argument because Treasury and Taxation make the valid point that once one tinkers with the tax law, one can open up loopholes. It is our responsibility to try to convince them that there is a way of rolling over the capital gain for a trading business without opening up loopholes.

That is a question to which the Opposition has never addressed itself. It regards finding loopholes in the capital gains tax as one of its obligations to its constituency, so that tax can become optional again, like it used to be before the capital gains tax was introduced. We do not and we will not share that view. If there is a way in which tax can be changed to address the requirements of small business without undermining the integrity of the system, let us look at it. But let us ensure that we are not passing obligations on to the honest taxpayers.

I want to talk briefly about the other controversial area-which I heard Senator McLean address by way of interjection-concerning banks, credit and interest rates. These very important issues were raised in comments by Mr Greiner this morning. There is anecdotal evidence abroad of banks cutting back on credit to otherwise very strong and sound businesses that could continue. I have to say that at the moment the statistics on bank credit do not bear out that anecdotal information. It appears that the supply of credit is keeping pace with nominal demand. It may be that there is a delay in the statistics coming through; it may be that a change is being disguised by the pattern that has applied to small business.

We have all heard the anecdotal evidence and we all know of some individual cases that have occurred. I suppose we have to say in passing that if this is a sign of increasing rigour by the banks in the application of their prudential requirements, it would be welcome. But if it is undermining support for otherwise sound business, that is something which would not be welcome. Excessive caution in that area would not be welcome; it would not be a case of the banks discharging their proper obligations within the corporate structure in Australia.

As the Treasurer (Mr Keating) said, there is room for further falls in interest rates to small business following from the easing of monetary policy since January. Nobody pretends that that is suddenly going to mean that interest rates will be low. It will not. They will not be in the short term and there is no point in pretending otherwise. But there is the capacity for further falls and we would expect-

TALK.START.PARA: —When are they going to happen?

—I regret to say that Senator Boswell is asking the wrong person. The Government has made possible the easing of monetary policy which creates the potential for those falls. We would expect that in the private enterprise climate, which the Opposition supports and which we recognise and support, the banks, in their competitive environment, will pass those on to small business as it becomes possible. The Government has created the climate for this to follow.

SPEECH.PARA: Nobody could pretend that this is not a difficult time to be running any sort of business, small or large. There is no magic wand. There is not some easy formula where we can say all of a sudden that the problems of small business are solved. Small businesses do not exist in a world by themselves outside the economic circumstance in which big business, private enterprise and public enterprise-all the industries that go to make up our total economy-exist. Small business does not exist in a world by itself.

The only solution is to restore the economy to sustainable growth with low inflation. This means sound macro-economic policies-fiscal, wages, monetary, and, if you like, exchange rate policies. It is a question of micro-economic reform and efficiency, but let us keep that in perspective. The macro-economic measures are always going to be more important. It is a question of providing special assistance to small businesses by way of advice and information to make it possible for them to operate. The best people to run small businesses are small business proprietors, not government and we should not pretend otherwise. Therefore, it has been the Government's obligation, and it remains its obligation, to concentrate on getting the economic fundamentals right, which we have done over the last seven years and which we will continue to concentrate on doing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise as the Australian Democrats spokesperson on small business to support this urgency motion. We are speaking on this urgency motion at a time when small businesses in Australia are in a crisis only surpassed by that experienced during the so-called Great Depression. Recent statistics show that bankruptcies and business failures are rapidly increasing and this has a major impact on all Australians. The significance of small business to Australia is set out in the third paragraph of the preface of the recently produced January 1990 report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology, which is known as the Beddall report. The report says this:

SPEECH.PARA: There are 600,000 small businesses in Australia-and an additional 150,000 in the farming sector. The precise contribution of the 750,000 small businesses to Australia is difficult to quantify but is substantial.
That is an understatement; it is a massive contribution from the 750,000 small businesses. The report continues:
They account for 96 per cent of all firms, half of the private sector employment and a third of all employment in Australia.
The existence of the small business sector contributes greatly to the flexibility of the economy and its ability to evolve to meet changing demands.

I am quoting from the first major report on small business since Federation. Almost 40 per cent of Australians are employed by small businesses. When these businesses go to the wall the impact passes like shock waves through all levels of our society. Only small businesses can be the vehicle of our economic recovery and until something is done to alleviate their economic woes, Australia will not come out of its present economic morass.

They are the simple realities of the significance of small business to this nation. It is a reality that this sector of the economy is in absolute crisis. It is all right for the Opposition, however, to point the finger of blame at the Government but, frankly, its record is no better. This critical sector of the economy has been ignored by successive governments. This is reported recently in the Beddall committee-the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology, and I will return to it later. The Beddall report reflects on the plight of small business as it has resulted from the failure of successive governments and not only the current Government. The Australian Democrats believe that a major contributor to the plight of small business was the deregulation of banks. This dramatically changed the climate in which small businesses have had to operate and in which small businesses have failed to cope.

Senator McMullan earlier cited the constructive things that the Government has done in support of small business, particularly in the area of taxation. We must acknowledge that some constructive things have been done by this Government in support of small business. However, the significant thing that this Government has done is to create a deregulated banking climate, a disastrous climate, in which small business has been unable to sustain itself. We now have a situation where we see the likes of Mr Fowler, the Managing Director of Westpac Banking Corporation, and Nobby Clark, who was quoted earlier by Senator Boswell, crying the plight of small business in this country, when we have been arguing in this place for the last 18 months that it is banks, in the context of deregulated banking, that have substantially created this plight. I have said over and over again, and will continue to say whilst ever I am a senator in this place, that deregulated banking has emasculated small business and must be reversed.

Banks have a three-way bind on us. First of all, at the stroke of a pen they create credit. Credit is a positive sounding word-but it is debt. It is credit in the banks' books, but it is a debit or debt in our books and the banks have created massive indebtedness. They are now saying that small business and ordinary individuals in this country cannot service that debt at interest rates running at 17 and 18 per cent and in excess of 30 per cent on overdrafts. I tabled in this place a document called the Argus memo. It revealed that Mr Nobby Clark's bank was asking small business people to service debt short term in excess of 30 per cent. If they cannot service that debt they are being bled white in attempting to service these levels of indebtedness. The banks are now going to foreclose on the assets which they previously cited as justification for enticing these small business people into that level of indebtedness. So we will see a wave of foreclosures; in fact, the leading bank magnates of this country cite the fact that they are going to have to foreclose on the very people that they have led into this chronic level of indebtedness.

The realities are that deregulated banking is not competitive banking at all. The banks in this country have behaved like cartels. One rise in interest rates is followed by another and then another. If it were a truly competitive situation, one of them would take advantage of the fact that the others are lifting their rates, but it is not a truly competitive situation.

TALK.START.PARA: —They do shop around.

—They do not. I have been looking at this issue constantly for the last 18 months and the banks admit that within days they will follow suit in raising their interest rates. Within weeks building societies follow suit, and within months so do credit unions.

SPEECH.PARA: I agree with the proposition raised by Senator McMullan that the banks are primarily responsible for spiralling interest rates. That is in the context of what they describe, in their own words, as super profits. We had Mr Fowler bleeding several days ago and apologising to his shareholders that for the first time in several stated half-yearly profit periods he had had to declare that profit was declining for his bank. Even though his bank recorded a profit of $340m-odd, he is wailing the same plea that symptomises the devastation of the very small business people he is asking to service the indebtedness that he had created at interest rates sometimes in excess of 30 per cent.

There has been total abandonment of the fiduciary relationship in banking. Banks are pursuing profits irrespective of the consequences to their clients. I will be tabling in this place on Thursday, as I have already done, evidence of the fact that that is clearly the case. I think honourable senators are aware that I have tabled affidavits relating to in excess of 80 cases now. That is just a sample of what is happening out there in banks exploiting their clients-I believe in complete defiance of the fiduciary relationship under law-in pursuit of their own super profits.

This new wave of foreclosures was inevitable. It simply reflects the very nature of banking. People are offered credit-that is, debt-secured against an asset. I have tabled in this place examples of banks that have foreclosed on those assets and then sold them off at 25 per cent of the valuation that they arrived at when they induced the business person to take the credit, in some cases less than 12 months previously. For the consideration of honourable senators I have tabled clear examples of this abandonment of the fiduciary relationship. I will be doing more of this in the remaining two weeks of this session and into the next parliamentary session.

One of the tragedies of the failures of small business is that small businesses are the clients of large businesses. As small businesses go to the wall, so the shock wave impacts upon large business. We have seen, and it has been much quoted in the media, the fate of so-called WA Inc. in Western Australia. There were a whole series of medium to large and very substantial businesses going to the wall at a cost of $699.5m. For the consideration of honourable senators I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a list of in the vicinity of 20 major business failures under the general heading of `WA Inc. Losses' which simply cites the impact upon medium to large business of what has been happening across this nation in the context of deregulated banking for the last six or seven years.
Leave granted.
