TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. Finally, in the few minutes remaining to me, I would like to look at the hopeful side, the more positive side, of the situation in which small businesses find themselves in Australia. I do not think we can alter the fact that there is a major crisis on our hands. It is the product of neglect of consecutive governments and of deregulated banking. I believe that there is a ray of hope in the pages of this document, now known as the Beddall report, which is titled Small Business in Australia-Challenges, Problems and Opportunities. It is at least a ray of hope to see that the Beddall report sees some future for small businesses. I know that at the moment many small businesses see no hope whatsoever.

SPEECH.PARA: I commend this document to the Senate. When the Council of Small Business Organisations of Australia in the pre- election context went to the Government, the Opposition and the Australian Democrats and asked, `How do you regard this report?', it sought assurances from government and alternate government at the time that the 66 recommendations of the Beddall report would be implemented irrespective of who came into office.

The Australian Democrats were the only ones to respond to that request by the Council of Small Business Organisations of Australia. Not even the Government, which had commissioned this report, was prepared in the pre-election context to commit itself to the 66 recommendations. Neither was the Opposition-the very Opposition which is castigating the Government today over the current fate of small business.

The Australian Democrats gave an unequivocal guarantee that we would support all 66 recommendations of the Beddall report. It is a constructive report. For the first time we have something which gives us an historical and a contemporary overview of the problems which confront small business. It makes a series of structural, general and specific recommendations which it believes will redress the plight of small business.

In conclusion, the Australian Democrats support this urgency motion. It is clearly a matter of urgency that the Government address the plight of small business. However, in supporting the urgency motion, we cite the fact that the current situation is not solely the result of the present Government's policies. Indeed, the Beddall report looks at the historical context of the plight of small business.

I give notice that as the Australian Democrats' small business spokesperson I will be returning specifically to the issue of banking. It is fundamental to the survival of small business that we redress the deregulated banking and that we challenge the banking system by setting up a full scale inquiry into banking practices. Irrespective of who is in government, until that wrong is made right, rationality will not prevail in the small business sector.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Olsen Sen J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Whilst I have been in this chamber for only a few weeks, I find it absolutely amazing and an insult to small business that we do not have present on the front bench-I note the presence of the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs (Senator Tate)-a Minister responsible for small business, Treasury or economic matters. So much consideration does the Government have for small business that it is not prepared to have an appropriate Minister sit through an urgency motion of two hours. This is an insult and a disgrace to the largest employment sector-the small business sector.

SPEECH.PARA: I listened to the earlier reply of the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, Senator Button, and the response by Senator McMullan. Senator McMullan said that we are going through a normal business cycle. Some business cycle! He said that that was an excuse for government policy, government inaction and government inertia-government ignoring the plight of small business. If Senator McMullan suggests that this is a normal business cycle with interest rates as high as they are, then I would hate to see his version of unprecedented high interest rates.

I concur with Senator McMullan to the extent that there will always be failures in the business community. Where people give it a go there will be people who fail. But today we are highlighting to the Parliament the magnitude of the number of failures and the escalation in the failure rate. The fact is that small businesses, like home buyers, simply cannot absorb high interest rates being inflicted upon them by government policy.

Senator McMullan said that the Government has a responsibility not to interfere with small business. It is certainly not doing that; it is totally ignoring small business. But it is the Government's responsibility to get the economic fundamentals right. It is the Government's economic policy direction and its high interest rates that are inflicting so much hurt and damage on small business at the moment.

Over the last few days we have seen Australia's banks being put in the firing line by Senator Button, Senator McMullan and Senator McLean. We need to pass off this responsibility on some group rather than on government economic policy. So the buck has been passed to the banking community. Never has there been a more graphic case of misplaced and inappropriate apportionment of blame than that given to the banking community.

On Sunday the Minister for Small Business and Customs (Mr Beddall) said that banks not only treated small business badly but also made it pay for blunders of corporate high flyers. This is an outrageous accusation. Yesterday, the Premier of New South Wales, in identifying policies of the Australian Labor Party as the core of the problem, indicated that the banks were overreacting to the downturn in the economy by pulling the pin on some successful small to medium sized businesses. Nobby Clark, the Managing Director of the National Australia Bank, fuelling the debate, said yesterday that conditions for small business in Australia were the worst he had seen in over 45 years. That is identifying the extent of the problem.

Job creation and retailing appears to have ground to a halt. Throughout the community, city and country alike, shop vacancies are increasing. Figures recently released by the Melbourne Institute of Applied Economic and Social Research suggest that consumer confidence is at its lowest ebb for 17 years.

The traditional quiet months of June, July and August are in front of us. What prospects do small businesses have for survival with interest rates as high as they are at the moment and with the Government showing no inclination whatsoever to ease monetary policy or interest rates. This affects not only small business people but also first home buyers. In the next three to four months they will be faced with a period of traditionally quiet retailing.

During the next three to six months will we see a massive escalation in the number of small businesses going bankrupt? Correspondingly, will we see a very savage increase in the number of people turned out on to the unemployment queues simply because small business is no longer able to provide them with jobs?

Last week Australia's largest retailer, Coles Myer Ltd, revealed that its sales in the March quarter were 5.4 per cent above that of the March quarter last year. That is not even keeping pace with inflation. There is a contraction in the level of retail sales.

As a result of high interest rates people in the age group of 25 to 45-the traditional home buyers; people buying, establishing and equipping their first home-have retreated from the retail market simply because they are trying to keep a roof over their head. They are not equipping their homes with the goods and essentials they would ordinarily require. That is rolling over and affecting the small business community.

They are serious problems. They have been put on the public agenda and they need to be addressed. It is simply not good enough for the Government to come in and say, `It is just the normal business cycle. You have to take the good with the bad. You have to put up with it'. We will not have a small business sector if the Government continues to ignore it.

There is no doubt that the behaviour of Australia's financial institutions is the direct result of the Hawke-Keating lethal cocktail of high interest rates and tight monetary policy. That is the net effect. That is what is filtering out of the community at the moment. Put simply, high interest rates-this Government's deliberate policy; a single instrument policy to dampen demand-are killing Australia's small business sector. The draconian monetary policy is threatening to decimate Australia's entire small business sector.

The Hawke Government has forced the small business sector on to a credit roller-coaster resulting in business failures, small business bankruptcies and forced mortgagee sales. While bankers, economists and politicians argue over whether the economy will have a soft or a hard landing, the small business community has had a crash landing. And the statistics indicate and clearly prove that.

The people have been largely ignored by a party and a Prime Minister which rely heavily on big business, big unions and big government. The forgotten part of the equation is the small business sector, Australia's largest employer. Yet, small business is the heart of the free enterprise system. Senator McMullan said that the Government supported the risk takers and the entrepreneurs in the private sector. The Government is not doing much to assist the small business community of this country. It seems that the Government has forgotten that Henry Ford was once a small businessman. Small beginnings encourage people to invest their life savings, to establish a business and to get out there and give it a go. People who are prepared to be risk takers in that respect deserve a fair go and encouragement from the Government. We have not seen that. The Government has not been interested in backing the small business community.

As John Collins, the President of the Australian Chamber of Commerce has said, when deals are made within the corporate estate on important issues such as industrial relations and micro-economic adjustment, small business would be lucky to be considered even as an afterthought.

Small business's role is crucial in what one could describe as the engine room of the Australian economy. It is the key part of the Australian economy, yet in the last March quarter alone bankruptcies rose by a huge 27 per cent compared with the corresponding period last year. The bottom line is that the small business sector in Australia is in desperate shape. Hence, the urgency motion in this House today. But the Government obviously does not consider the situation to be urgent.

Most small businesses are struggling to survive. Interest rates of 20 to 25 per cent are the norm and not the exception. As the economy moves towards a recession, there are excessive tax burdens and falling demands for products. If one is a small business proprietor and one happens to go over one's overdraft limit, one pays a surcharge for that period in overdraft which is, in some instances, between three and five per cent.

Our high inflation rate of 8.6 per cent, which is higher than that of our major trading partners, impacts on small business simply in the need to restock the inventory, the stock in trade, which is the means by which businesses can trade and service the needs of their clients. With an 8.6 per cent inflation rate, small businesses are required to allocate more of their retained earnings simply to keep stock at last year's levels without giving any consideration to expanding the range of goods and services that they can provide.

Retailers rely on suppliers' trade credit for inventory holdings. Because of high interest rates, in recent times we have seen small businesses, instead of paying for their goods on a 30-day basis, being forced to spin their payments out to a 60-day basis, then to a 90-day basis simply because they do not have the retained earnings in their business to pay their creditors. With the current economic circumstances, when creditors have pressure applied to them, it is applied down the line to the small business operators. Hence, we have this cycle of contraction of funds and available cash within small business to maintain existing stock levels, inventories and credit files for those customers it would ordinarily service. Yet, there are no policies in place to tackle inflation in a meaningful way. Again, we have a credit rollercoaster. Sales tax is a nightmare.

It is interesting to see that we have another division within the Government on the capital gains tax. I noticed that the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce today indicated that he did not think that capital gains tax was a problem at all for small business. It so happens that the Minister for Small Business and Customs, Mr Beddall, thinks it is a major problem confronting small business at the moment. The Minister for Small Business has indicated that he will be taking a Cabinet submission which would allow the roll-over of capital gains tax for trading businesses. He has Senator Button on his side, but he does not have the Treasurer (Mr Keating) on his side. We have become accustomed to who wins in a circumstance like that; it is usually the Treasurer.

So, we have a divergence of views between Ministers handling the area of economics and small business as to what policies ought to be put in place to give some breathing space to small businessmen who have mortgaged their homes and used their life savings to establish a business. Invariably, they rely upon the capital gain of that business over an extended period of time for their superannuation. It is their retirement fund. It is what they accumulate over an extended period of time.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is what they risk, too.

—It is what they risk. Should they not be entitled to plan effectively for their future? The capital gains tax system that we have in place has certainly put a damper on that. The Australian Society of Accountants and the Institute of Chartered Accountants have endorsed the need to look at credit, the incapacity of small business to borrow currently at reasonable rates in the marketplace, the high debt load of small business and the bringing forward of corporate income tax collections. We clearly need to put in place a range of monetary policies which do not rely solely on the single instrument of high interest rates to dampen demand within the community. That is the fundamental flaw in the Government's policy direction. It is relying on a single instrument of policy to dampen demand.

SPEECH.PARA: For example, we should have enterprise agreements. It is ludicrous that the centralised wage fixation system should set the rates for a motor mechanic working in Sydney and apply exactly the same rate to a motor mechanic working in a country town somewhere in the backblocks of South Australia. The cost of living in Sydney is markedly different from the cost of living in that country town in South Australia. The capacity for customer turnover in Sydney is markedly different from that of a country town in outback South Australia. Yet through the centralised wage fixation system we apply the same criteria.

Those businesses have not got the capacity to meet the very divergent cost structures that apply in each case. We need flexibility. Therefore, we need to move to enterprise agreements so that we can get a more rational approach in that area. In addition, the Government needs to reduce its expenditure.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Olsen, your time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Maguire Sen G.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —This afternoon we are debating a motion that has been moved by the Leader of the National Party of Australia in this place, Senator Boswell, alleging the Government's failure in relation to small business in Australia. I outrightly reject this motion. I am not sure whether Senator Boswell is a big businessman or a small businessman, but in 1982-83, when in government, honourable senators opposite drove Australia and small business into a full-blooded recession. They drove thousands of small enterprises in this country to the wall.

SPEECH.PARA: From 1985 onwards, when we were reforming the taxation system, the people opposite tried to defend the indefensible. They defended sectional interests, privilege and, worst of all, inefficiency in the Australian economy. Let us look at Senator Boswell's track record. The very person who moved this motion in the Senate this afternoon, attacking us in relation to small business, in 1985 attacked this Government for disallowing entertainment expenses. He made the most dire predictions. He predicted doom and gloom for Australia as a whole because of our disallowing entertainment expenses as a tax deduction. Today we have the spectacle of Senator Boswell, now in a new role as Leader of the National Party in this place, again spreading doom and gloom and making the worst possible predictions about a key sector of the Australian economy.

The reality is that the entertainment allowance was hardly used by small business. It was a $330m annual rort heavily used by big business, the big end of town. Small business owners could not take advantage of that rort. They were too busy working to have lunches subsidised by the taxpayer. In 1985 Senator Boswell, in this place, foretold doom and gloom for a key section of the Australian economy, the restaurant sector. Of course, the restaurant sector is a small business sector. It is not populated by large business undertakings; it is a small business sector of the economy.

I shall take a few moments this afternoon to check the forecasts made by Senator Boswell less than five years ago, in 1985, about that small business sector. They are on the record. We have all got Hansard and the computerised database. It is fascinating to see the predictions made by conservative politicians in this place. The most important thing that we on this side of the chamber must do time and time again is check those predictions and claims because conservatives, of course, trade on the basic proposition that people out in the electorate have short memories. What they do time and time again is to make predictions hoping that people will forget them in the very near future.

Senator Boswell is on record in Hansard of 4 December 1985, page 2932, as making outrageous claims about the impact of the disallowance of entertainment expenses-getting rid of the free lunch, getting rid of the tax subsidised lunch paid for by other taxpayers in Australia. The present Leader of the National Party is making these claims to defend sectional and privileged interest in Australia. He said that the disallowance of entertainment expenses would lead to a loss of jobs in the restaurant industry of around 11,000. That is a statement from Senator Boswell, the mover of this motion about small business. On the very same page-I do not know how he got to the calculation-he upped the prediction to 14,000 jobs lost in the restaurant industry. That is the reality; that is the prediction Senator Boswell made as recently as 1985 when talking about an important small business sector of this economy. That is what he said. On the very next page of Hansard, he said this:
After the Christmas boom-
this speech was made in December-
. . . around February or March-there will be a massive fall in the Industry.
That is the reality of Senator Boswell's claim. That is what he said in this place.

Let us see how Senator Boswell's predictions came out for a key small business sector of the Australian economy. I want to check those claims and forecasts. After all, Senator Boswell has come in here today and made further doom and gloom claims about the small business sector of the Australian economy. I have had a look at the Australian Bureau of Statistics figures for employment in the restaurant sector, and they make fascinating reading. The figures are official information from the Australian Bureau of Statistics for restaurants, hotels and clubs-in other words, the hospitality service sector of our economy. Bear in mind that Senator Boswell, the present Leader of the National Party, told this place in December 1985 that 11,000 jobs would be lost in the restaurant sector. Then he upped the figure to 14,000. The reality is that in November 1985, a month before Senator Boswell made this speech, there were 230,000 jobs in the service sector, the hospitality sector, of the Australian economy. That is the reality; those are the official figures. In November last year, just recently, 11,000 jobs had not been lost in that sector; in fact, quite the reverse. There were not 230,000 jobs in the hospitality sector of the Australian economy but a massive 307,000 jobs. So in the space of four years, in a climate when the entertainment allowance had been disallowed, when we had stopped businessmen in pinstripe suits in Sydney and Melbourne going out to lunch and ticking it up to the taxpayer to the tune of $330m a year-something that small businessmen could not do-77,000 extra jobs had been created in the hospitality sector of the Australian economy, and overwhelmingly those jobs were in the small business sector.

So there we have Senator Boswell, the Leader of the National Party, exposed. He thought he would get away today with making further doom and gloom claims about a key business sector, but the record shows that as recently as four years ago he had no credibility in making predictions about business; he is simply not believable. The reality is that, while Senator Boswell said that the hospitality industry would go down, it went up-despite his predictions.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about small business today?
—Senator Parer is very lucky that I did not pull out some of the quotes he made about the industry in 1985. They are on the record, too.

SPEECH.PARA: This motion again demonstrates amply that the conservatives take a narrow view of economic management and of key sectors of business. They do not have the full perspective of what happens out there in the marketplace. In fact, conservatives are incapable of seeing the big picture so far as business is concerned.

This motion focuses on Government monetary policy. That is not spelt out but that seems to be the focus. The motion seems to be about interest rates and the cost of finance. It goes on to make claims about bankruptcy levels. I happen to monitor bankruptcy figures very closely, and I have had a look at the figures for my State of South Australia. It is just not sustainable for conservative politicians to make sweeping claims about universal increases in bankruptcies across the board. Let us look at the first months of this year.

TALK.START.PARA: —Twenty per cent of Australia's bankruptcies are in South Australia.

—Senator Olsen is going off about bankruptcies in South Australia. In the Adelaide Advertiser of 15 May, which I thought I would keep here as insurance, an article appears under the headline `Low Level of Bankruptcies Puzzles Experts'. That is a newspaper in Senator Olsen's own State. The article states that in the first quarter of 1989, the first three months of 1989, the Small Business Corporation of South Australia had identified 92 business bankruptcies in the State and that-surprise!-in the first three months of 1990 there were not 92 but 81. Presumably, Senator Olsen has not read this article, but it certainly pays to do your research in this place and keep abreast of what is really happening out there in the community. Doom and gloom is being spread around the place by conservative politicians-yet there is the fact from the research director of the South Australian Small Business Corporation saying, `Well, 92 last year; 81 this year for the same period'.

SPEECH.PARA: The Hawke Labor Government believes that small business is a vital sector for the Australian economy. We are well aware of its dominance in the private non-agricultural sector of the economy, where some 44 per cent of total employment is in the hands of small business people. It plays a major role in the economy, and I am certainly aware of major overseas studies that show that the formation of small business is a major source of total job growth in the overall economy. One of the key determinants of how many jobs are created is in fact the number of small businesses actually being started up. So we are certainly well aware of those factors. We do acknowledge that there is concern out there about the level of interest rates and the cost of finance, and that has already been amply canvassed this afternoon by other spokespersons.

There is more to Government policies and economic management than just talking about monetary policy and the cost of finance; there is wages policy, incomes policy and fiscal policy. For example, the key difference between this Government and the conservatives-who, fortunately, are on the Opposition benches and will stay there for some time-is that we have operated a very successful incomes policy. We have allowed the Australian economy over seven years to expand significantly without double digit inflation occurring; we have had a managed incomes policy. I think Senator McMullan made the point earlier that cost pressures faced by small business under the Fraser-Howard Liberal Government were running at 11.5 per cent per annum. That certainly was the consumer price index in 1982-83, but I think Senator Olsen said a moment ago that the CPI was now running at 8.6 per cent. So there we have a three percentage points reduction in the underlying cost structure facing Australian business.

What about the other side of wages policy? One of the great successes of the Hawke Government for small business is in keeping down the number of industrial disputes, cutting out the sheer number of days lost in industrial disputes around this nation. It is a tremendous achievement. For example, when the Liberal-National Party coalition was last in power-and I have checked this with the Parliamentary Library-the number of days lost in Australia due to industrial disputes was two million. Two million days were wasted in this nation due to industrial disputes-a great disruption to both small business and big business, which really suffered because their products could not get to markets. There were disruptions everywhere in the economy.

Under the Hawke Labor Government we do not have two million days lost annually due to industrial disputes. We do not even have 1 3/4 million days lost. The last figures show that 1.2 million days were lost in industrial disputes compared with two million under the Liberals. They are very important things to bear in mind.

I think we should also look at investment. Firms are not going to be investing if they are going to the wall. Surely the proof of the pudding is in the eating. If there is large investment going on in the Australian economy, something must be going right in the productive sectors of the economy. I want now to run quickly through some investment figures. For example, real business investment in Australia is running at a level 68 per cent higher than it was under the last Liberal Government. It is 68 per cent higher in real terms; in other words, it has gone up 68 per cent more than inflation. That is an enormous increase in investment. The average rate of growth of investment under this Government for the last five years has been 10.8 per cent per annum, whereas in the last five years of the Liberal Government it was 1.6 per cent per annum-an enormous difference. The investment has gone into plant and equipment, new factories, warehouses-all of which, in the longer term, create jobs.

We have also helped small business-particularly incorporated businesses-by adding the double tax on dividends. No longer is company tax paid on company profits as well as income tax on dividends in the hands of recipients. We tax one or the other now, and that has certainly been an advantage for incorporated enterprises. We have cut the rate of company tax from 49c to 39c in the dollar.

Those measures have been funded by cracking down on the rorts. We got rid of the free lunch-$330m a year ticked up to other taxpayers. We brought in the fringe benefits tax and that is now pulling in about $900m a year. The revenue from those things is funding the reforms we have put in place.

The motion moved by Senator Boswell this afternoon should be rejected-it should be thrown out. I have shown that in the past Senator Boswell has been totally without credibility in making predictions in this place. He certainly has no credibility in making these predictions today about small business. The record of the Liberals in government was to send small business to the wall by the thousand. Labor recognises the key role of this sector of the economy and we are implementing a major report on small business. We have got the runs on the board on small business and the Opposition's rhetoric is no match for the Government's achievements.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles Sen S.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —If Senator Maguire's contribution were not so serious it would almost be laughable. Senator Maguire has the audacity to stand up in here today, when we are debating a most serious urgency motion, and accuse the Opposition-in particular, Senator Boswell-of not having any credibility concerning small business. The only three people in this debate with small business experience are the three coalition speakers. Senator McMullan is an Australian Labor Party official; Senator Maguire is a researcher-cum-whatever he certainly is not a businessman; and Senator Cooney is a barrister. Senator Maguire has got the audacity to talk about credibility. Who has got the credibility?

SPEECH.PARA: Senator McMullan was absolutely and utterly amazing, as was Senator Maguire. He is still going on with ancient history, blaming the Fraser Government for the problems that small business is experiencing today. But then again, we cannot expect him to understand or empathise with small businesses because not only has he never been in one but also, he has never had to deal with them. He has never gone to them nose to nose, eyeball to eyeball, and had a look at the issues day to day. He has never had to worry about struggling to pay the staff wages at the end of the week. He has never had to worry about paying workers' compensation, the rent, the telephone, payroll tax and all the other taxes. He has never had to worry about filling out the copious quantities of paper work that this Government and the State governments demand on a daily, weekly, monthly and annual basis.

No. All is well because obviously, from listening to Senator Maguire's contribution, small businesses have never been better off than they are today. I suggest that Senator Maguire get out there and talk to some of the small businessmen who are going broke.
The urgency motion states:
This government's failure to provide small business with the necessary economic climate in which to survive, as evidenced by the record number of business failures and bankruptcies.

We could not make it more specific if we tried, and the facts are there to substantiate it. The reason many businesses are going broke in the overwhelming majority of cases is not because of their own inadequacies but because of the disastrous economic climate brought about by this Hawke-Keating Government. This Labor Government has failed the 750,000 small businesses in this country. Once a government decides to rely upon interest rates as its major economic tool and drive the economy into recession rather than seek the reforms that would improve our productivity, then the scenario is inevitable. Big business may lick its wounds with smaller profits, but small business simply struggles and goes out of business.

The evidence is well and truly before us, contrary to what Senators McMullan and Maguire have said. Senator McMullan said, and I wrote it down, `Things have not changed at all over the last five years'. Bully for him. Only last month we learned that bankruptcies had risen by 50 per cent since 1984-85, with a 27 per cent rise in the last quarter.

This is an indication that as many as 10,000 small businesses were in serious trouble. But this Labor Government, through this debate today, is telling us that nothing is wrong; all is well. The bankruptcy statistics for the March quarter show another 2,142 Australians were declared bankrupt. That is a rise of 27 per cent by contrast with the same period in 1989. There is no better indicator of a troubled small business sector.

In Western Australia, my home State, 296 bankruptcies represent a 74 per cent increase on 1989. Most of these, I might add, do not simply reflect the misfortunes of an individual; they mean that many employees are simply out of work and other small enterprises are left with bad debts. For each small business that formally goes bankrupt, another five close down voluntarily before they go all the way down that same path. Therefore, in Western Australia we are looking at the disappearance of 1,500 small businesses in the first quarter of this year. The outlook for many of the other 70,000 small enterprises in that State is not promising either.

An article in the West Australian on 18 May reported that in the smart, refurbished Piccadilly Arcade in the heart of Perth-right in the central business district-there were four empty shops. That is just in once arcade. One of the shops bore the notice, `We've had enough after six years. Thanks Bob and you too, Paul'. I believe that really sums it up. There was a small business that was able to survive for six years-therefore, it could not just have been badly managed or inadequately based-but thanks to this Government it has gone out of business. At the same time 100 jobs have been lost through the closure of the Bi-Best discount department stores-the larger end of small business.

Next Saturday there are two by-elections in Perth, in the electorates of the ex-Premier and the ex-Deputy Premier who have been forced, by their own Party, to nick off. We see the pork-barrelling of the world going on over there by the new Premier, Dr Lawrence. But small businesses over there are being hit for six by that Government, too. They have high land taxes, water and council rates and, I think, the highest electricity charges of any State. This, combined with the problems created by this Federal Government, leads one to ask what have those people in Fremantle and Maylands got to look forward to if they vote for the Labor Party on Saturday?

The Treasurer (Mr Keating) merely tells us how well his policy is working. On the Sunday show on 8 April he stated that he thought the banks would bring business rates down to about 18 per cent or even better. What a cynical joke! A survey by the Small Business Letter showed that not one respondent paid less than 20.2 per cent plus surcharges. We can see how closely our aspiring next Prime Minister understands the real world of small business, because the only small business he has been involved in-which might not be so small-is buying antique clocks.

A Mr White in Sydney calculated that, on top of his 24 3/4 per cent interest rate, he was paying an extra 5 per cent in government and bank charges. With an effective 30 per cent interest rate, he decided to close down his 35-year-old suburban retail outlet. Many other businessmen around Australia are reaching similar conclusions and taking similar action. It is not only those in small business and their employees who are affected. Taxpayers also feel the effect as all these people go out of business.

I agree with my colleague Senator Olsen who said that quite clearly this Government does not consider this issue to be urgent. I would go so far as to say that I do not think it even thinks it is an issue because it has treated it with absolute contempt today. Not to understand the impact upon small business under the Hawke Labor Government of the real cost of business borrowing rising from an effective 4 per cent in 1982-83 to 15 per cent in 1988-89 is nothing short of a disgrace.

The impact of these high interest rates upon the housing sector is a fairly familiar story, as Senator Olsen has already touched on. It is not only those who cannot afford houses but also the small businesses associated with the building industry that are suffering. In Western Australia their position has not been helped by a 50 per cent drop in housing starts in the December quarter, a halving of the market for $40,000 homes in the March quarter, and new dwellings overall 30 per cent below last year's figures.

Interest rates are not the only burden that the Hawke Labor Government has foisted upon small business. Nominal wage growth and lack of productivity growth under the Australian Council of Trade Unions accord means that staff become too expensive to employ. Yet 10 minutes ago Senator Maguire stood up in here and told us how fantastic the accord had been.

TALK.START.PARA: —He should have spoken to Senator Walsh.

—Yes, it is a shame he did not speak to Senator Walsh about that. He would have put Senator Maguire straight. The accord has not served small business well and it has made sure that many small businesses will simply go bust. If that is the Government's ultimate goal, why does it not come clean and tell small business? It should not let them just drift on getting into a worse and worse state and going bankrupt. There is no point in Senator Maguire shaking his head. The statistics in Western Australia show quite clearly that there has been a 74 per cent increase. I notice that Senator Maguire very judiciously did not touch on the Western Australian figures in his speech. They also show a 27 per cent increase nationally.

SPEECH.PARA: The lack of micro-economic reform is felt by those efficient small businesses engaged in export or importing, since our ports are only 50 per cent as competitive as European ports and 40 per cent as competitive as those of Asia. We now have a Minister for Small Business and Customs (Mr Beddall) who admits that `people are feeling the pinch and that is very worrying'. Those are his words, not mine. He expressed the objective to `get government off the back of small business'. Is this not a fine sentiment after the election? thanks to his Government, small business is just another arm of the Australian Taxation Office. It is forced to undertake half its work and is severely penalised if it falters in any way.

The Minister says that we have to `get government off the back of small business'. This is the Minister who also started saying that maybe capital gains tax should be able to be rolled over: `When one business is sold, buy another one'. Yet prior to the election campaign this Government categorically and unequivocally denied our claim that nearly half the businesses that were liable for capital gains tax had incomes below $40,000. It categorically denied that. Now, after the election, it says that maybe there is a need to look at the problem with capital gains tax. Of course there is a problem with capital gains tax.
It is notable that during the recent election campaign the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) told the Small Business Letter that the then Minister, Mr Barry Jones:
. . . made it clear that Governments at all levels need to get off the backs of small business.

Such a view did not stop him getting the sack soon after, I might add-Barry Jones was easily expendable. All we may get therefore are junior Ministers, such as Mr Beddall, mouthing pro-business sentiment while the Hawke-Keating Labor Government goes its own merry way and more and more people go into bankruptcy. The Minister is starting to believe that some of the issues may need to be looked at. It will be interesting to see whether Prime Minister Hawke, and the soon to be Prime Minister Keating, will actually act upon some of these recommendations.

A survey conducted earlier this year by the Australian Small Business Association showed complete unanimity among 2,000 respondents to the proposition that assets held for more than five years should not be taxed. This is the view of the coalition, but it is rejected by the Hawke Labor Government. Small business knows that it pays too much and has devoted too much valuable time to compliance with government regulation in the taxation field.

TALK.START.PARA: —You have lost three elections on capital gains tax.

—The issue is quite clear on this one. Senator Maguire's Government did not tell the truth prior to the election. There is no point in saying that the people of Australia believe that the capital gains tax is equitable because the Government told the people of Australia that that was the case and they were foolish enough to believe it. Yet the small businessman knows it not to be correct.

SPEECH.PARA: Today we have had before us sales tax legislation which will probably put some smaller vehicle importers out of business. We have the proposed training guarantee that is nothing more than another tax on businesses with payrolls greater than $200,000. And we are yet to see the reappearance of last year's Privacy Amendment Bill that strengthened the hand of delinquent debtors against small businesses. This is part of the total climate created by this Labor Government that is destructive of the enterprise ethic and that pays only lip service to the contribution that small business makes to Australia. I hope that the last speaker for the Government, Senator Cooney, will give some encouragement to the small businesses of this country which are actually going broke at an unprecedented rate and cannot afford to continue to do so.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has been said by all speakers in this debate, I think, that there are 750,000 small business people in Australia and many of them are feeling the strain. In so far as there is good news it is that most of them will continue to carry on small businesses not just for their own benefit but for that of the country. I wish to congratulate the very many small business people who carry on their businesses efficiently and well, as I say, to the benefit of themselves, Australia, and the world as a whole.

SPEECH.PARA: Most small business people do well. There are those who do not and there are those who are going bankrupt, and to those people we must have nothing but sympathy. All honourable senators have made that point, including Senator Boswell with his usual great style, Senator Olsen, and Senator Knowles in her very forthright manner. Indeed, the Government understands that. We have been accused of ignoring the plight of small business people. That is not so at all. The report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology-the Beddall report-is an indication of that. The things done under that report are indications that the Government has not forgotten the small business person, the person who, as Senator Knowles quite properly says, has to bear the burden of on costs such as insurance-whether workers compensation insurance or otherwise-payroll tax, the renewal of equipment, and so on. We on this side thoroughly understand that it is hard for people with those oncosts and high interest rates. In so far as that is a point that has been made on the other side, we agree with it.

I am not sure whether this matter of urgency will go to the vote or not. Whether or not it does, the reality as to who has the better of this argument was proved on 24 March. The sorts of things that have been pointed out by the Opposition and the arguments that have been put forward so eloquently on our side by Senator McMullan and Senator Maguire, have been ruled upon by the people of Australia. The interesting thing is that the matters urged by Senator Knowles, Senator Olsen and Senator Boswell have been ruled upon not by the Government but by the people of Australia, who have voted to give this Party, this Government, another three years in office.

The situation that now exists with regard to small business is little different from the situation that existed on 24 March. The people of Australia have said that this Government is the appropriate one to look after not only small business but the economy as a whole. I assure any small businessman, businesswoman or business company that may be listening to this debate that the Government is very conscious of its responsibility to that particular sector and will be moving to do several things which I will come back to.

It has been said, or at least implied, that there has been a lessening of demand. That is quite correct. There has been a lessening of demand because unfortunately that has been made, by necessity, a central part of the Government's policy. The demand in Australia has been too great. That has sucked in imports from overseas. That has put us in a situation where we owe too much to people overseas and has brought about the necessity for us as a nation to consume less. That is a scenario that was accepted by the Australian people on 24 March. They understand that we have had to do this, but we do not do it, Madam Acting Deputy President, through any joy--

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Cooney, I am not Madam Acting anything.

—Madam Acting Deputy President has just gone out of the chair. May I address her as she disappears out the door. Mr Acting Deputy President, as you come into the Chair, may I welcome you because, always, you grace the chamber. I apologise for not noticing the aura that you brought into the chamber.

SPEECH.PARA: I have mentioned the things that this Government has already moved to do regarding its promises in the short time it has been in office since 24 March. There was, of course, the Beddall report. I agree with those on the other side who welcomed that report. I wish to quickly go through what this Government has done and what it proposes to do. There will be regular meetings between Mr Beddall, the Minister appointed specifically for small business, and his counterparts in State governments to promote coordination in the manner in which governments deal with small businesses. One of the great objections that small businesses have had to the way government in general has operated is that there are, as a result of Federation, a variety of authorities, not coordinated, which impinge upon business in a bad way, whether small or large. It is therefore a matter of great moment that governments should get together to coordinate their approach to small business. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has also promised an annual report to Parliament on Government policy as it affects small business.

TALK.START.PARA: —That will be handy!

—As Senator Boswell so generously said-and I thank him for that-that will be handy. It will certainly be handy that there will be an annual report which will indicate what has happened to small business, which will show what the Government has done for small business and which will allow this House, as well as the House of Representatives, to have an opportunity to debate the issues that surround small business.

SPEECH.PARA: The Treasurer (Mr Keating) has announced an inquiry into the complexity of the taxation system, again a matter of great moment. An ability therefore exists to make the taxation system more understandable and hopefully more simple. There will be a consultative group consisting of relevant business and professional groups to report on its responses to the tax recommendations in the Beddall report. In other words, the report that David Beddall has produced has been made available to those interested, specifically to small businesses, to discuss and give a response to. Again, that is something that has been done by this Government.

Under this Government there has been a reduction of the rate of tax that companies have to pay. It has been reduced to 39 per cent, taken down from a high of 60 per cent in the last decade. As a pilot program for 1989-90, mobile information vans telling businesses about this reduction will be taken into rural and isolated communities with small business being a significant target area. Not only is small business in the cities and in the major country towns looked at but small business in rural areas will also be looked at. From 1 July 1990 self-employed persons and unsupported employees will be able to claim tax deductions in full for contributions up to $3,000-this is in terms of occupational superannuation-and for 75 per cent of the excess of contributions over $3,000. This Government has set up a program whereby people in small businesses can make provision for their retirement.

These are simply a few of the things I have read out from a list that has been given to me from Mr Beddall's office. It is a summary which covers over four pages. If I went on I could point to many other issues which have been embraced by this Government, specifically by David Beddall's office and by the Minister himself, and which specifically go towards helping small business.

When the Opposition, as it has today, properly puts forward its case, and does so with great style and great gusto, it is usually raising issues which this Government has specifically put up and has answered. In a certain sense it is not to the point to say that there has been an increase in bankruptcies. Of course, there has been an increase in bankruptcies. Is that bad? Of course it is bad. It must be bad for anyone to go bankrupt. For a person who has built up a business, say a small corner store, a cabinetmaker's business, a plumbing business or, with great respect to Senator Knowles, a solicitor's business or a doctor's business, for a person who has spent time and effort building up a business and then for a variety of reasons finds that that business has to go into bankruptcy, it is a tragedy. It is a tragedy which this Government understands and which this Government is going to do something about. It is a tragedy which clearly is understood by those on the other side. But to understand the tragedy is not to meet the point.

The real point is: What is the answer to that problem? I have gone through and illustrated what this Government has done. All the Opposition has done-and I think it does it with a great deal of sincerity; those on the other side are always sincere when they prepare these matters of public importance-is say that interest rates are too high. They are very high. I agree. Those opposite say the economy is not as good as it should be. I agree.

TALK.START.PARA: —What are you going to do about it?

—Senator Boswell asks what we are going to do about it. I have said what we are going to do about it. First of all, we are going to press down on demand-and this is a severe medicine but it is medicine and it has to be taken. People have voted with the understanding that this is what has to be done. Demand has to be suppressed because we are sucking in too much from overseas. We must turn the economy around to produce goods here which we can sell overseas. And that is what is happening. Business investment has risen in real terms by an average of 10.8 per cent per annum over the past five years and 92 per cent of the 1.6 million new jobs created have been in the private sector.

SPEECH.PARA: All I am saying is that, given all these difficulties, the answers that the Government is giving are much more pertinent, direct and efficacious than those suggested by the Opposition.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why are you granting wage rises?

—The great test as to whether what I say is correct is the results of the last election where this Government won on the policies it put forward. Unfortunately for the people on the other side, they will have to spend another three years in opposition. Just to give them some hope, the Australian Financial Review of Wednesday, 16 May states:

SPEECH.PARA: No recession, but Accord will keep rates high. . .

This is a report from the University of Melbourne Institute of Applied Economic and Social Research which I have no doubt honourable senators opposite will accept. Here a very responsible economic adviser criticises the Government in some respects but in other respects simply says that there is no recession. When honourable senators opposite come in here and raise the points that they legitimately raise they should not overplay their hand; they should not go in for the hyperbole. They may point out the problems that are being faced, that there is bankruptcy, but should not go to the extent that they have gone to today of saying that things are in recession or that things are absolutely hopeless.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I raised this matter of urgency today because I hoped that the Government would throw some light on what policies it would enunciate to help small business but I am afraid to say that that hope has been dashed. We have just listened to Senator Cooney telling us that everything is all right. I challenge Senator Cooney tomorrow in the lunch adjournment to go down to the shopping centre with me; we can walk through that shopping centre and if he can find anyone who says, `Business is good. We are booming. We are making money. We are happy with the interest rates. We are delighted the Government put a capital gains tax on us and delighted we have the fringe benefits tax' I will be very surprised and I will get up and make a public apology to the Australian Labor Party and the Government in this chamber.
—Shout him lunch.

—Senator Bjelke-Petersen says I should shout him lunch, and I would be prepared to forgo the loss on the fringe benefits tax. I say to Senator Cooney to look at any headlines he cares to look at: `Banks warn worse ahead', `Retailers feel the pinch as economy slows', `New method needed to rescue companies', `10,000 companies have gone to the wall since Christmas'. We can go through headline after headline. We will find that there is a recession; there is no way out of it. The figures indicate that 10,000 small businesses are going broke annually, and that rate is increasing.

SPEECH.PARA: But all we have heard from Senator Cooney and the other Government speakers is that everything is all right, there are no problems, and all we have to do is hang on. That is not what I expected to hear. It is certainly not what the small business people want to hear. They want to hear what the Government is going to do about interest rates, on-costs, superannuation payments, training levies, 38-hour weeks and accords. Those avenues were not addressed.

The main issues of this debate were not picked up. Senator Cooney said, `The way we will fix this is by the Prime Minister putting down an annual report in Parliament'. I can assure Senator Cooney that that would be absolutely no good at all. Miles and miles of paper are coming across our desks here now. What we want to see, and what the people who are going broke in record numbers want to see, is some action.

Not Senator McMullan, Senator Cooney or the other Government speakers have taken any time to point out how the Government is going to help small business. The Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) has said that he is going to reduce demand. Senator Cooney has said that the Government is going to reduce demand. But all it is doing is reducing business.

When those opposite face up to it, what is going wrong in this country is that we are not producing anything. The on-costs that the Government is putting on business are driving businesses into the ground. The Government is closing factory after factory and reducing our capacity to manufacture. Last year 31,000 jobs were lost in our manufacturing sector. We have a $2 billion trade deficit every month. Every month this country is going broke at the rate of $2 billion because we have no capacity to manufacture, we have no capacity to get productivity up and we are going bankrupt at the rate of $2 billion a month. But Senator Cooney tells us that the Prime Minister will put down an annual report in Parliament.

That is not going to work. Senator Cooney has shown today that none of the three Government speakers has a clue how bad the situation is. They do not understand small business, the engine room of the Australian economy, and they do not know what they can do to help. They do not even understand the problem. It has been an exercise in absolute futility to try to explain the Government's position because it has no position. It does not understand the need to protect those 10,000 people who are going broke annually. I am very disappointed in the contribution that the Government made because it had no answers whatsoever for small business.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: NATIONAL HEALTH AND MEDICAL RESEARCH COUNCIL

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

I seek to draw the Senate's attention to several aspects of the report of the 108th session of the National Health and Medical Research Council (NHMRC). On other occasions we have drawn attention to the inadequacy of the NHMRC structure to deal with a number of quite important matters. It is a structure which has grown like Topsy over the years. Many of the committees are composed of part time people who have other quite arduous duties in relation to university teaching, lecturing and research work. The considerations by the NHMRC committees of a number of important matters are then very often dealt with in a delayed fashion and the independent research capacity of the NHMRC is also inadequate to deal with many of these questions. I draw attention to several matters in this report. On page 9 we find that toxicological work is going on in relation to the origin of high organochlorin levels in breast milk.

The extremely high levels of some of these pesticides in human breast milk was drawn to the attention of the public in Western Australia in the early 1970s. It was pointed out then that human breast milk in Western Australia would not be admitted to the market if it were cow's milk because of its excessive levels of organochlorin pesticides. Yet we find that in 1990, some 18 years-if my memory serves my correctly-after that was first drawn to the public's attention, the NHMRC is beginning an investigation into this subject.

The uptake of organochlorin pesticides from residential and occupational exposures is, again, a matter which has been in the public domain for quite a long time and one which quite clearly should have been taken up before now. I am not reflecting on the competence or the integrity of the NHMRC, but rather on the inadequacy of the total structure to more quickly and expeditiously pick up these matters and deal with them.

Page 10 of the report deals with the training of pest control operators. In 1986 I was a member of a South Australian Government committee looking at a massive contamination of the Streaky Bay High School with aldrin-dieldrin. For a time it looked as though it might be cheaper to totally demolish the school and rebuild it. This situation was due to the inadequacy of the schedule which set out how pest control operators should behave, and also the inadequacy of the training of that particular pest control operator. The system was so loose that despite the massive cost no action could be taken against the pest control operator in that instance.

Page 11 draws attention to the limited data available in Australia on dioxins in paper. This underscores the inadequacy of the ability of the NHMRC to independently research these matters, and therefore that it is dependent-overly dependent in my view-on information which comes in from overseas. We should have a great deal more independent local research effort which can advise the NHMRC and others in these matters.

Finally, I am reflecting on the integrity of the NHMRC when I draw attention to page 30 of the report which deals with the effectiveness of water fluoridation. It mentions that the NHMRC has a committee inquiring into a number of matters raised by, among others, Drs Diesendorf, Sutton and Colquhoun. In an article in Nature Dr Diesendorf drew attention to the inadequacy of the data on which proof of the effectiveness of water fluoridation was established. Nonetheless, this report goes on and says:
Meanwhile Council affirmed its earlier recommendations that fluoridation of community water supplies was--

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also rise to speak to the report of the 108th session of the National Health and Medical Research Council. We learn on the first page of this report that the National Health and Medical Research Council was constituted way back in 1936, and that the functions of the Council include reporting to the Commonwealth, the States, the Territories and to the Australian community on matters relating to the improvement of health, the prevention of disease and ethical issues in relation to health.

SPEECH.PARA: With reference to those expressed functions, if one turns to page 17 one sees that there is a section headed `Disease prevention and control'. I cannot see under this section, or anywhere else in the report, a segment on iatrogenic diseases. I believe that there is an urgent need for research into this area in Australia. There also appears not to be a lot of overseas research. The Parliamentary Library was unable to come up with many references when a request was made by me last year. The research that I, and others in my office, have done in the epidural use of depo-medrol has suggested a very large problem in that area. In fact, that research has led us down a number of paths and it seems that the use of depo-medrol epidurally is possibly only one in a number of problem areas.
I draw to the Senate's attention an article in today's Perth's Daily News under the heading `Victims to Sue over Pain Drug'. The article states:
Forty West Australians have launched a legal bid for compensation from WA doctors for injuries allegedly caused by treatment with the controversial drug Depo-Medrol.
Members of the WA Depo-Medrol Epidural Action Group are taking action both individually and as a group to stop others from being injured by the drug. The article continues:
The Depo-Medrol Epidural Action Group claims hundreds of West Australians have been left virtual invalids after undergoing spinal injections of Depo-Medrol for back pain.
The WA Health Department is drafting a set of guidelines for the appropriate use of Depo-Medrol.

I would like to commend the Western Australian Health Department for taking that action. However, I have some reservations as far as that is concerned. It seems to me that it is not a defensible proposition that a form of therapy which the Australian Drug Evaluation Committee (ADEC) has refused to register should be in any way supported, defended or regulated by any State health department. If a health department were to do so it should require medical practitioners to inform patients that depo-medrol is the substance proposed to be used because one of the problems that arose was that patients were simply not told what drug was to be used.

The health department should also require practitioners to make it clear to patients that the drug manufacturer applied to the Australian Drug Evaluation Committee to have depo-medrol approved for administration by the epidural route and that the application was rejected because the ADEC considered that efficacy was not substantiated and that the procedure was risky. The health department should also require practitioners to make it clear to patients that the notes supplied with depo-medrol by the manufacturer, Upjohn Pty Ltd, make it very clear that epidural administration is not supported by the manufacturer and that the pharmaceutical products guide specifically advises against epidural administration.

There are a number of sections in this report which make it absolutely clear that patients and people who require treatment by a hospital or doctor should take a lot of responsibility for their own actions. Only yesterday there was a report in a newspaper that almost a third of asthma deaths in Australia could be prevented if patients sought help more quickly. It is a tragic situation when if people sought the proper help at the right time--

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

I welcome this report of the Inter-State Commission entitled Road Use Charges and Vehicle Registration: A National Scheme and, in particular, I am pleased to see that this issue is being addressed seriously. The report indicates on page 228 that the impact of recommended changes that will be brought about by the adoption of the report would be such that for all vehicles, other than the heaviest rigid trucks and trailers, all road use costs would be recovered through fuel charges. Such a suggestion I welcome indeed.
Inter-State Commission

The report generally heads in a direction which could redress some of the anomalies which we can see at the moment in our present road funding practices. I am pleased to see that the report tackles the issue of registration fees. The name `registration fees' is a misnomer. As the system exists now that fee is paid at a State level. Such a fee is used for a variety of purposes associated with transport. Probably in most instances only a twentieth of the fee is actually used for registration. At present it is a fixed charge and does not reflect any of the variables which should be considered.

The two most important variables which should be taken into account when placing fees or charges on a vehicle would be the vehicle's mass and the amount of use it makes of the community's roads. This report at least enters into that debate and considers some of the variables.

Those two variables, the mass of the vehicle and its use of the community's roads, are the variables which determine the contribution of that vehicle to the wear and tear on our roads and they should be put to work to determine the level of the contribution that vehicle will make towards construction and maintenance of our roads. We could use weigh bridges, tollgates, roving test crews, locked odometers and all sorts of devices to arrive at a just charge, but as this report suggests, an efficient and equitable charge could be applied through fuel levies.

I believe it is important to remove fixed charges such as the so-called registration fees for several reasons. Firstly, high registration fees are an incentive to make use of what has been paid for. In my case, the car registration is in fact about 20 per cent of the market value of my vehicle. Having paid that, it is wasteful of me to leave the vehicle sitting in the driveway, so I get out and use it. A low registration fee and a high fuel tax should encourage more people to use public transport. A low registration fee would also encourage owners of older vehicles to keep them on the road for a few more years. We should not overlook the effect of this measure. Even a superficial understanding of the motor trade would allow the conclusion that vehicle repair and maintenance is a labour intensive activity. We should take into account the fact that employment can be generated by encouraging people to keep vehicles on the road for longer. This report could go a little further in looking at some of the fuel charges. I think, for example, that the present tax zones that we use for income tax could be manipulated in some way to determine a differential in the fuel taxes paid by different people in different zones in the country.

The report in general gives us a clue to some of the directions that we could follow in bringing to resolution some of the anomalies that are at present in our road funding arrangements. I was entertained by the report and I hope that a considerable number of its recommendations and findings are adopted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Obviously Senator Bell has a lot to learn in politics. It is obvious that he can pay a taxi fare from one end of his electorate to another because of the implications that would arise as a result of the report of the Inter-State Commission, Road Use Charges and Vehicle Registration: A National Scheme, in a place like Tasmania. I would challenge Senator Bell, as an Australian Democrat, to take a much wider vision than the small patch that he represents in Tasmania and come to some of the more remote, regional and distant parts of Australia and look at the effects of many of the recommendations of this report on people who live in areas where they cannot catch a taxi from one side of town to another when they have to do something.

SPEECH.PARA: There are many ways in which some of the recommendations of this report will impinge very seriously on Australians who live away from the major capital cities or the south-east corner of the nation or in fact in Tasmania. I flag many points in this report that need to be addressed very seriously and carefully. If honourable senators take the time to look at the tabling statement by the Minister for Land Transport, the Hon. Bob Brown, in the House of Representatives, they will see that there are a number of issues on which he has clearly set out the objectives that `we will be observing'-I presume that is the Hawke Labor Government-and the principles that will be adopted.
The Minister in his statement goes into quite a lot of the principles that he has already set down. Let me just highlight one of them:

. . . our initial approach will be to seek a cooperative basis for reform with the States, but we will make strategic use of Federal powers, which are considerable, where this process does not yield a satisfactory rate or level of change.

That is one of the keynote principles of the Labor Government. It is obviously going to wave the big stick under the eyes of the governments that are scattered throughout Australia that must cope with this particular area.

I highlight, for example, a problem that could arise. It came out in the Estimates Committee hearing the other night when I questioned an officer from the Department of Transport and Communications about whether that Department had in fact recommended the mass distance charge for heavy trucks and trailers travelling long distances. The Department accepted that it had made that form of recommendation. That in turn would produce remarkable additional costs on freight charges in remote parts of Australia. For semitrailers, registration is likely to rise from approximately $900 per annum to $16,000 per annum. What implications of that will be passed on to the consumers living in remote and regional parts of Australia? It is all right for Senator Bell, who has only to pay a taxi fare to get from one suburb of Launceston to another, to expect that charges will not be picked up.

This report canvasses a lot of economic and social debate and argument, just as it should do, but it must be read in the context of the way in which the Labor Government is disadvantaging people who live away from the major capital cities and the major parts of Australia. There are many aspects of this report that need careful consideration by all of the large States and by the Northern Territory. If it is just picked up using the principles outlined by Minister Brown, we will see a large number of Australians, who are not in any way represented in this place by the Australian Democrats, vastly disadvantaged.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was not going to speak to the Inter-State Commission report, Road Use Charges and Vehicles Registration: A National Scheme, but Senator Tambling indicated such conservatism in his remarks and his protection of the status quo that I think further remarks need to be made.

SPEECH.PARA: The proposal, of course, is not in any way new. I point out to the Senate that I was the Australian Conservation Foundation's representative to the National Economic Summit which Mr Hawke called in 1983 shortly after he was elected. If honourable senators want to go back to the reports of the National Economic Summit, they will find in volume three four chapters which I wrote. One of those chapters canvasses precisely the recommendation from the Inter-State Commission which is now before us.

Indeed, I took the proposal somewhat further and addressed some of the problems that were raised by Senator Tambling. My suggestion was that the Government essentially abolish, apart from a nominal charge, registration of vehicles. I also suggested that the majority of third party insurance cover be abolished so that the cost of vehicle ownership would be very small, but that the fuel price be doubled. I suggested that approximately half of that increase in revenue go to pay registration charges and third party insurance costs, but that the other half go to subsidise the purchase of fuel efficient vehicles. That would be on a sliding scale depending upon fuel efficiency.

Senator Tambling does not seem to realise that many of the costs that he talks about are already being borne, but not by those who are incurring those costs. They are being spread on to the rest of the community. We will shortly have to import billions of dollars worth of fuel because our indigenous reserves are running out. It is clear that we need to increase substantially the efficiency of the whole transport system in Australia. We are the third most serious greenhouse polluter in the world on a per capita basis. That is a problem that needs to be addressed and, indeed, we are currently looking at a way of reducing greenhouse emissions by 20 per cent by the year 2005.

A major contributor to greenhouse emissions is the amount of fossil fuel that is burnt in motor vehicles. One way in which we can substantially address the problem raised by Senator Tambling, and which I mentioned in my paper, is that part of the extra revenue that is raised as a fuel tax would go to establishing regional distilleries so that farmers who grow a whole variety of crops could produce alcohol, locally, which could be used in vehicles. If the price of fuel was doubled, the price of power alcohol would be roughly equivalent to the price of fossil fuel. That would make farmers independent of outside sources and not subject to the vicissitudes of the withdrawal of labour in oil refineries by tanker drivers and so on. It would also provide local industrial expansion and employment in regional centres and would exactly address the problem of greenhouse emissions, because by fermenting crops to alcohol and then burning the alcohol, one is simply cycling carbon dioxide through that system and not adding to the total greenhouse gas emissions.

It also addresses the problem of the increase in the imports of fossil fuels which this country will increasingly face during the next decade. I think there is considerable merit in the proposal which is before us. It needs to be expanded rather than contracted and I think the problems raised by Senator Tambling can be addressed through those mechanisms.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to spend a few minutes on the report of the Inter-State Commission. I will discuss the mass and distance aspects relating to vehicles, as mentioned in the report. Although I welcome the idea of dropping the registration fee and adding the amount to the fuel levy to be put back into roads, I am concerned that what has already happened to levies raised in Australia for use on roads would happen again. The idea of imposing a fee on trailers also concerns me because a lot of trailers are already licensed and if a person owns only one prime mover and two or three trailers, that owner can get a reduction for the second and third trailer. Unless one has a road train licence, of course, one can pull only one trailer.

SPEECH.PARA: But this report seems to get away from that aspect. The proposal for a fee to be imposed on trailers was to appease the subcontractors who own prime movers, and pull the big transporters' trailers around the country. This report came out to hit the main contractors rather than the subcontractors. That idea is all right providing that a person can get full use out of his or her trailer. If a person has a trailer licence, costing $16,000 for the year, and only uses the trailer for part of the year, as farmers do, then the idea is certainly not going to work. I welcome some other aspects of the report, but it certainly has a long way to go concerning this matter.

Senator Coulter mentioned fuel efficient vehicles and the fact that operators should be encouraged to buy and use fuel efficient vehicles. As one who is experienced in contracting in road transport, I can assure Senator Coulter that the present cost of fuel in Australia makes a contractor go for the most fuel efficient vehicles that he can get hold of and also the most fuel efficient drivers who drive according to the road conditions and the load being carried, and who therefore use the minimum amount of fuel.

I now come to Senator Coulter's idea of production of power alcohol. This idea was pretty popular in the surplus wheat years from 1969 to about 1976. Our family business looked at the idea of manufacturing our own fuel and we simply worked out that for the plants available at that time to manufacture power alcohol, we would have to keep them going for two shifts a day, 365 days a year, in order to produce enough fuel to meet our needs. Then at the end of the process, the cost was not very different from that of fuel that could be bought. So we discarded that idea. I believe that this report has merit. There is a lot to learn from it, but I also have a lot of reservations about it. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The report outlines:

SPEECH.PARA: The number of design faults and defects in the New Parliament House not only continues to be a source of inconvenience to the occupants of the building but some are causing operational inefficiencies which add to the servicing costs of the building. Resolving many of these problems appear to be cumbersome and time consuming involving numerous consultations between the Joint House Department, the Parliament House Construction Authority and the original contractors. It is hoped these faults will not become a permanent feature of the building.
I read out that element of the report because I wanted to stress that it tends to underline some of the points I have been raising for quite some time in this chamber, with varying levels of support.

I want to deal with some problems about the way these matters were dealt with in the Senate Estimates Committee because there is now, no doubt, a massive list of mistakes or errors or problems that have emerged out of building design faults. It does appear that these estimates are the appropriate ones under which to deal with those matters, even though under Estimates Committee D, I think it is, the Parliament House Construction Authority will come up for discussion.
