However, the answers from the Parliament House Construction Authority have come back via Estimates Committee A, and that is why I intend to deal with them now.

There is no doubt that whenever one has a major building one has a series of problems. I am concerned that so many design faults seem to have emerged-apart from the architect reinventing the wheel in so many areas, for example the door handles, which have been specially designed to catch coats, tear trouser pockets, and do as much damage to people's hips as possible. Apart from things like that, one has to look only at the carpets upstairs; the number of marble tiles that have had to be chipped out; the water leaks; the nonsense involving the blinds; the chaos in the kitchens; the moth-eaten textile walls in the other chamber; the air-conditioning breakdowns; the pools of water that gather on floors which are, for some quaint reason, set dead level rather than having any run off towards drains in wet areas; the louvres outside and the curtains inside the members and guests dining room; the acoustics in this chamber and in the committee rooms; the need to spend $680,000 to make the members and members and guests dining rooms habitable and useable. The list seems to go on and on.

We did get some interesting answers in Senate Estimates on some of these matters, but the problem is that most of the defects liability with the Parliament House Construction Authority has either expired or is soon to expire, and the Parliament House Construction Authority itself is set to expire on 30 September. The sort of thing that bothers me is that problems that clearly emerged a long time ago when these product liability situations were alive are only just now coming up for action. For example, there is the farce with the blinds. I remind the Committee that when we first moved into this building back in August 1988, many of the rooms, particularly those on the western side where the sun comes in, did not have blinds at all, and there was a great rush to get the blinds installed. I am grateful for whoever it was who thought it would be a good idea to shut me up by getting me a set of blinds pretty early in that process.

What interests me is that in Senate Estimates the Joint House Department revealed that it first advised the Parliament House Construction Authority in about August 1988 that it believed the mech- anisms were inadequate and would fail in service. It has been progressively following up that matter with the new Parliament House Construction Authority. That is almost two years ago. Here we are now, close to running out of our defects liability. I suppose it is reasonable for us to wonder why it has taken so long. I can understand the problems Joint House has in establishing whether it was the architect or the supplying company or who it was that was in trouble, but it is clear that the mechanisms were inadequate.

As a result of that inadequacy, a lot of the blinds do not work and the mechanisms are being replaced at a very substantial cost, as I recall. It is a performance contract and it is up to the supplier to provide adequacy for service. The only problem is that labour costs will be about $120,000 for fixing up the blinds problem by providing mechanisms that actually work, rather than the light plastic mechanisms that certainly were not designed to carry wooden slats, which the timber venetians are made of.
We have received this reply from the Parliament House Construction Authority:

The timber venetian blinds are not, in the Authority's view, fit for purpose or adequate to fulfil the expectations of either the Agreement with the designers or the Contract with the blind manufacturer.
Remedy is being followed by PHCA through both avenues.

Independent and parallel actions to establish a more serviceable option that can be taken up to correct these blinds are also being pursued so that these are ready to proceed as soon as the contractual matters have been resolved.

There are approximately 1875 blinds to be corrected and work will need to be done progressively to allow recovery of reuseable components, rebuilding and reinstallation with minimum disruption to the building occupants.

This work will continue beyond the closure date of PHCA. The Authority will therefore organise the repair program, provide adequate funding and appoint agents to complete its responsibilities for this work.

We really have to ask why the Parliament House Construction did not come to the view two years ago, when it was first pointed out by the Joint House Department that the blinds were inadequate, that they would not and, in fact, have not worked? It seems to me that wishfully hoping that maybe the problem will go away is simply not good enough. I wonder to what extent the Parliament, the Joint House Department and the Australian taxpayer will be disadvantaged because of the delay. I simply hope that full remedy will be available. I seek an assurance that the delays have not meant that full and total recovery of any expenses faced by the Joint House Department will not be made. I want to make certain that the delay has not diminished in any way our prospects of making that recovery.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Michael Baume raised a number of problems with design faults and defects in the new Parliament House. I think he has been more critical of the Parliament House Construction Authority than of the Joint House Department. I have been advised that the Joint House Department is doing everything possible. It is pursuing its full legal entitlement and, hopefully, will arrive at a satisfactory solution to the problem.

—Another matter raised relates to the lamp starters which are a factor in the lights in this chamber and in other places not working properly. The Parliament House Construction Authority's response is that the Joint House Department has been offered $10,000 to buy replacement starters of its choice which can be progressively installed in conjunction with its normal relamping program. As I understand it, the failure rate and the inadequacy of the lamps has been appalling. The Authority, in its response to me, has said that it is awaiting a response to this proposal. I am wondering whether Joint House Department believes that $10,000 is adequate to resolve this problem and whether it will be accepting that proposal.
—I have been advised that the Joint House Department thinks that the figure is closer to $50,000 or $60,000, including the labour. That is the figure that the Department will continue to pursue.

—Presumably there will be some time pressure in dealing with this matter, as the Parliament House Construction Authority will depart this world in September this year. What will happen if the Construction Authority believes that $10,000 is enough to see this problem out and refuses to do any more? Will this be another example where design faults effectively, at least to some extent, will be carried by the taxpayer? On that issue and the timber venetian blinds issue I want to be assured that there will be no burden on the taxpayer through the appropriations to the Joint House Department. As I recall, these blinds are worth about $1m. It would be nice if they worked, but if it did not cost the taxpayer more to make them work.

—I have been advised that the Parliament House Construction Authority will be able to carry on litigation after it has gone out of existence. If Senator Michael Baume would like to put the matter of the legal situation on notice, I am sure I will be able to provide a more detailed answer to him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, I am concerned that many of the questions that I asked during the Senate Estimates Committee A hearing were not answered by the Parliament House Construction Authority (PHCA), through the Joint House Department. I asked whether we could have an estimate of the ultimate charge to the public for the failed mechanisms overall. I have just had an undertaking from Senator Sibraa that he would seek a view about whether the Joint House Department would have to pay. As I recall, I asked whether the total cost of this sort of thing would be different from the amount the Joint House Department would have to pay-is there a total cost involved? I also asked about the cost of designing and equipping the main kitchen which is now to be closed. As I understand it, the Parliament House Construction Authority says that it is a bit too hard to find out that information. It has told us that it has answered all the questions that are necessary.

SPEECH.PARA: It seems to me that we have a total collapse-or an effective replacement-of the main kitchen because it is to be phased out and subsidiary or serving and presentation kitchens around the place will now carry that burden. I wanted to find out the original cost of putting in a major kitchen area-which now is either to be massively unused, or, depending on policy decisions taken, used only for some specific things like baking. When I asked what was the cost of design, construction and equipping of the main kitchen, which is now to be closed, the President said it was something that we had to get from the Construction Authority, too. I believe that some stab at it, without being too detailed, is possible.

Another matter that I want to raise on this same subject of design failures is the question of ponding on level tiled floors in wet areas. The President mentioned that not only does it happen in the kitchen, it also happens in the gymnasium and dressing rooms. Mr Guilfoyle from the Joint House Department said that this was an issue that the Parliament took up with the Authority and was overruled.

I want to say something about the large volume of design faults that seem to be emerging in terms of user problems. Before doing so, let me say that this is a brilliant public building; it is just not user-friendly. The issues that I am raising relate to user-friendliness. It seems to me that it is not really built for people to work in; it is built for people to look at. On this question of the Parliament being overruled on matters like this, is it possible for the Parliament to be advised about the extent to which its requests were overruled by the Authority:

Here is a clear example where-I presume that the Joint Standing Committee on the New Parliament House might have made the request or it might have been a Presiding Officer or maybe Joint House; I do not know who made the request-the floors should have had a capacity to drain water away to the nearest waste outlet. It would seem that if this kind of overruling did take place by the Authority, we should find out to what extent the Parliament's desires were not met in building this place.

I also ask whether $680,000 was needed to restructure the members only dining room to resolve the design fault, if I can call it that. Some design faults cannot be corrected. For example, the requirements for waitresses and waiters in the dining room to negotiate a flight of seven steps with fully laden trays is something that cannot be resolved. It is simply an in-built design fault which will remain there, no doubt, for ever and those people who are unfortunate enough to fall either up or down those stairs will suffer many grazed knees and destroy plates. Does the $680,000 being spent now to restructure the members only dining area include the construction of a glass wall and how much would be saved if such a glass wall were not built, if it is in fact a part of that expenditure?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sibraa Sen The Hon K.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —In reply to Senator Baume, I have been advised that a number of questions that he asked the other evening at the Estimates Committee hearing have been sent to the Parliament House Construction Authority for answers. I think Senator Baume would realise that we have asked for estimates of money and that might take some time.

SPEECH.PARA: I will refer to some of the other points he raised. It is a fact that a consultant's report recommends that there be a reduced usage of the main kitchen. But I would like to point out that there has been no decision taken yet to fully go along with that report.

The honourable senator mentioned a sum of $680,000 for improvements to the second floor dining and bar areas. Let me go over the history of this. I point out to all honourable senators that no contracts have been let at this stage. But if the work is to go ahead and be finished for when we come back on 20 August, it has to commence the moment that the Senate gets up. The consultants looked at this because of continuing complaints that were voiced by senators and members about the food quality and service, the high subsidy level required, the lack of privacy, the poor ambience and the poor design leading to operational difficulties. We actively investigated ways of overcoming these deficiencies.

To assist the Presiding Officers, Spotless Catering Pty Ltd was commissioned during the 1989 Budget session to undertake an operational review of catering services. A progress report was presented to the Joint House Committee on 29 November 1989 on improvements to the second floor dining and bar areas, including relocating and screening off members only dining to the upper level. The Presiding Officers, on the resolution of the Joint House Committee, agreed to proceed with the proposed changes. An information circular-1989/73 of 29 November-went to all senators and members. Spotless then conducted a survey of senators and members on 29 and 30 November 1989.

TALK.START.PARA: —Only some.

—Yes, but I believe it was a fairly representative group across the Parliament. Frequent survey comments included: members areas devoid of atmosphere; bistro area poorly conceived; lacking a club atmosphere. There were complaints about food presentation and style, and poor furnishings in the members area. The Presiding Officers then wrote individually to all senators and members in February of this year advising about the proposed new members dining arrangements, inviting them to view a display of plans and artists impressions and to provide comment. The problem then was that we had an election. That display was deferred until April 1990. It was made available to senators and members who attended the first party meetings. It was also made available to those new members and new senators who were coming into the Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: On 13 March 1990 a trial of some of the new service and menu concepts that had been recommended to us by Spotless began. We have had excellent customer feedback from that. There is a strong indication that the financial outcomes that were suggested by Spotless are obtainable. That trial continued until the end of April.

On 11 May, which was during the first sitting week, the members dining room redevelopment booklet was made available in the members club room. Regular meetings of the Joint House Committee have not been possible during the May sittings but I have been approached by members of the National and Liberal parties saying that there is some serious doubt about whether the Presiding Officers should go ahead with the plans that have been shown to members and senators of the improvements that would cost $680,000. In reply to Senator Baume, the glass screening is included in that work. If it were possible to hold a Joint House Committee meeting this week or next week and the previous decision was reversed-that is, a decision was made not to go ahead-there would be, of course, substantial savings. There would still have to be work done in the kitchen. I have got no idea what the cost of that would be, but there is no doubt in my mind that there would be substantial savings on the $680,000.

I spoke to the Speaker about this matter this afternoon and, hopefully, we will be able to come up with some solution as to whether a meeting is possible before the end of this week. I ask Opposition senators who have approached me on this matter to at least canvass their colleagues on the Committee, particularly from the House of Representatives, because all that the Speaker and I have been doing so far is carry out the resolutions of that committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to comment on some of the matters just raised by the President. I was astonished at the history he gave of things that have been sent out in recent times. I do not think anyone would be surprised that most members and senators were more interested in the election than in the circulars that may or may not have turned up on this matter over the period he referred to. Certainly I was not aware until yesterday of the booklet he referred to.

SPEECH.PARA: Discussing this matter in the dining room, one of the staff mentioned the booklet and went and got several for those of us who were discussing it at the time. As you know, Mr President, I spoke to you yesterday and today I conducted a survey amongst Opposition senators. I now have before me a letter I have just signed to give to you of the results of that survey, indicating beyond doubt that the glass panelling is not favoured. I personally find it astonishing that glass panelling was ever thought of to create what I think everybody wanted, that is, more privacy. My answer to that, and the answer of most honourable senators to whom I have spoken, apart from one of our senators, was that that has been achieved very successfully in a most pleasant way with the plants that have been put there.

There is absolutely no doubt that the standard of food at present is excellent. Everybody I have spoken to has commented on that fact. It is a marked improvement which is most welcome. There is great favour with the way the food is presented. I do not know what the bistro construction will do to improve what is presently provided. If it interferes with members serving themselves with salads and other food that would be an absolutely retrograde step. That matter has been included in the questions that we asked our own members. There certainly was significant opposition to the suggestion of turning the bar around to bring it into the dining room rather than leaving it separate as it is at present. What was most definite amongst those of our colleagues to whom we have spoken was that the glass would be claustrophobic. I think it would absolutely destroy the area. The concept of the members' and senators' own dining room being separate and at the top, as it is and as was originally intended, is undoubtedly the best idea for the area. Nobody is denying that the survey conducted some time ago indicated that greater privacy would be expected by members and senators, but I cannot see that anyone would deny that it has been achieved by the placing of plants, as is the case at present. Maybe we should leave it precisely as it is for 12 months or so and then see whether any changes need to be made.

I recognise that the kitchen has some aspects that need attention right now, and that should probably proceed, but the rest of it is particularly doubtful. Certainly I think that the glazing that is intended should be left out. I shall deliver this letter to you, Mr President, as soon as the chamber rises.

TALK.START.PARA: —Could I get one thing clarified which did not come through to me at the Estimates inquiry? I understood that the cost of the equipment alone that is needed to make the upstairs kitchen a workable kitchen was about $120,000. I understood that those kitchen costs `are out of the final quote'. Does that mean that the $680,000 does not include the $120,000 for kitchen equipment? What will be the other costs involved of any structural alterations? What labour costs are involved in putting this new kitchen equipment in? As I understand it, a decision has been made to proceed with the upstairs kitchen. What will be the costs involved? Has a final decision been made to make that a full kitchen and not just a finishing kitchen?

—I have been advised that the $120,000 that the honourable senator has referred to is included in the $680,000: building works, $371,000; kitchen equipment $120,000; services, $110,000; and preliminaries, $84,000. That comes to approximately $680,000, from what I can see.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am further concerned that the response from the Joint House Department about the question of the poor design of the kitchens appears to throw the matter back to the Joint Standing Committee on the New Parliament House, except that there is a phrase here that may suggest that that kind of buck passing is inappropriate. The reply from the Parliament House Construction Authority states:

SPEECH.PARA: The design of the kitchens and food services generally was based on-
I underline the words `based on'-

a brief approved by the Joint Standing Committee on the New Parliament House and refined after extensive consultation and approval by a series of individuals responsible in the Parliament for the food service and kitchen.

That is why I raise again the question: Who did mess this up? We hear from the Joint House Department that the Construction Authority did not agree with the Parliament's request. The Construction Authority has said that it was based on a brief approved by the Joint Standing Committee and that there were massive subsequent discussions. That is particularly in relation to the level floors and, as I understand it, Joint House having to purchase water vacuum cleaners to get the water off the floor in these tiled areas.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not believe it is possible to give Senator Michael Baume an answer to those questions right at this time. I will undertake to get an answer as soon as possible.

—I thank the President for that answer. I do not want to go into other matters about whose fault it was regarding the automatic retractable awnings and various other things. There is clearly disagreement between the Parliament House Construction Authority and the Joint House Department about this. But I would like to ask about another matter. I regret to say that it is under the Auditor-General's report, so I will have to ask it later, will I not?

—I think it would be more appropriate if we stuck to it. We could go on to the next subject if no-one else wishes to speak on the building design faults. The next subject is the committee room acoustics. Does anyone wish to speak on that?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The report of Estimates Committee A states:

SPEECH.PARA: Poor acoustics continue to be a major problem in the main committee room. Not only is it difficult for the Committee members to hear witnesses, Hansard reporters continue to operate under considerable duress. Further, it is also very difficult for people sitting in the room to follow the proceedings.
Then in very solid black type it states:
This problem has to be rectified!
When will it be rectified? At whose cost? How soon? And I ask all the other appropriate questions.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sibraa Sen The Hon K.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I believe that there has been work on a number of the committee rooms. There has been marginal improvement. The work certainly has not been finished. I would think that over this next parliamentary break the work will be able to be concluded in the committee rooms that have not yet been finalised.

SPEECH.PARA: I have also had some complaints about the standard of lighting in some of the committee rooms. There is a difference in the lighting between where the witnesses have to sit, where the public have to sit and the main tables, but that is a matter I have also referred to the appropriate people.
Sitting suspended from 6.30 to 8.00 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Committee is considering the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill (No. 2) and the motion moved by the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Senator McMullan) that the report of Estimates Committee A be adopted. The question is that that motion be agreed to. Before the dinner break we were discussing committee room acoustics. Is there any further discussion on that?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sibraa Sen The Hon K.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have some more information which I was able to obtain over the dinner break. An extensive program of configuration testing and research on sound pattern generation and dynamics has been carried out over recent months in the chambers and committee rooms. The objective was to produce optimum performance from the current sound systems from the microphones through to the speakers. As a result of changes made following that program, improvements have been reported in all committee rooms except the main committee room and committee rooms seven and 16. Results of the modifications and adjustments are now being assessed by an independent electro-acoustics specialist. When the specialist report is received, the Sound and Vision Systems Office, in conjunction with the Joint House Department, will investigate further ways to enhance sound quality with priority to be given to the main committee room. If possible, the necessary work will be carried out during the winter recess.

SPEECH.PARA: I have some more information on other questions that were asked but it does not relate to acoustics. Perhaps I should give that information later.

TALK.START.PARA: —Does the information relate to building design faults?
—The questions related to design changes to the parliamentary dining room.

—Although we have finished with that, I think it would be appropriate for the Committee to agree that you give answers to those questions now. I do not want to reopen the question of building design faults. I think that the President's information will be well received.

—Senator Michael Baume asked a number of questions. To the best of our knowledge the cost plan is unavailable at this stage. I am talking about the wood panelling and the glazed partition in the members' dining room. The broad order of costs identified by the cost planner for the wood panelling and glazed partitions to screen off the upper levels of the members' bar, the members' dining room and the members' guest bar would be about $200,000.

SPEECH.PARA: Before we went to dinner, Senator Reid gave me a letter about Opposition attitudes to proposed changes in the members' dining room. I ought to reply to them now. The first question she asked of Opposition members was: Do you support turning the members' dining room around so that it faces into the dining area? We are not turning it around at all; the members' bar is not changing. A servery is being built on the other side of it to serve the members' dining room. The second question was: Do you think a bistro area should be constructed in the members' dining area to replace the present food display area? The food display area is only being reallocated to a permanent position.

The reason that the glass panelling was contemplated was that members and senators made constant requests to watch television in the members' club room. They wanted to be able to watch the news and the 7.30 Report. That is why the television was put into the old bistro area. If those requests are to be complied with, that area will have to be soundproofed, otherwise the television will be heard all over the members' and guests' dining room.

During the last two weeks of sittings we have had a number of complaints from members and senators that members' guests have been walking up the stairs into the members' dining room looking for the toilet facilities. Again, it is felt that the area ought to be permanently partitioned.

I will refer to one other matter in the consultant's report about what should be done in the dining areas of this building. The trial to allow parliamentary pass holders to use the members' and guests' dining room during non-sitting weeks was very successful. Part of that consultant's report says that in non-sitting weeks the upper level area that is now the members' dining room should be partitioned, with members at one end and members and guests at the other end. Parliamentary pass holders should be able to use the lower level. If our experience is as it was during that last non-sitting period, that area will be packed and very noisy indeed. It was felt that some sort of soundproofing would be needed.

During the meal break I spoke to the Speaker. We are quite happy to consult with the Joint House Committee. I point out to Opposition members that the Joint House Committee has already endorsed the concept. If we can get a meeting next week we will hold it but, if these changes are to be implemented before we come back in August, these decisions will have to be made urgently.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not reopen those matters but, having been one of those Opposition members asked by a Whip to respond, I am glad to hear the full case for the partitioning.

SPEECH.PARA: I go back to the issue of the main committee room. As I understand it, there have been complaints for just short of two years-ever since we moved here-about this problem which is now to be rectified. I make the same point now that I have made in respect of other matters such as the blinds. The complaint about the equipment not working began when it was still under warranty; when whoever provided it had to make certain that it worked. It has never worked properly. Has the delay been such that we now no longer have the capacity to require the people who put in this lousy system to fix it up without it being at cost to the taxpayer?

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been informed that the sound system was put in by the Australian Broadcasting Corporation and that we are still negotiating with the Parliament House Construction Authority to try to reach a solution to the problem.

—I understand that, but my problem is this: Are we now out of guarantee? Has the time expired under which we could claim that there was a defect in installation and therefore the equipment has not met the requirements of the contracts? If the guarantee time under that contract has expired, when did it expire? Were these faults ever required to be rectified while the warranty-if there was a warranty-was still there?
—I will put that question on notice and I will get Senator Michael Baume a detailed answer.

—Is that all on committee room acoustics? We will move onto the next item, which is unanswered questions. There is only one unanswered question referring to the parliamentary departments, and that is a question from Senator Parer asking how much was budgeted for commercial newspaper, magazine, radio and television advertising? It was answered on behalf of the Senate on 18 May but has not been answered by the other departments. I do not know whether anyone wishes to pursue that. If not, we will turn to Senator Michael Baume's reservation on the subject of the Auditor-General's report. I ask him to assist the Committee by drawing attention to which item in the Auditor-General's report he is referring and to which item in the appropriations that report refers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am referring to item 12.2 on page 115 of the Auditor-General's report, No. 31, on ministerial portfolios. It relates to the Parliamentary Catering Service, which was dealt with in the Forward Estimates. The Auditor-General says:

SPEECH.PARA: The audit of the 1988-89 financial statements of the Parliamentary Catering Service resulted in a qualified audit report to the extent that an opinion could not be formed on the dissection showing `cost of goods sold' and `gross profit' for members services, staff and public services, and functions. In the absence of a reliable system to record stock movements the dissection was based on estimates. The signed financial statements were submitted for audit on 23 November 1989. The audit certificate and accounts and records report were issued on 1 December 1989 and 6 March 1990 respectively. The annual report has not yet been tabled in the Parliament.

I suppose that the first question I should ask is: `Why not?'. I understand that the Parliament was not sitting during the election period, but some time has passed since then. The key point that I wonder about is the following:

The accounts and records report in respect of the Parliamentary Catering Service identified a number of matters relating to the ADP Hospitality Inventory Management System, stocktaking, casual wages and provision of credit, where internal control could be improved. The Joint House Department advised of remedial action taken or proposed to address these matters.
I want to know whether the proposed action has been taken. Basically, have the problems been resolved? If not, when will they be resolved?

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been informed that, apparently, the Auditor- General had no difficulties with the total in the first part of section 12.2.1. The problem was with the dissection of the total and the methods used for the dissection. I believe that the problem is being worked on to the satisfaction of the Auditor-General. I have been advised that the automatic data processing hospitality inventory management system is being worked on at the moment. Hopefully, we can come to a satisfactory conclusion. I have been told that the financial accounts are included in the annual report of the Joint House Department and, as such, there is no requirement that these be tabled separately.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The next matter I want to raise relates to the Parliamentary Information Systems Office (PISO). Item 12.2.3 of the Auditor-General's report notes:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . an audit was carried out relating to an unofficial account operated by the Parliamentary Information Systems Office.
That was dealt with in the Estimates. However, I am concerned about the following:

The audit found a disregard for the established form of Commonwealth budgetary and expenditure control and a number of breaches of legislation in that moneys received were not paid into the Consolidated Revenue Fund and were spent without appropriation and the exercise of other statutory processes.
I am interested in what has been done to ensure that that situation cannot be repeated.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sibraa Sen The Hon K.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —In reply to Senator Michael Baume, I inform him that, the recommendations of Audit Report No. 25, namely, Investigation of an unofficial account operated by the Parliamentary Information Systems Office, are being implemented. On Monday, 14 May 1990 in Estimates Committee A I incorporated a document entitled `Response to issues raised in the report of Senate Committee A, November 1989'. Paragraph 5 on page 2 of the document outlines action taken to date on the recommendations of report No. 25. I have a copy of it here if Senator Michael Baume requires it. In summary, action has been taken on both the specific recommendations and also to improve the general management and financial reporting arrangements within PISO and between PISO and the Secretary of the Department of the Parliamentary Reporting Staff to whom PISO now reports. I also believe that a staff member from the Department of Finance has been seconded to PISO to make sure that everything is done as is required.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill agreed to.
Bill reported without amendment; report adopted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill (on motion by Senator McKiernan) read a third time.
Consideration resumed from 21 May.
REPORT OF ESTIMATES COMMITTEE A
Motion (by Senator McKiernan)-by leave-agreed to:
That, in Committee of the Whole, the votes for departments be considered in the same groups and order as the departmental estimates referred to Estimates committees.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to the order of the Senate, I will call on the proposed expenditure in the departmental groups and order considered by the Estimates committees. I therefore call on the expenditure considered by Estimates Committee A.

INTERJECT.PARA: Motion (by Senator McMullan) proposed:
That the report of Estimates Committee A be adopted.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! In accordance with the new procedure adopted by the Senate, passage of that motion will have the effect of approving the expenditure contained in the Bill. I will now call on departments examined by Estimates Committee A and in relation to each department the matters recommended by the Estimates Committee report or by the reservations attached to the Estimates Committee report for further examination by the Senate. Honourable senators are reminded that under the new procedures debate must be confined to those matters.

INTERJECT.PARA: The first department is the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce. The first matter recommended by the Committee for further consideration by Committee of the Whole was the motor vehicle plan. As no-one wishes to speak on the motor vehicle plan I turn to the second matter.

The second matter to which the Committee drew attention was the question of the multi function polis. Does anyone wish to speak on the multi function polis? If not, I will turn to the third matter to which the Committee drew attention, export market development grants. Does anyone wish to speak on that subject? If not, I will turn to the fourth matter to which the Committee drew attention, matters relating to coastal surveillance and the apprehension of illegal fishermen.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I note that there are a number of issues arising with regard to the matter of coastal surveillance, not only in this Department but also in a number of other departments, where information has been sought with regard to the overall coordination between departments and the various pieces of information that should be made available for much broader consideration by the Government. At page A43 of the Hansard of 14 May for Estimates Committee A I asked the following question:

SPEECH.PARA: What additional resources have had to be applied by Customs in that increased activity?
Whilst I received a number of general answers to that question, I was keen to find out what consideration had been given by the Department to the coordination of those matters.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I cannot add very much to what both I and the Comptroller-General of Customs said at the Estimates Committee. This matter, particularly on the apprehension of illegal fishing vessels, has been a fluctuating problem, particularly at Broome, and the Australian Customs Service is seeking extra resources from the Government in this forthcoming Budget to renew the existing vessels and increase the number of vessels it has for the apprehension of illegal fishermen. I cannot add anything more at this stage. If there are any matters Senator Tambling wishes me to inquire into and provide a written answer about, I will do that. I thought Mr Kelly, the Comptroller-General, gave the best answers he could in the circumstances in the course of the Estimates Committee.

—If there is no further discussion on matters relating to coastal surveillance and the apprehension of illegal fishermen, the next matter that is proper to be raised before the Committee is the unanswered questions. There are about a dozen of them. Does anyone wish to raise any matters in those unanswered questions? A list has been circulated by the Committee of the unanswered questions. If no-one wishes to raise those, Senator Michael Baume has a reservation in regard to the Auditor-General's report. Do you wish to raise any matters with regard to the Auditor-General's report, Senator Baume? If so, I would be grateful if you would indicate which particular paragraph of the Auditor-General's report you are referring to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is page 106, paragraph 11.2.7-Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation. Very briefly, the Auditor-General discovered some discrepancies between the general and subsidiary ledgers. I must say that this is the sort of point I would have raised in Estimates had I had the Auditor-General's report with me. There may be a very simple answer. The report states:

SPEECH.PARA: The imbalance has persisted despite the issue of detailed instructions, amended reconciliation procedures and an increase in the threshold level for non-current assets from $1000 to $3000, resulting in a halving of the number of assets required to be recorded separately.

As I said, there is still a $3m discrepancy. The Auditor-General reports that the organisation has recognised these deficiencies and was considering proposals to conduct extensive stocktakes and reduce the stocktake cycle from five to three years. It intended to conduct training seminars for staff designed to enhance the timeliness and accuracy of the fixed assets reconciliation process, and so on. The report goes on to say:
Further, introduction of a dispersed ADP accounting system in 1991 would provide for automatic updating of fixed assets records when the relevant expenditure was incurred.
What has been done along the lines of what the organisation was considering? Has it in fact considered these proposals and has it put them into effect yet?

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —That question, of course, takes me by surprise and, as Senator Michael Baume said himself, he would normally ask it at the Estimates Committee. I will undertake to obtain an answer from the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation and provide it to Senator Michael Baume as soon as possible.

—Could the Minister take up one very small matter, that is, who actually owns the properties that CSIRO occupies? I believe there is supposed to be a resolution of this matter, but I also understand from the Auditor-General's report that relevant negotiations have yet to be initiated. Why have they not been, when will they take place, and when will the matter be resolved?
—I am not sure what sites Senator Baume is talking about.

—The Auditor-General says that previous reports referred to crown land and land held in Commonwealth title occupied by the organisation for which it held no legal title. He says that the book value of this land is $12.6m.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —The CSIRO normally owns its own property, but at sites like the Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation site at Lucas Heights, as Senator Michael Baume knows, there is some occupation by CSIRO over there. I would not think that it owned the site. I will try to obtain an answer which elaborates on what I have said.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The next question concerns the Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation (ANSTO). I do not want to go back to the dispute about whether or not it was going to be serviced by staff and whether that dispute is continuing, although I would be interested to know what the state of play is and whether peace has been declared in the battle between CSIRO and ANSTO. The Auditor-General states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Report also referred to an opinion of the Attorney-General's Department that the arrangement permitting the use of ANSTO land and buildings by CSIRO and the current arrangements for employment of staff by the ANSTO to work with CSIRO may be outside the functions set out in the Act.

The Auditor-General notes that the arrangement remains unaltered. Is the chaotic situation that existed at about Christmas time last year, as I recall it, on that site at Lucas Heights the result of this curious legal situation; and what is the Government doing to resolve what appears to be, both legally and practically, a very unsatisfactory situation?

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that that issue has been resolved, so I was advised two or three months ago. Since then, I have heard nothing further about it. I do not want to stir up any legal opinions or anything of that kind to complicate what was a storm in a teacup in some ways. I think it has been resolved to the satisfaction of both parties.

—Unfortunately, the Auditor-General says that the arrangement may be outside the functions set out in the Act. In view of the fact that the Auditor-General is critical of the fact that the arrangement remains unaltered, does the Minister intend to continue a situation which is outside the functions set out in the Act?

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —He does not say it is outside the functions of the Act, he says it may be outside the functions of the Act. That may sound like a quibble, but it is an important quibble. I will look into that matter and see whether it can be resolved by another legal opinion or something else.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —There is one final matter with regard to the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce. It of the general matter relating to all departments which the Committee wished to draw to the attention of the Committee of the Whole, and that is performance indicators. Does anyone wish to speak on performance indicators? If not, that completes the consideration of the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce.

INTERJECT.PARA: In relation to the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet, there are no matters which the Committee wishes to draw to the attention of the Committee of the Whole, but there is one unanswered question from Senator Archer concerning the release of public documents. Does anyone wish to speak on that? If not, there is the Auditor-General's report. If no one wishes to speak to that, that completes the consideration of the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet.

In relation to the Department of the Treasury, the first matter which the Committee wishes to draw to the attention of the Committee of the Whole is release dates of publications from the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development. Does anyone wish to speak on that? The second matter is the Industry Commission, the appointment of a Green Commissioner, the future of Inter-State Commissioners, the number of inquiries, and related costs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak on this matter of the Green Commissioner, the Industry Commission in general in relation to the appointment of that commissioner and the role of the Commission with respect to its Act, because these matters have come very much to the fore in the last 24 hours. When the Industry Commission Bill was before this chamber during the last session there were two amendments moved by the Australian Democrats, accepted by the Government and passed into law. They were first, a new subclause 8 (4) of the Bill, which stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Where a matter is referred to the Commission for inquiry and report, the Commission must also inquire into, and, in the same report, report on, the social and environmental consequences of any recommendations it makes.
In other words, it is an overriding, ever-present term of reference, as it were, which must intrude into every report which the Commission makes on any subject.
Further to that we also moved, and the Government accepted, an amendment to proposed subsection 28 (2) which stated:
At least one of the Commissioners must be a person who has knowledge of, and at least 3 years experience, in an employed or voluntary capacity, in environmental matters.

That is the issue which is before us now-the giving of effect, through the appointment of that commissioner, to that intention which is clearly written into legislation and which was accepted at the time, as I recall, without demure by the Government.

As honourable senators will know, yesterday a speech was made to the so-called Sydney Institute by one Dr Alan Moran. Dr Moran said, among other things, that concerns about Australia's soil degradation problem were completely unfounded. He is reported as having gone on to say:
Self-contained land degradation, exhaustion and erosion, where it is confined to the individual's own property, is one of the great fabrications of alarmists and rhetoriticians.

That is an interesting word. He went on to say that concern about a serious soil problem in Australia was also `completely unfounded', as a study of American croplands showed. Finally with respect to this particular matter Dr Moran said that Australian agricultural output showed signs of achieving sustainable development, which he defined as using resources today without reducing real incomes in the future.

I point out, first of all, that Dr Moran was reported as speaking as the First Assistant Commissioner with the Industry Commission and also as a senior Federal Government official. Honourable senators will recall that at Question Time today I asked the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button), in relation to Dr Moran speaking in this way, whether he was speaking as a private individual or whether he was speaking as a spokesperson for the Government. Senator Button indicated that it really did not matter very much whether he was speaking in one capacity or the other.

I find that a rather remarkable statement, particularly in view of the fact that in reply to an earlier question from Senator Childs, the Minister for Social Security (Senator Richardson) said of Dr Alan Moran that he had a `cavalier, cowboy attitude'. Clearly, in his reply to Senator Childs, Senator Richardson was distancing the Government from Dr Moran's statement.

I do not know the capacity in which Dr Moran made that statement. I was not at the meeting; I am only going on the newspaper reports. But in a prima facie sense he was speaking in his official capacity. I would defend very strongly the right of employees, including government employees, to make public statements on any matter whatsoever, including government policy, provided they make it clear that they speak in a private capacity. When they speak as government employees it seems to me that it is absolutely essential that they speak only in relation to what government policy is.

I am particularly disturbed by these statements made by Dr Moran, as I indicated, at least in a prima facie sense as an employee of the Government, particularly bearing in mind the amendments which have gone into this Bill to attempt, as it were, to green this very important activity of government.

I note also in passing that Dr Moran was speaking to the Sydney Institute, which describes itself as a think tank. I have had a little bit to do with the Sydney Institute by way of reading some of its material. I must say I wonder how Gerard Henderson and his colleagues can think with brains that, in my view, seem to have been frozen somewhere in the nineteenth century.

If we look particularly at this statement by Dr Moran that Australian agricultural output shows signs of achieving sustainable development, which he defined as using resources today without reducing real incomes in the future, we find a statement which is absolutely typical of economists who have no knowledge whatsoever of the real world of living things. Indeed, because of their abstraction from the real world they have a total disregard for the real world.

It is not surprising because economists compare unlike things by rendering them into dollar terms. So many dollars buy so much land, wheat or petrol. At one level it is certainly true that economists can compare unlike things-they can compare them through dollar terms. But they then make the completely unjustified assumption-and it is clear from Dr Moran's statement that he is guilty of this offence-that, therefore, they are completely interchangeable or exchangeable. That is simply not the case. One cannot eat dollars, nor can one drive a vehicle with land, although through the market system they can be interchanged with dollars. In the real world they cannot be interchanged-they are simply not substitutable. Economists and Dr Moran ignore this difference between the real world and the abstraction which goes on, and has gone on, with economists.

The important point is: Does the Government share this particular view? Senator Button said today that he was not worried by Dr Moran speaking in his capacity as a Government employee. If the Government shares this view put by Dr Moran, it does not augur well for the Industry Commission. Indeed, the Industry Commission is going to find itself in a great deal of hot water if it is influenced by and makes the sort of statements that Dr Moran is reported as having made.

If it is Government policy, why has the Government stated that it considers land degradation a serious problem and is spending not a sufficient but a considerable sum of money in the repair of this damage? Surely if Dr Moran is right in his economic analysis, we should be flogging off land to the Japanese for holiday homes. That would maintain income, which by Dr Moran's own criteria and definition would amount to sustainable agriculture.

Let us compare the statement of the scientist, Dr David Smiles, the head of the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO) Division of Soils, speaking in response to Dr Moran. He pointed out that on a yearly basis Australia loses $350m to $400m worth of nitrogen from its soils; $160m to $200m worth of phosphorous; $60m to $80m worth of potassium; and that there is a real declining quality of wheat because of the declining nitrogen content of the soil. He pointed out that there is great difficulty in maintaining the protein level.

TALK.START.PARA: —Put a bit more fertiliser on it.

—Yes, Senator. Dr Smiles went on to point out that nitrogen loss is tied to acidification and the problems of residue management and that those problems are still without solution. That is the real world-a long way from Dr Moran's totally artificial world in which he compares land, wheat, petrol and other things simply in dollar terms.

SPEECH.PARA: This all adds up to the fact that Australian agriculture is simply not sustainable; that the land on which we are growing our crops is deteriorating. Dr Smiles pointed out that there is no clear way so far in which the nutrient levels in the soil can be maintained. The Government itself admits to $600m worth of lost export potential because of this nutrient loss. According to today's newspapers, Dr Smiles believes that the figure may be closer to twice that level-$1.2 billion. In addition, there is extensive soil loss and salinisation, particularly in Western Australia. Dr Moran went on to say that the world's oceans were too vast to be spoiled by pollution. He said that the cleansing powers of the world's great oceans remained intact and they were still the surest low-cost means available to break down waste and make it harmless: the oceans were `too vast to be spoiled' by damage caused by pollution.

Was Dr Moran saying-I stress, again, that ostensibly he was speaking as a Government employee-that the heavy pollution of the oceans contiguous to most of the world's major cities, including many Australian cities, as residents of Sydney would know but no more so than those of Adelaide where we have a tertiary sewage treatment system, is not to be taken seriously but, indeed, made worse because ocean dumping is the cheapest means of disposal? Is that Government policy?

I come back to the fact that Dr Moran was making the statement as a Government employee, apparently. Dr Moran went on to point out that in his opinion the best way to protect endangered animals was to pass them into private ownership. I am surprised by that but, in the light of his other remarks, apparently he seems quite incapable of considering the loss of a species as at all important. The history of private exploitation of animal species is littered with examples of forcing species to extinction, or near extinction. Economic common sense, as expounded by Dr Moran, would mean that a company or a person owning a species would force it to extinction, if that was profitable, and invest that money in the next species. That would be Dr Moran's economic rationality.

The fundamental question which emerges from this matter is: Is Dr Moran's view the view of the Government? If not, why was he appointed to a commission which, according to its charter passed in this Parliament only in the last session, should take a very different view from the view which he was espousing only yesterday? Will the Government see that Dr Moran, and people of his view, are shifted to less important and less sensitive positions?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the last question asked by Senator Coulter is no. I thought I went through this issue after lunch in Question Time. Senator Richardson also answered a question about it. I have never heard a more laboured point than the one Senator Coulter sought to make tonight. Dr Moran is not a commissioner of the Industry Commission. The Business Regulation Review Unit was put in with the Industry Commission. Dr Moran headed that Business Regulation Review Unit. As I understand it, his position is equivalent to a First Assistant Secretary. He is not a full commissioner of the Industry Commission.

SPEECH.PARA: Secondly, Senator Coulter referred at length to the fact that the Industry Commission was a government body with a charter. That is true: it is a statutory authority with a charter. The most important point of its charter, in some ways, is that it is an advisory body to government. It has no greater status than that. The Government can take notice of the Industry Commission's views, ignore the Industry Commission's views, or reject the Industry Commission's views. Dr Moran is a public servant working in the Industry Commission who has expressed views which are not formal views of the Commission. Even if they were formal views of the Commission, the Government could ignore them or reject them.

I think that Dr Moran is in a similar position to that of the scientist, Dr David Smiles, who at a seminar in Sydney put a different view from that of Dr Moran. Dr Smiles is an employee of a statutory authority, the vast majority of whose funds are government appropriations. Presumably, according to Senator Coulter, he is quite entitled to put his view because it is a view that Senator Coulter happens to like.

I would say the same about both men. I prefer the view, and Government policy is more in accordance with the view, put by the CSIRO scientist. Why are we spending all this money on soil degradation if that is not the Government's view? Why is the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) devoting so much attention to this issue if it is not the Government's view? Senator Coulter knows perfectly well that it is the Government's view. However, he comes in here and tries to make a mountain out of a molehill because Dr Moran has a view which he does not like.

I do not share Dr Moran's view, but I do assert his right to put it if he wants to, just as I assert the view of the CSIRO scientist to put his view, with which I happen to agree. I suppose this little point that Senator Coulter is making is a good launching pad, but it is nothing more than that. I have nothing to add to what I said this morning.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am disturbed by the Minister's reply. I made it quite clear that I have no objection whatsoever to Dr Moran putting any views at all provided he explains that they are his private views, particularly as he is an economist and he is making statements right outside his area of expertise. I do not think for a moment that Senator Button can compare those views of an economist when he is speaking on ocean pollution, on soil degradation and on the threat to endangered species with the views of the head of the Division of Soils of the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO), putting expert evidence before the public. That is a totally different situation.

SPEECH.PARA: Secondly, if Senator Button is saying that these matters are merely matters of opinion, then I am doubly disturbed because these matters are not matters of opinion. There is objective evidence in relation to soil degradation; there is substantial objective evidence in relation to ocean pollution; and there is substantial evidence in relation to endangered species. It is not simply a matter of opinion, as Senator Button seems to be saying. There is objective material there and I think that, with respect to soil degradation, Dr Smiles of CSIRO has a perfect right to put the best evidence before him. That is not a matter of opinion, whereas the expressions of opinion-I use those words quite deliberately-by Dr Moran were just that. In expressing an opinion he evidently did not distinguish his position as a public servant from his other position. He was described as being a First Assistant Commissioner with the Industry Commission. In that respect he is slightly removed from Government, but he was also described as a senior Federal Government official. He was apparently holding himself out as speaking in that capacity. That is not a reasonable thing for a person to do when he is simply expressing an opinion.

TALK.START.PARA: —If there is no further discussion on the Industry Commission, we will turn to the next matter, which is the Fore-site consultancy services.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —One matter has still not been resolved. We have heard that Dr Moran is not a commissioner. When is the Green commissioner going to be appointed? There was a great deal of discussion in Senate Estimates of what criteria was to be used in appointing him. I am wondering whether we can assume that today's venture from the Australian Democrats is to make certain that Dr Moran does not become the commissioner, if he had an application in. I assume that today's arrangements are to remind the Minister of the deal that the Democrats did with the Government in order to get this legislation through in the first place, which was to require the appointment of a greenie commissioner.

SPEECH.PARA: All of us on this side support conservation and have no difficulty with the concept that someone who is concerned about conservation should be a commissioner of the new Industry Commission. Perhaps our definition of a greenie may be different from the Democrats' definition, and hopefully the Government's is as well. The Democrats' view, from listening to them tonight, is that a greenie is someone who has an acceptable greenie position as far as they are concerned. Other people who have genuine conservation views, who are genuinely concerned about the degradation of our soil, for example, are not necessarily acceptable to the Democrats. There was a great deal of effort put in in the Senate Estimates to establish what criteria there is to be and what sort of `pay-off' to the Democrats is involved for getting this legislation through in the first place.

Despite all the constitutional problems that have arisen as a result of the passing of this legislation, and despite all the problems that emerge about commissioners who do not retire until 1991, in one instance, and until 1994, in two other instances, they have obligations in that area and are committed in their jobs and in their station to a salary until that time. They cannot be removed. The only thing that the Government can do is offer them other jobs or ask them to accept a compensation package or something like that. We have here a situation where under the Act at least one of the commissioners must be a person who does not have a job and who has at least three years experience in an employed or voluntary capacity in environmental matters.

Having heard the Democrats today put in their bid for an acceptable greenie, I urge the Minister to appoint to that role someone who has a genuine interest in conservation matters and who has the capacity to balance the conflicting pressures of growth and conservation in a rational way to the benefit and advantage of all Australians, rather than to give way to the Democrats' demands that the deal they did with the Minister should be satisfied only by a greenie of their choice.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —The appointment of what Senator Michael Baume calls the Green commissioner was made last week. I answered a question about it at Question Time today. The appointee is Dr Hundloe, who is currently the Director of the Institute of Applied Environmental Research at Griffith University. I am advised that he has written extensively on environmental impact assessment and the economic and social impact of development and cost benefit analysis and has undertaken consultancies for State and Commonwealth governments and the United Nations. There is no question of Dr Moran, before or after Dr Hundloe's appointment, being appointed as a Green commissioner.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I cannot let Senator Michael Baume's remarks pass without comment. I think the statements by Dr Moran clearly indicate that there is a real necessity for at least one out of eight commissioners to have a sympathetic view in relation to the environment. If the prevailing view which is coming through from Treasury is that indicated by Dr Moran-and that was the gist of everything I was saying earlier, because he was representing himself as a Government person-it is absolutely necessary that at least one in eight of those commissioners have an alternative view.

SPEECH.PARA: I also wish to comment that Dr Hundloe has been in the environment area for quite a long time. In the past he has been a councillor of the Australian Conservation Foundation. For Senator Baume's edification, he is a person who also comes from the econometric side of the environment debate. I think he would not object if I did not call him a rabid greenie. That might satisfy Senator Baume, to think that at least he is not one of these far out people-not that for a moment I would suggest that any of the Australian Democrats are far out.

I am also rather intrigued, as I am sure Senator Button is, by the claim which is oft repeated in this place that somehow or other I and Senator Button did a deal to get these amendments in to the Bill. I do not think Senator Button, from the remarks he has passed this evening, is in any way disclaiming the benefit of the amendments included in the Bill. As he said, the Government has given effect to these amendments by way of an appointment which was made last week.

TALK.START.PARA: —If there is no further discussion on the Industry Commission the next matter to which the attention of the Committee of the Whole is drawn is the Fore-site consultancy services. There is no discussion on that. The next item was taxation matters, taxation advisory committees, tax audits, lost returns and estate returns. There is no discussion on that. The next matter is the Tax Pack Magazine.

—I hope we can get a clarification in relation to the new segment that is being established called the help department. What is the status of the advice that is given and is that advice binding on the Commissioner of Taxation in relation to subsequent amended returns? I believe the answer needed some clarification.

—Rather than giving Senator Watson my instant assessment, and in the absence of officers from the Australian Taxation Office, I will give him a written reply on that. That is the safest way to make sure we are both operating on the same basis.

—We now come to unanswered questions which are now before the Committee of the Whole. There are 27 unanswered questions in regard to the Treasury, which seems to me an excessive number. One would have hoped that they would have been reduced before the Committee of the Whole met.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to address some comments to the unanswered questions relating to the taxation zone rebates. As shown in the Estimates Committee A Hansard at page A108, Senator McMullan undertook at the Estimates Committee hearing to provide answers and written replies to a number of points that I made that evening and which are listed in quite some detail. These related to the current review that was under way with regard to taxation zone rebates. I asked questions about what use was being made of consultants in the review and whether any particular consultation had been undertaken with the various State, Northern Territory or local governments on this matter.

SPEECH.PARA: I was also seeking to know what recommendations arose from the report some two years ago, in 1988, of the Prime Minister's country task force, which for the last two years a number of Australian Labor Party politicians have been touting around in the electorate with rather gay abandon, saying that they had expected that there would have been changes in the 1988 and the 1989 Budgets which have not been forthcoming. Of course, I would now hope that in the 1990 Budget we will see the results of this particular review emerging. I am concerned that those questions have not been addressed at this point. I would have thought that in the last day or so they would have been.

I would also like to address a further question more particularly to Senator McMullan, who also stated at the Estimates Committee hearing the other evening that in any redefinition of the boundaries that could be applied to or be part of any review of the zones the boundary review was certainly part of what is being reviewed. Senator McMullan said:
The Prime Minister's statement announcing the review said that it would be on a no detriment basis.

I would like to ascertain more details with regard to that specific supposed statement by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). My staff have spent the last two days trying to get a copy of that statement-they have searched thoroughly through library records-and have been unable to do so. I would like Senator McMullan in particular to address the basis on which he made that particular statement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, let me first address your general comment concerning the large number of outstanding questions from Treasury, which is a reasonable cause for concern. I am told that, because they were so many questions put on notice, a lot of resources have been put into trying to collate and ensure that these questions are dealt with quickly. Many of them are under way. As an example, I can deal specifically with those which Senator Tambling has raised, which I will do in a moment. I myself checked on that this evening. I am concerned that the answers are not here but I am advised they are proceeding expeditiously.

SPEECH.PARA: With regard to the general matters of taxation zone rebates, the questions raised by Senator Tambling have the same status as the other 20 questions. I have personally inquired to ensure that expeditious handling of the matter to give him comprehensive answers to all these questions is being undertaken, and I can assure him that that is the case. I would have hoped that it would be here by today but certainly it is being dealt with promptly.

I checked the no-detriment basis myself. I am fairly confident that the words were used by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) but where they are used in a written statement-and I would have thought that document would already have reached Senator Tambling but certainly it is in transit to him-is in the advertisement calling for submissions to the inquiry. It said quite clearly, `on a no-detriment basis'. That document, if it has not reached Senator Tambling, is in transit to him, and that is where it is stated explicitly and in writing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have not at this stage received any of that documentation. I will study it carefully when I receive it. I am particularly concerned at the delays in answering these questions because on Monday of last week I directed a particular question to Senator Collins as the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Northern Australia. I directed a very direct question to him on that occasion. Senator Bjelke-Petersen followed that with a similar question, I believe a day later, to which the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, (Senator Button), was unable to give a direct response, and in fact gave almost a contrary view to Senator Collins. However, Senator Button came into the chamber a day later with a prepared answer to Senator Bjelke-Petersen's question. Very obviously there was considerable preparation in the material that was provided to Senator Button last week which was in advance of the Senate Estimates hearing. Therefore I am most concerned to now find that there is obviously confusion and inadequate responses coming from the Department of the Treasury and that it is unable to meet the genuine requests of the Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: With regard to the issue that arises in relation to no detriment, I do not believe we can just accept that an advertisement for calling of submissions is in any way indicative of what Government action will be in this response. Thousands of taxpayers in remote and rural parts of Australia have not had any change in the taxation rebate scheme since 1984. Therefore the matter is urgent. The issue relating to zone boundaries or what towns will be included in either zone A or zone B are of particular concern, as I said, to thousands of Australian taxpayers. I do not believe that we should be left on a hook, waiting for these types of inadequate responses that are to come. It will certainly be one issue in which the Government is going to be judged very carefully in the 1990 Budget.

TALK.START.PARA: —Could I just briefly respond to that? Senator Tambling's high dudgeon is a little hard to cope with. He came in when the relevant section of the Estimates Committee had passed-the appropriate section in which he could have asked these questions having been dealt with some two hours previously-tried to ask questions at the wrong time, and, because I said, `Don't worry about the fact that it is not appropriate now; I am happy for you to ask them now and I will try to get you an answer' he now comes and tries to put on some sort of star turn as if he has been done a disservice when in fact we could properly have said, `I'm sorry, you are too late; we have long passed that section'. Essentially we are providing information to him in response to questions that he did not ask at the right time and to which he was not strictly entitled in accordance with the Standing Orders. It is a bit much for him to come in here and put on that sort of performance. I also think it is just this side of preposterous for him to say that the Government making a written statement in the newspaper of the basis upon which it is conducting a review is not adequate guidance. But that is for him to judge and for others to judge his interpretation.
—The next matter is the Auditor-General's report, No. 31. Finally, if there is nothing there, there is a general matter raised relating to all departments, the question of performance indicators.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —My comments cover not only the Department of the Treasury but also the Department of Finance; they are relevant to both. The Committee needs to take a very hard look at the effectiveness of this so-called program budgeting in areas where performance indicators are not available or where they are inadequate. While endorsing the philosophy of making managers responsible for the decisions under their control, one line appropriations in areas such as Treasury and Finance for their subprograms are not sufficient, nor are the explanations adequate, particularly for the Supplementary Estimates which we have just dealt with. They are not adequate for appropriate parliamentary scrutiny in their present form.

SPEECH.PARA: As parliamentarians we do not have the ability to make an assessment of just how effectively these managers have administered and discharged their responsibilities. We do not have an assessment of how effectively they have met their goals or their programs. I think this is reflected in a question that we asked, believing that the 3 per cent national wage cost had not, or could not, be allocated to programs. We were advised that we would have to be given a paper on that position so that we could clarify what program management budgeting involves. There was a further implication that there was one set of books for the Parliament's evaluation and another set for internal consumption. Clearly, these explanations are quite insufficient and inadequate.

When we attempted to ask questions of a general administrative nature, they were repeatedly deflected-incorrectly, in the view of the coalition. The Government representatives' interpretation of our ability to question in this area was inappropriate. Further, this rejection was not on the basis of our questions asking for an opinion or asking a policy question. Our questions were framed in the light of the administration of the programs under the responsibility of the departments concerned. Guidelines must therefore be established at an early opportunity to overcome this inability of parliamentarians to question adequately in this area of program budgeting.

It is clearly an unsatisfactory position that we have at the present time. We were told that through the implementation of program budgeting the Parliament would be given a lot more information than we were in the past when we had item by item descriptions. We have absolutely no ability, where there is a lack of performance indicators, to see how effectively these programs have been administered. There are good reasons for suspecting that there could be some hiding under the cloak of program budgeting. The concept of program budgeting is to open up these areas for further illumination of what has happened and how effectively the responsibility has been charged. In other words, as a parliament, we need to know just how widely we can question in areas which can rightly be regarded as the proper sphere of administration of a department, whether that department has administered outside the traditional guidelines as well as the extent of the ambit of the administrators' true Public Service responsibilities to the Parliament and the Executive.

TALK.START.PARA: —That completes consideration of the Treasury. We now turn to the Department of Finance. The first matter in relation to the Department of Finance to which Estimates Committee A drew the attention of the Senate is that of Australian Audit Office matters. The second matter is the assets register. The third matter is the method of allocating running costs to programs. We now turn to the reservation by Senators Bishop and Watson on the Department of Finance paper on the coalition's Economic Action Plan.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.
