TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to raise an issue encountered by my colleague Senator Bishop during consideration of the Supplementary Estimates in Estimates Committee A. The Liberal-National Party coalition continues to be concerned that during the Estimates the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer, Senator McMullan, refused to allow questions to be asked concerning the minute paper prepared by the Department of Finance which purportedly costed the coalition's Economic Action Plan. The Government senator's reason for refusing to allow officers to answer questions was that the matter did not relate to a specific program for which additional estimates were being requested. The matter that the members of the Committee wished to raise was of a general administrative nature and not related to any specific program, least of all the one for which the Department was seeking additional estimates.

SPEECH.PARA: The coalition is of the view that Ministers, or their representatives, should not block questioning on additional estimates which are related to the general administration of a department. This is particularly the case where the matter is one which could be regarded as politically sensitive. The coalition will further pursue this matter in the Senate but in the interim this reservation has been appended to the report of Estimates Committee A to draw the Senate's attention to the concerns of the coalition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have not been in the Senate as long as most other people in this chamber-perhaps everybody else in this chamber. But I have been on Estimates Committee A, I regret to say, almost from the day I arrived because it started sitting almost on my first sitting day, dealing with Supplementary Estimates. The Chairman of Estimates Committee A, Senator Childs, has been fairly liberal in his interpretation and I think that is appropriate. But I have always had the view, particularly with regard to Supplementary Estimates, that there needs to be at least some connection between a supplementary estimate and the question being asked.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the good things about the Parliament is that there are plenty of forums in which to pursue information. Sometimes an Estimates committee is the most appropriate place to do that. It is done with vigour and so it ought to be. Sometimes this chamber is the most appropriate place. Sometimes it may be a standing committee of the Senate or a special committee or whatever. There is no shortage of avenues. But Estimates committees, no less than any other part of the Parliament, need to operate within the Standing Orders of those bodies. I do not think we ought to take too narrow a view of it. I do not think anybody who observed the Estimates Committee A proceedings, at least in so far as they related to Treasury and Finance-which are the areas for which I was responsible; I think it is also true for others, but I cannot speak for them-could say that we were particularly difficult in preventing people from raising issues.

I just commented on Senator Tambling who came in to the Committee entirely out of order, but with questions that if he had asked at the right time and in the right way would have been perfectly appropriate. They were Estimates committees matters. So we said, `Do not worry about the procedural problems; just put the questions on notice and we will get the answers'. The relevant officers had left because we were not dealing with the right section, and that is why we took them on notice. That was an example of endeavouring to cooperate with honourable senators to provide information, and there were others.

But there just comes a time in which the connection between the matter being pursued and the estimates before us becomes so remote as to be, in effect, non-existent. We had questions such as this in an attempt to make the matter relevant. Senator Bishop said that because the National Audit Office comes under the Department of Finance and the Audit Office would be concerned about the manner in which departmental money is expended, perhaps she could use the Audit Office estimates to ask a question about this matter. I am quoting Senator Bishop, who said:
Page 14 talks about the National Audit Office. Presumably, the Audit Office will be concerned about the manner in which departmental money is expended.

If we started to use the Audit Office's role of auditing other bodies to mean that questions about those other bodies could be asked under the estimates of the Audit Office, we could ask questions about the Department of Primary Industries and Energy under those estimates, because the Audit Office reviews that Department's expenditure. That just does not make sense as a point.

I was quite relaxed about whether or not the question was asked and answered if it could be brought within the Standing Orders. It was not. I simply pursued a point in my first experience on the front bench which I pursued for two years as a back bench member of the Committee. I did not do so because I sought some sort of argument or confrontation, because I am a great advocate of Estimates committees. As the officers at the table and others will know, I have spoken at a number of seminars about the role of Estimates committees and put forward my views. They may not be the views that everybody shares, but I wanted to put on the record the fact that there was in no way any obstruction.

I certainly am quite relaxed about a proposal that the capacity for people so to pursue matters that are not covered by any estimate ought to be regularised. I am not necessarily having any confrontation with the point that there ought to be some situation by which the situation is clarified. I have found in 2 3/4 years that it is continually uncertain. I am quite relaxed about that. The only reason I chose to speak was to make sure that, the matter having been raised, there is nothing left on the record to say that I set out in some way to prevent people exercising their proper rights under the Standing Orders, which I will not do.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —This goes to the heart of some of the problems that we are having with Estimates committees. I believe Senator McMullan was quite genuine in his defence of the indefensible. What Senator McMullan avoided noting was that one of our concerns-it was reflected in a question put on notice by Senator Watson-is that the Estimates committee process now is being subverted by the departments putting additional estimates relating to wages and salaries in lines that are not related to the programs. Had the additional wages and salary requirements been put against the programs to which they applied, these matters would properly have been able to be raised and Senator McMullan's objection could not have taken place, because this would have been part of the administrative process. The whole point is that the salaries and wages case required a `not applicable to program' addition in every department.
—You find an estimate for it in the Department of Finance. There was not one.
—Yes, Audit. I drew attention to it.
—Every department had an adjustment, as I recall it, relating to additional expenditure because of wage guidelines.
—No. You are wrong.
—Why did the Audit Office have one?
—Because it is a very efficient department, perhaps; but you will find that in Finance there was not one and that is why it could not be raised.
—It was raised under Audit.
—Senator Watson says there was one and it was raised under Audit in Senate Estimates Committee.
—It is not a matter relating to Audit.

—Senator Watson raised this matter and there was a lengthy reply; Senator Watson can pursue this in a minute. There was a lengthy reply to his questions regarding additional funding for national wage increases not being allocated to particular programs in the Additional Estimates explanatory notes. His concern was that by not allocating those additional funds the Senate was being denied the knowledge of which programs would receive these funds. That seems a basic general point.

SPEECH.PARA: I must say that I would be much more comfortable if we could be assured of the fact that a failure to allocate them to individual programs does not prevent our pursuing individual programs even though they do not appear with line by line alterations, so that people like Senator McMullan can say, `It didn't appear; it wasn't in the Supplementary Estimates, therefore you cannot talk about it.' That is just not acceptable to the Opposition.

If in fact there have been wage increases not allocated, we believe we have the right to raise all sorts of issues because we do not know where the money has been allocated. It is not allocated to function. In other words, we can be prevented from dealing with matters of substance in an activity which has in fact had an increase in expenditure. We are prevented from knowing, because there is no line entry, whether it is a matter that can properly be raised in Senate Estimates. I believe the Government is on a collision course with the Opposition if it persists in this view.

TALK.START.PARA: —I just want to clarify the situation with regard to this matter. I do not wish to challenge the general point that Senator Watson and Senator Michael Baume have made because it is a matter which I have heard raised but which I have not given consideration to. So I am not challenging the general point; I simply reiterate that it is not appropriate to this particular circumstance and was not the background to this matter. It may or may not be a legitimate general point. It was not, I might say, raised in the attempt to pursue this matter by Senator Bishop.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —That completes consideration of the reservation. We now turn to unanswered questions. There is only one concerning postal allowances. If no-one wishes to speak on that I turn to Auditor-General's report No. 31. The final point is the general issue on which I think Senator Watson spoke earlier with regard to the Department of Finance performance indicators. Does anyone else wish to speak on performance indicators? If not, that completes consideration of the report of Estimates Committee A.

INTERJECT.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
REPORT OF ESTIMATES COMMITTEE B

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —I now call on the expenditure considered by Estimates Committee B.

INTERJECT.PARA: Motion (by Senator McMullan) proposed:
That the report of Estimates Committee B be adopted.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —In accordance with the new procedures adopted by the Senate, passage of that motion will have the effect of approving the expenditure contained in the Bill. I will now call on the departments examined by Estimates Committee B and, in relation to each department, the matters recommended by the Estimates Committee report for further examination by the Senate. Senators are reminded that, under the new procedures, debate must be confined to those matters.

INTERJECT.PARA: The first one is Foreign Affairs and Trade. There is one reservation by Senator Newman relating to United Nations contributions to Namibia. If there is no discussion on that, the second matter is the list of unanswered questions. Does any honourable senator wish to raise any unanswered questions? The Committee, by the way, did not list unanswered questions as being a requirement to be referred to this Committee. The final matter is the reservation by Senator Michael Baume to the Auditor-General's report No. 31. If there is no matter to be raised there we will refer to Defence. (Quorum formed)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a matter regarding the motion before the Chair, namely, that the report of the Estimates Committee be adopted. I presume I am allowed to speak on that, under the new rules?
—Yes, you may.

—That is the first matter to be raised with regard to the Defence estimates. I want to make a few general remarks about the problems that senators face due to the new procedures. We have here a very bland report by an Estimates committee, despite the fact that it has been considering some very important estimates over a period of two days. The Government has compressed, in an excessive and, I think, an unprecedented way, the amount of attention that is able to be given to Estimates-albeit that they are Supplementary Estimates rather than the general Estimates, but the same general issues are always raised which require the proper attention of this chamber.

SPEECH.PARA: Under the new rules the theory seems to be that the Senate can, and should, rely solely on the report of Estimates committees in order to debate the details of the Government's expenditure. Although that may not be such a major question in regard to these Supplementary Estimates, it will certainly be a very real question when we consider the Budget estimates in the next session of parliament. If the new rules are going to make any sense at all-and I have very grave doubts as to whether they will; I must say that I have already expressed those in the debate we had when they were brought into the Senate-the Estimates committees will have to do a decent job of reporting to the Senate.
Nobody could possibly say that the report we have in front of us at the moment is anything more than a bland, anodyne attempt to prevent this chamber from being able to conduct that debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I can assure you, Senator Durack, that when we get to Estimates Committee C you will find some stimulating contributions.

—I am glad to hear that that is so. But what concerns me is the amount of time that was allowed for consideration of this report. I do not know what happened to other reports, but certainly the time allowed for the compiling of this report was totally inadequate for the presentation of a detailed consideration of the estimates. This Committee finished its consideration of the Estimates last Thursday evening and a meeting was held on the following Monday at 1.50= p.m. in some public area of the Parliament in order to settle the report. As I recollect, the Senate got up on Thursday--
—Who is the Chairman of that Committee?

—It does not matter who the Chairman of the Committee is. The fact is that the Government has brought on the consideration of these Estimates this week before the committees have had any real opportunity properly to consider the matters before them.

SPEECH.PARA: I am not blaming the Committee. I am blaming the Government's handling of this whole process. The report of this Estimates Committee is a classic example of the way in which the Government has compressed the time for the consideration of Estimates. That is my point. I am not trying to blame any particular members of the Committee. I think they were given an impossible job. I am not a member of this Committee but I did attend the Estimates hearings for some periods and I know that detailed consideration was being given to them. But the hearings did not finish until Thursday evening and senators were not available for meetings on Friday.

Having shown some interest in the matter, I was asked if I would put forward any reservations, if I had any. In fact, I was asked to do so before the Committee had finished its work. But, as I said, the Committee then met for a few minutes on Monday to settle the report, due to the Government's demands that these matters be brought before the Senate this week. The Committee did not have any reasonable amount of time for consideration, unless committee members had spent the weekend here-which is a rather unreasonable request considering that the Senate had sat for two weeks. But the Committee was expected to have completed its report before the Senate sat on Monday because the Government demanded that the reports be presented so that they could be debated today or, I suppose, if the Government had its way, even earlier.

This is certainly an impossible atmosphere under which the new system must work. If we are going to proceed with these new Standing Orders-and I must say that when governments behave like this it is a pretty good indication that such Standing Orders cannot work-and assuming that we are having them foisted on us before the Government has the numbers--
Government senators-No.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government's numbers pushed these things through, with the support of the Australian Democrats. If they are going to work, then proper time has to be given for the Estimates committees to consider properly the matters before them, to properly consider the reservations that honourable senators have put in. There is a list of reservations here. I put in only one reservation on this one, but I will jolly well make sure that there are pages of reservations in future-and I am not even a member of the Committee. I will ensure that there will be pages of reservations or that there will be all-embracing reservations. I can tell the Government that a horse and cart can be driven between these Standing Orders if it thinks it can get away with this sort of blue murder.

SPEECH.PARA: As I said, I put in a reservation on a matter I was particularly concerned about. Of course, no attention whatever was paid to that. I see that one of my colleagues has put in a number of reservations. There is absolutely no comment on any of those put forward by Senator Newman.

If we are going to require this process that any senators, whether they are members of the Committee or not, have to put in reservations to get any attention whatsoever given to these important estimates when we come to debate them in detail, as we are trying to do now, then the Standing Orders will be subverted. The intention clearly is that the Estimates committees will take a wide and embracing consideration of the matters, and will try, as Senate committees usually do, to reach some consensus about such matters. It will only be in cases where that cannot be reached that reservations will be put in. But that is a process that needs time. Clearly, this Committee was simply unable in the time to do the job that was given to it.

That is the first matter of concern that I wish to express, and I think the Senate, whether now or at some later stage, is going to have to consider the way in which this new procedure is going to work.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Durack, I have allowed you to discuss this as it is relevant to the motion that the Committee report be adopted, but I do not want to start a wide-ranging debate at this period on that matter because it would not be relevant to the matter before the Chair. Could you now turn your attention to the matters for discussion, the first one of which is defence--

—I must say that I am quite astounded by that statement. We are asked to adopt a report of a committee. If a committee has not had adequate time to consider the material on which it is reporting, I would have thought it was very clearly relevant to the question of whether that committee report should be adopted.

—That is why I allowed you to speak on the subject. Nevertheless, I do not think a wide-ranging debate at this point in the Committee of the Whole on the nature of the Estimate committee procedure would be appropriate. We are considering particular estimates.
—I am prepared to debate whether the report should be adopted, if that is what you are saying I should be doing. I have been speaking relevantly to the motion before the Chair.

—That is why I allowed you to speak. I thought you were finished on that subject and were about to turn to something else. I did not want a number of other speakers debating this issue because it is not a matter that is relevant before the Chair at the moment.
—Are you saying that you are not going to allow debate on the question of whether the Committee has been able to report adequately?
—Yes, that would not be in order at this point. There are other procedures which could be discussed but this is not the moment to do it.
—When would it be?

—Whenever the Senate likes to raise the matter. At the moment we have a particular report before the Committee and we have reservations on it and they are the matters before the Chair. The general procedure by which these conclusions are arrived at and the overall issue of how the matter reached this stage are not relevant before this Committee at this stage. I have allowed, I think, 10 minutes for you to develop your argument, as I know you feel strongly about it. I do not think a debate in this Committee at this time would be appropriate.

—It so happens, Mr Chairman, that I have largely covered the points I wanted to raise. I hope that other senators might agree with my view that this Committee report reveals clearly that it has not had sufficient time to look at the matter. That must be relevant to the question of whether it should be adopted; but I will leave that to further debate. I presume we will be able to speak again if necessary.

SPEECH.PARA: Coming to the particular reservation that you sought to attract my attention to at the beginning of this debate, I had sought further consideration of one matter that I had raised in the Estimates Committee, namely, under the Royal Australian Navy subprogram, the refit of HMAS Onslow and related questions. I ask the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray) whether or not the matter has progressed any further since last week, whether or not he has taken that matter to Cabinet and whether or not, indeed, Cabinet has made a decision.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Durack has raised two issues, one of which I am not really going to refer to, other than to note that earlier today when we wanted some procedures discussed and referred to the Standing Committee on Procedure, his side blocked that. So much for democracy in that sense. With regard to the refit of HMAS Onslow, I think I explained at the Estimates Committee that I had sent an evaluation team to both Western Australia and New South Wales. It has completed its task and reported to me. In the near future I will lodge a Cabinet submission on the matter and a decision will be announced. I also made it very clear that any decision would be based on a bid, on a tender, that could deliver the best quality at the cheapest price, not on the basis of statements from politicians, be they State or Federal politicians, be they Trades Hall Council or Australian Confederation of Industry representatives. This matter will be decided with the proprieties, if you like, observed, as defence contracts must be. I expect the matter will be resolved in the next couple of weeks.
—The next matter is program 1.2, management of funds not sufficient to adequately allow for the provision of women on naval ships-a reservation by Senator Newman.
—Are you simply calling on the reservations?

—Yes. I am going through the reservations. The situation is that what the Committee of the Whole is considering is matters that the Committee raised. As you pointed out this Committee did not raise any matters for the Committee of the Whole to consider. But other members of the Committee or people who are not members of the Committee are entitled to list matters they wish to have discussed and drawn to the attention of the Committee of the Whole. I have a list of them in front of me and I am going through them one by one asking who wishes to speak on them, if anybody. If no-one wishes to speak, we will go on to the next one. The one before us is the reservation by Senator Newman referring to the funds for women on naval ships.
—It has been raised by Senator Newman, but I presume any honourable senator can speak on it?

—Anyone can speak on the matters. They are matters before the Chair and are not peculiar to the person who raises them. Anyone may speak on a matter when he wishes to. When no-one wishes to speak any further, we will go on to the next one. The matter before the Chair is program 1.2.

—Senator Newman has raised the question of the adequacy, presumably, of the funds to implement the Government's newly announced program for women to be able to serve on naval ships. There was quite a deal of discussion about this matter at the Estimates Committee. I can recall Senator Newman asking a number of questions about it. There were some matters on which further information was going to be provided to her. I wonder whether the Minister for Defence is in a position to provide some of that further information.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Both Senator Newman and Senator Durack have raised questions relating to whether management of funds is sufficient to adequately allow the provision of the recent announcement about women on naval ships. Navy seeks no funding in the financial year 1989-90 to implement its announced policy to employ more women at sea. Women will continue to be posted initially to ships where satisfactory accommodation and privacy provisions exist or can be made available.

SPEECH.PARA: Forty women are already at sea under these arrangements. In subsequent years Navy may seek modest funds to make some change to accommodation arrangements in existing ships. Changes would normally be made during a planned refit. Refit costs are not expected to increase significantly as a consequence. Provision will be made to accommodate women in new ships during the construction phase, for example, the Anzac ships. Navy plans to have about 500 women at sea by 1996.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister in a position to identify the ships that are already in a condition to accept women?
—I have been advised that Jervis Bay, Flinders, Tobruk and Cook are the four ships that can accept women.

—If there is no further discussion on that matter we will turn to program 1.3 in relation to which I have a reservation by Senator Newman asking that the attention of this Committee be drawn to Army involvement in United Nations peacekeeping activities. As there is no discussion on that matter I will turn to subprogram 1.3.5 in relation to which I have a reservation by Senator Newman asking that the attention of this Committee be directed to increased expenditure in training. As there is no discussion on that matter I will now turn to program 1.4, cost recovery regarding use of VIP Royal Australian Air Force aircraft and on which I have a reservation by Senator Newman directing the attention of this Committee to that matter. As there is no discussion on that matter I will turn to program 4.4, additional costs regarding Steyr rifle.

—I can recall this question being canvassed by Senator Newman. Apparently at the time no costs were available concerning the delayed production of the rifle. Is the Minister in a position to provide any further information on that matter?

—The only extra cost that may arise in terms of the delay would be the maintenance of the old 7.62 millimetre and 5.6 millimetre weapons and ammunition for an extra period of time until the new weapons and ammunitions are introduced. There should not be a significant difference in the maintenance costs of the two systems. Ammunition has to be provided to test rifles more extensively than planned. Obviously if there is a minor defect, one must use more ammunition to remedy the defect. About 100 rifles were exhaustively tested to find a solution to the problems being encountered. No negotiations on the cost or who should bear the cost of these weapons has commenced. Administrative costs-travel and overtime-have been incurred at a level higher than anticipated during the extra testing of the weapons.

—As there is no further discussion on the Steyr rifle, the next point that is drawn to the Committee's attention by Senator Newman is the reduction in guarding provided by Australian Protective Services.
—I think Senator Newman only wanted to congratulate the Government about that.
—In the questions that I have just cleared on notice, there is an explanation as to how we achieve the savings.

—The next program to be dealt with is 5.2, future of the Australian Defence Force regarding overseas recruitment and citizenship. Again, I have a reservation by Senator Newman drawing the Committee's attention to this matter.

—This particular item of the estimates raises some very important questions, both in the short and long term, for the Australian Defence Force. I suppose these questions arise in their most acute form as a result of the losses of pilots in the last year or so. I understand that the Royal Australian Air Force is short of approximately 150 pilots-perhaps the Minister could confirm that-and also that there is a recruitment drive for middle level pilots, who I understand range from the ranks of flight lieutenant right through to wing commander. There are some serious questions as to the roles these overseas pilots will have, particularly at those levels. Has the Minister any further information? I think some questions were directed to that matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before tonight I did not know, and I guess Senator Durack did not know, that these people are referred to as lateral recruits. That is something that probably we have both learned tonight. I will give you some information from the questions coming out of the Estimates Committee B hearing and I hope that will cover enough of the ground.

SPEECH.PARA: Normal security clearance procedures for Royal Australian Air Force (RAAF) personnel are followed for prospective lateral recruits. That is, security vetting is done by the Directorate of Air Force Intelligence and Security. Immigration processing of lateral recruits is subject to the normal rules of the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs. To expedite processing, a tripartite negotiated arrangement between DILGEA, the Department of Employment, Education and Training and the RAAF was signed on 23 December 1989. The tripartite negotiated agreement removes the sponsorship skills test requirements and permits the annual migration of a total of 30 officers of general duties, pilot, navigator, engineer, supply and air traffic controller categories. Lateral recruits from other categories are sponsored by the RAAF under the employer nomination scheme. Australian citizenship is a requirement for permanent RAAF service. A lateral recruit may be accepted by the RAAF if he or she gives an undertaking to apply for citizenship when eligible; that is, after three months full-time RAAF service.

Retention measures specific to lateral recruits do not exist; however, lateral recruits are eligible for any retention incentives offered to other members of the RAAF. If a lateral recruit accepts RAAF assistance for removal, including furniture and personal goods, a three-year return of service obligation is applied. Non-poaching arrangements were resolved before lateral recruitment started when the Chief of the Air Staff wrote to the Royal Air Force Chief of the Air Services on 17 May 1989 to apprise him of the intention regarding lateral recruitment; that is, recruitment aimed at ex-RAF or serving RAF officers who had already decided to separate.

On 13 June 1989 the RAF Chief of the Air Services responded, agreeing to lateral recruitment by the RAAF. No specific employment contracts apply to lateral recruits. The number recruited during 1989 total 10, with a further 3 possibles. That is made up of four coming from the RAF, one air traffic, one pilot, one engineer and one police; two from the Canadian armed forces, one pilot and one police; three from Air Force Zimbabwe, one air traffic and two pilots; and finally, from the Royal New Zealand Air Force, one ground defence, making a total of 10.

RAAF lateral recruits are not mercenaries in accordance with article 47 of the protocols of the Geneva Convention 1949, which defines a mercenary as any person, firstly, specifically recruited locally abroad in order to fight in armed conflict, who does in fact take a direct part in hostilities, is motivated to take part in the hostilities essentially by the desire for private gain and in fact is promised by or on behalf of a party to the conflict material compensation substantially in excess of that promised or paid to combatants of similar ranks and functions in the armed forces of that party, is a national of neither party to the conflict, and who has not been sent by a state which is not a party to the conflict on official duties as a member of its armed forces. That is a very convoluted definition of a mercenary. That will also be provided tomorrow in answer to a question.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the lateral recruitment exercise been targeted to certain countries, or have there been some general advertisements or requests?

—I do not suppose that anyone is barred, although I do not think someone from, maybe, the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics airforce would be accepted. The advertisements were placed solely in Great Britain. Obviously, those from Zimbabwe and New Zealand read the Times.

—I suppose this raises the general and obvious question of how we can recruit even as many as 10 pilots from overseas-and obviously we may be able to attract them from the countries that the Minister mentioned. How is it that we are able to attract numbers from the United Kingdom rather than being able to retain our own pilots? Has any assessment been made of this? That is the heart of the problem.

—The conundrum is that anyone we recruit has to separate from another service and this probably indicates that other services have retention problems too. I do not know what the motive is. I guess it would not take too long to quickly interview the people and ask them what their motives are for coming here. I think it is the general migration motive-that they made the move for family reasons, a better environment for their kids or they are sick of the cold winter.
—The Thatcher Government!

—No, I do not think so. Those are the sorts of reasons, I imagine, that would normally apply to migrants. There are 10 personnel in all, four of whom are pilots. I do not think it is an enormous figure, but I guess that someone else's retention rate problem could be our gain.

—I asked the Minister to confirm, deny or provide some other figure in respect of my suggestion that the RAAF is 150 pilots, or thereabouts, short. Is it intended to try to make up whatever that shortfall is. It is very substantial. Is the RAAF intending to make up that figure by recruiting from overseas or has it got other plans?

—We are, of course, trying to increase our number of pilots in training. As we explained to the Estimates Committee, recruitment-not just with pilots but with several categories-is probably one of our major difficulties. It is very hard to recruit in certain areas. Because of the alternatives that can be offered, once fully trained, retention is difficult. As we said, international airlines and others quite often see us as a prime recruiting ground and it says something for their training methods I guess.

—Is there anything further on program 5.2? Are there any questions on the Auditor-General's report No. 31 and reservation by Senator Michael Baume? Any unanswered questions are eligible for consideration by the Committee. There are 23 unanswered questions which have been circulated. Do any honourable senators wish to speak on any of the unanswered questions or probe further on them?

—The whole procedure-the way that estimates have been handled this year-has been very difficult. I know that there are a lot of unanswered questions in respect of the Estimates. I believe that the Government has not given the departments time to answer the questions. All the departments have been rather reticent in terms of answering the questions quickly. We usually come to the Committee of the Whole with perhaps one or two outstanding questions.
—This year is a bit unusual, isn't it?
—The interjection is that it is a bit unusual.
—This year is a bit unusual.

—Well, this year is a bit unusual-we have had an election. The whole procedure of the Senate has got to take second place because the Government decided to have an election. I am terribly sorry but that will not occur-fortunately, the Government does not have the numbers in this place.
—Order! Senator Walters, this is not a relevant matter for the Committee at this stage.
—Mr Chairman, you asked for comments on questions that have not been answered.
—I asked whether anyone wished to pursue any unanswered question. A general discussion on the nature of the proceedings is not in order at this stage.

—I am concerned that there are 23 questions unanswered. How on earth can anybody ask questions about questions that have already given to a department if they have not been answered? The impossible is being asked of us. I am asking why the questions have not been answered. Why has the Government not given the departments long enough to answer the questions so that this Committee of the Whole is not a complete farce? As Senator Coates said, the Government wanted to call an election.
—The last part is entirely in order, Senator Walters.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Walters may have noticed that I was not here for the very start of the Defence section because I thought discussion on Foreign Affairs and Trade may have run for half an hour to 40 minutes. I was in the process of clearing all the answers. I have got to the stage where I have them with me. There are only five questions unanswered. I would agree that on this occasion there was insufficient time to get some of the questions on notice answered. My Department endeavoured with a great deal of energy to get them answered. One of the difficulties the Department faces is that the answers must be cleared through the Minister. I admit that I have been in Cabinet for virtually all the day and could not clear them in time. Maybe I anticipated that we would not be debating this tonight. I congratulate the chamber on getting this far.

SPEECH.PARA: I think all departments will be very conscious at the next Estimates committee meetings of endeavouring to get questions answered before this Committee of the Whole meets. Time constraints on this occasion were a well-known disadvantage. I made no secret of the difficulty of the Estimates committee timetable this time. I said it was very difficult. I said that we had problems and I allocated an extra sitting day on the Monday.

TALK.START.PARA: —And not getting the Forward Estimates figures early enough too.
—Yes, all those sorts of things. Senator Coates is also right. I think Senator Baume will find that when the coalition went early a couple of times and had an election--
—Early?

—Well, 1977. But elections do sometimes upset even the august chamber of the Senate. As I say, we are quite happy to dispense with them and, I suppose, just rule without a mandate. I do not think the honourable senator would be very happy about that.

SPEECH.PARA: So the major point to come out of Senator Walters's comments is that next session we will draw the attention of departments to the need to get the questions answered. I would very much like to refer to some of the other points that have been made here about the perversion of the Estimates Committee because this is a two-way street and a two-way argument. But now is not the time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I certainly accept the great bulk of what the Minister said. But I raise a point that should be made. The lack of time to examine the Forward Estimates themselves before the Estimates committees met has rarely been equalled and this cannot be justified by the existence of an election or anything else. The figures were presented to us two months after an election. Basically, the figures surely would have been available earlier than this because there are no major policy changes to my knowledge.
—They have not got any policies.

—The interjection was that they have not got any policies. In those areas where there are no policy changes, I simply cannot see why Supplementary Estimates figures could not have been prepared and been made available, thereby giving us much more time to consider them. It was Thursday afternoon or Friday morning before we got the estimates figures to be debated the following Monday.
—But the Bill has to be up-to-date when it is introduced, you know.

—Senator Coates says that it has to be up to date. Unless the Minister has some special reason, which I do not know of, I cannot see why the great bulk of this information could not have been readily available earlier. I cannot see why all the figures have to come out on one day. We got everything in one heap. Surely, the material could have been presented to honourable senators as it became available. That simply did not happen. I, frankly, cannot believe that every department's estimates were not ready until the Thursday before we met which, as I recall, was when we got them. I think the Minister has shown goodwill towards the Senate in this area. The Opposition depended heavily on getting this material. Let us recognise that there is a real need for the Senate to be treated better than it was this year.

—I will answer very briefly. The timetables are determined by the Department of Finance, not the Department of Defence. The honourable senator probably missed the opportunity to raise that with the officers. I suggest that someone send a Hansard of the honourable senator's remarks to the Minister for Finance (Mr Willis) for his consideration and certainly in the spring session-it is normally at the end of the Budget week that they come out-we will have a fair deal more time in which to consider them.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I call the next speaker, I think I should make quite clear to the Committee why I am ruling as I am about relevance. I was personally frustrated about the very short interval between the Senate Estimates committee hearings and the Committee of the Whole when there was not time for the reports to be properly considered and presented to the Committee of the Whole. As all honourable senators will remember, we had trouble on that issue this morning. Therefore, I can understand the frustration of some honourable senators about that. Nevertheless, I think I should draw attention to what this debate now is supposed to be about and what its limitations are. The order states:

INTERJECT.PARA: That, where proposed expenditure contained in an appropriation bill has been considered and reported on by Estimates Committees, debate on that bill in the committee of the whole shall be confined to matters in respect of which reports of Estimates Committees, or reservations attached to reports, have made recommendations that the matters be further examined by the Senate.

That is why I allow people to talk but I have not allowed general debate on the issue, because there is nothing in this Estimates Committee report that recommended further consideration of that matter by the Committee of the Whole.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can I just get this clarified, as it is vitally important for future consideration? I know that there seems to be some tremendous pressure to get through all these reports tonight, if possible. It is a remarkable attitude, but it seems to be pervading the chamber. I protest against that attitude, if that is the case. Perhaps the Minister for Defence is more relaxed than most, but there is an atmosphere around here of urging everybody to get on and get these things through tonight or as soon as possible.

SPEECH.PARA: As part of the new procedure we have a provision whereby these Estimates committee reports may recommend the adoption of the estimates, as I understand it. I do not quite understand why that is so important, frankly, but anyway it is there. It is put forward as a major new development under these procedures. It does seem to me that, if we are going to have a motion for the adoption by the chamber of the estimates, that must be a subject which can be debated.

I want to get this clear. Mr Chairman, are you ruling that the motion to adopt the report cannot in itself be debated and that the only debate that can take place is in relation to matters that are actually referred to in the committee report or raised by reservation?

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —That is correct. I will read again the order of the Senate:

INTERJECT.PARA: . . . debate on that bill in the committee of the whole shall be confined to matters in respect of which reports of Estimates Committees, or reservations attached to reports, have made recommendations that the matters be further examined by the Senate.

I take it that it is deliberately intended by the Senate to limit debates at this stage. I am merely implementing the order of the Senate. I have allowed a fairly wide-ranging debate, as everyone is concerned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can I seek your guidance just by way of ruling on that matter, Mr Chairman? You will see when we come to the report of the next Estimates Committee that there is a matter which is raised in the Estimates Committee report and on which the Committee expresses an opinion. It states, `The Committee is of the view that-X, Y, Z', but it does not make a recommendation that the matter be further considered by the Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: When it was suggested that, in order to comply with the order of the Senate, a reservation should be entered saying `Senator Puplick recommends that the Senate further consider the matter on which the Committee has expressed a view', we were advised that it was not necessary to put a separate reservation because the issue concerned was one which was specifically taken out and identified as an issue of concern and an expression of the view of the Committee, but a recommendation did not flow from that.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —I think I can help the honourable senator there. I should make clear that I was aware of the rushed circumstances under which these committee reports were prepared-the fact that senators on committees were not experienced in how the Chair was going to rule on these matters, and there is a developing process there. I have been leaning over backwards to allow any matter about which a committee appeared to be expressing concern to be raised in these debates. But in the particular case the honourable senator raises, Estimates Committee C, the first recommendation of Estimates Committee C states:

INTERJECT.PARA: Estimates Committee C recommends that the Senate approve, without amendment or request for amendment, expenditure in accordance with additional estimates considered by the Committee and that matters raised in this report be further examined by the Senate.
I therefore take it that any matters raised in the report would be eligible for consideration in the Committee of the Whole.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will try to refrain from getting involved in all these procedural matters. I indicate to the Committee on behalf of the Government-and I am sure that the Australian Democrats will agree with me-that we are quite happy in the next few weeks to discuss the procedures as they are evolving in regard to Estimates committees to see how they are working, et cetera. The one thing we will resist is that we just revert completely to the old Estimates committee procedures, having conceded ground elsewhere. There has to be a balance. That is the only point I make.

SPEECH.PARA: If these procedures are regarded by the Liberal and National parties as not satisfactory to expose the issues, we are quite happy to discuss that and make the relevant adjustments. It cannot just be one-sided where all the turkey goes over on one plate and we get nothing back. We did get something back in terms of a more focused Estimates committee debate and a couple of other things. In turn, those opposite got a much more comprehensive look at the committee stage of Bills off-chamber, if you like, and it is a nice balance. If this part of it does not suit honourable senators, we will look at it, provided we look at the overall balance to make sure that there is some sort of equality.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, cognisant of your ruling earlier tonight, I want to make only one brief comment. I refer to something that Senator Durack said and, almost by way of inference something that Senator Ray said a moment ago. This new procedure was forced on the Senate by the combined numbers of the Government and the Opposition. I suggest that people return to the debate of 5 December. They will discover that it was accepted without division. There were two amendments-one moved by Senator Durack and the other moved by Senator Crichton-Browne. If honourable senators look through the names they will discover that members of all political parties voted no. Senator Chaney in fact joined Senator Ray on that particular occasion. I notice that it was not forced on anybody. There were 25 ayes and 44 noes and that exercise ought to be corrected for the record.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —That completes the consideration of the report of Estimates Committee B. The Committee will now turn to Estimates Committee C. I call on the expenditure considered by Estimates Committee C.

INTERJECT.PARA: REPORT OF ESTIMATES COMMITTEE C
Motion (by Senator Tate) proposed:
That the report of Estimates Committee C be adopted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think we have been over this ground fairly well. I will repeat it, as I think is proper. In accordance with the new procedures adopted by the Senate, passage of that motion just moved by the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs will have the effect of approving the expenditure contained in the Bill. I will now call on the departments examined by Estimates Committee C and, in relation to each Department, the matters recommended by the Estimates Committee report for further examination by the Committee, which, of course, includes reservations. Honourable senators are reminded that, under the new procedures, debate must be confined to those matters. The first Department in Group C is Social Security. The first matter is the Auditor-General's report No. 31. Do you wish to raise anything, Senator Michael Baume?
—No, not under this section.

—There are a number of unanswered questions to the Department, all of which are eligible for further debate. As there are no questions for Social Security we will move onto the next matter, which is the general reservation attached by Senator Walters by which she can discuss any matter she wishes under Social Security.
—I do not have any questions for the Department of Social Security.

—That completes consideration of the Department of Social Security. The next department is the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. One matter referred to the Committee of the Whole was the Australia Council news release containing party political opinion.
—I raise a point of order. Is not the Department of Community Services and Health next in the report? I cannot understand the order.

—No. The order given to me in this paper is first, the Department of Social Security, secondly, the Department of Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, thirdly, the Department of Veterans' Affairs and, fourthly, the Department of Community Services and Health and general matters.

—I go to the report of Estimates Committee C, which is a good starting point. It deals with the departments in the following order: it starts with the Department of Veterans' Affairs. The Department of Community Services and Health is second. Then comes the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. It does not seem to include the Department of Social Security. It is confusing for honourable senators to try to follow. We are working from the report of the Committee. I thought that was why Senator Michael Baume might have been caught by surprise. It seemed that the Department of Social Security came in no order that we could derive from this report.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I came down prepared to start with the Department of Veterans' Affairs. I was told by officers that I was out of order and that the Notice Paper indicated a different order. That was thrust in front of me. I must confess that I gave in and accepted it with bad grace.

—I think we can solve this problem. The order I was given the departments was the order in which they were referred to the Committee. For reasons I have not gone into, the Committee has reported a different order. If it would suit the convenience of the Committee, there is no difficulty at all taking them in that order. Is that the wish of the Committee?

—My recollection of Estimates Committee C is that the first day of hearing was devoted to the Department of Veterans' Affairs, the Department of Community Services and Health and the Department of Social Security. That was completed. On the second day the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories was dealt with. In the report of Estimates Committee C, the index to Hansard of Monday 14 May is printed but the index to the Hansard of 17 May is not printed because it was not available in time. Although you, Mr Chairman, may have been given a particular list, I think the correct way would be to proceed on the basis of the order in which the Committee examined the departments, which has led to the way in which the report is sent out.

—That is what I just proposed to the Committee. If it is the wish of the Committee, we can take the departments in the order which the Committee report deals with them. It is not worth wasting time on the reason for the discrepancy. I will offer the Department of Social Security to anyone later on in case anyone was caught by surprise by its early passage. The first matter is the Department of Veterans' Affairs. The Committee drew attention to two matters. The first was the failure to present performance information relating to objectives.

—I want to do something quite unusual; that is, offer some praise to the Department of Veterans' Affairs. Senator Richardson looks surprised. Following that Estimates examination two very senior officers of the Department came to see me to discuss the question of performance indicators. Some information has been supplied and some promises have been made concerning the next examination of the Estimates. On that basis I am prepared to let this matter rest.
—If there is no further discussion on that matter, we move to the other matter of hospital waiting lists.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —At this stage it would help me if the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs (Senator Tate) could summarise for me the answer to the relevant question that the officers can provide for him. The question I asked concerned a representation I had had from an orthapaedic surgeon who had advised me of an elderly patient requiring a knee replacement in a veterans' hospital. His surgeon told him that there were considerable waiting lists at the Repatriation General Hospital in Concord.

SPEECH.PARA: My question was: how long were the waiting lists? How long was this veteran likely to have to wait? The letter from the surgeon made it clear that the reason that the person had seen the doctor was continuing pain in the joint. The operation was required because of not only the underlying orthapaedic problem but also the symptom of pain. In those circumstances, any considerable waiting time is unsatisfactory and probably unsupportable. In that context we were promised some information about waiting lists. It has come through today but it would help me in advancing this argument if that information could be summarised for me. From memory, there are about 29 entitled patients on the waiting lists at Concord for those kinds of joint replacements. If that is so, could the Minister confirm it?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen the document. Some of the points that emerged from it are that the number of people waiting and who are entitled are about 30 for most of the surgeons. DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Australian Security Intelligence Organisation-South Africa: Migration

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —It being 10.30 p.m., under sessional order I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to deal with a matter that received passing attention yesterday, that is, the annual report to Parliament of the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation (ASIO). As you know, Mr President, I have run a campaign for a very long time about the quality and timeliness of annual reports. The Australian Security Intelligence Organisation has failed this Parliament in reporting belatedly, and unnecessarily so, on an issue of major significance to this country.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not like having to criticise an organisation for which I have a very high regard and for which Australia has a great need, but I want to say this: Unless ASIO can justify its belated reporting, I believe it should be criticised by this Parliament. Under the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation Act of 1979, ASIO is required to provide the Minister with a report on activities of the organisation as soon as practicable after 30 June. Usually, one finds that those organisations that report late have the justification that they were having a dispute with the Auditor-General, that they could not get their sums right or that these negotiations resulted in the late presentation of their reports. ASIO is not in that situation. The Audit report was signed on 31 August last year, the Attorney-General's declaration was signed on 4 October last year and there was nothing to prevent this report coming to the Parliament last session except that the Director-General's letter covering the report was not in fact sent until 12 February this year.

What was happening between October 1989, when the Attorney-General's declaration was signed, and 12 February to delay this report? I believe that the Senate is entitled to an explanation from a body which, quite rightly in many instances, finds good reason for not explaining itself but which this time has an obligation to explain itself. I am getting sick and tired of governmental bodies which treat this Parliament with contempt in this way.

I want to raise another matter of some substance, a matter that has been raised in the report and that I believe the Senate has to look at with a great deal of seriousness. A significant remark made at the end of the report was not mentioned in the press reports this morning of this annual report. It reads:
. . . the scale and diversity of likely future demands indicate a need for significant additional funding in the years ahead.

I believe that for ASIO to give us this warning is a matter of some substance. We are entitled to know why and in what areas. There is some explanation earlier on. In Chapter 2, for example, ASIO identifies far higher levels of activity by some intelligence services over the past year than was previously known in Australia. That is why I think it is important, when we are considering why ASIO should receive additional sums, to look at what ASIO's justifications are for this need to expand. ASIO says:

Australia continues to play host to a number of representatives of foreign intelligence services from various countries, whose activities are regarded as hostile to Australia's interests. Over the past year ASIO has discovered a higher level of representation and activity in Australia by some hostile intelligence services than had been previously known or suspected.
It goes on:

. . . the threat from these services has been shown to be significant. The lowering of world tensions over the past year arising from political reforms in some countries has not reduced the level of activity of hostile intelligence services.

This is a matter of great significance because we are in an environment in which the general view is that the detente between the East and West should lead to a relaxation of our guard, if you like. I think that ASIO is telling us that, despite what is happening around the world, Australia simply cannot afford to lower its guard against the threat of hostile intelligence services operating in this country. For example, ASIO points out that, while Australia faces a low level of threat involving politically motivated violence, nonetheless there has been some activity in Australia:

A most significant development was the attempted entry to Australia of a member of one of the most dangerous currently active terrorist groups. Although already married, the member sought to gain entry through his engagement to an Australian woman he met when she was overseas. The woman is believed not to have known of the affiliation of her `fiance' and to have been an unwitting party in the matter.
It continues:
. . . domestic groups on the extreme right have shown a clear potential to cause distress to sections of the Australian community, and perhaps threaten life.

In New South Wales we have had the experience of an ethnic Chinese Australian member of the New South Wales Parliament being threatened at a meeting by a group of racists in a most offensive way. ASIO notes:
The increased collection effort of intelligence during 1988-89 allowed ASIO to detect a greater number of identified and suspected foreign intelligence officers in Australia.
I am certain that most Australians do not realise that there has been this clear increase. It continues:
The increased figure represents both the arrival of more foreign intelligence officers in Australia and ASIO's improved awareness of the roles of those already here.

I want to conclude with one other matter relating to ASIO and that is its important role when we have a high level of migration. Many people fail to recognise that a high level of migration, such as the one that the Government has presently set of 140,000 migrants a year, imposes a specific obligation on Australian security services to provide adequate screening to ensure that we are protected against the sorts of risks that clearly flow from such inflows. I have already mentioned the checking done to make certain that a foreign agent or a terrorist does not come into Australia.

ASIO makes the point that it made 31 adverse assessments last year relating to non-access checking security requests. It then notes, however, that all but one of those adverse assessments against the granting or renewal of visas to enter or remain in Australia were accepted by client departments. I raise this because, as I understand it and as I understand statements made last year which, I must say, the former Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, Senator Robert Ray, did not respond effectively to, ASIO did make an adverse recommendation about Sheik Al Hilaly. If this report is so and if the suggestion in the documents that were available last year is correct, it makes it even more extraordinary that on only one occasion was an ASIO recommendation overruled and it appears to have been for what could be a political reason. That does add concern to the basis on which ASIO's recommendation was overruled. Obviously, ASIO's recommendations have been sufficiently sound to be accepted in 30 out of 31 cases, but in one case it is found not to be sufficiently sound to be acted upon.

As I said, mainly I wanted to dramatise to the Australian people that ASIO's major job is to investigate indications of activity against it by foreign intelligence services or other groups or individuals, that this risk appears to be increasing, and that we should not be lulled into any false sense of security.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise briefly to touch on a matter which is sufficiently attractive for it to be on the front page of today's West Australian. The headline reads, `Racist threat in WA: ASIO'. When one reads the rather more modest print, one sees that this story is a beat up by Mr Keith Wright, a member of the House of Representatives for a seat in Queensland, who is the Chairman of the Joint Committee monitoring the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation (ASIO). The thrust of the comments by Mr Wright is that there are well known families of South African descent or families who directly migrated from South Africa to Perth who are promoting racial hatred. He goes on to make a number of other outrageous claims which I will touch on in a few moments.

SPEECH.PARA: This epitomises the outrageous hypocrisy and bigotry which underlines the double standards in the immigration debate. I should say at the outset that my understanding is that Mr Wright, as Chairman of this Committee, was not speaking with the authority or knowledge of the Committee. It seems to me to be typical of the Australian Labor Party's attitude. It inflames racial hatred, as this article is designed to do, and prejudices decent, honest migrants who come from one part of the world. At the same time, as we have seen in the past, every time the Liberal Party dares to raise the question of immigration it is claimed to be racist.

Mr Wright claims that he has been given this information by a senior Perth church leader during, to use his expression, a recent secret meeting on the goings-on of families who have migrated from South Africa. I have to say that it very much reminds me of the poor man who spends too much time reading spy comics. I would have thought that if Mr Wright had something of substance to say he would have named the senior prominent Perth church leader and the families and would have gone to explain the nefarious activities in which they are involved.

Having spent some considerable time in South Africa and having spent some time talking to left wing clergymen such as Archbishop Tutu, Bayers Nadir, the Reverend Allan Boesak and one or two others, because of my personal communication with them and their public statements which have inflamed the racial hatred and the violence in those townships, I have come to the conclusion, sadly as a Christian, that to be a minister of the cloth gives one no mortgage on morality, decency, peace and goodwill amongst men. That view was reinforced by my visit through Nicaragua, where I encountered the involvement of a number of members of the Catholic Church in violence in the name of communism. Also, events in the Philippines have done nothing but reinforce that view.

In my view, the comments of Mr Wright-I do not know whether he purports or pretends to be a Christian-about Christians in Western Australia, because he says that the greatest sin of these people is that they promote right wing policies of racial intolerance under the guise of Christian principles, are rather a commentary on him and not on Christians. It is interesting that Mr Wright makes much of what he sees to be the responsibility of ASIO to monitor the activities of right wing extreme groups. At the same time, I find him deafening in his silence in respect of the activities of the extreme left wing groups in this country. I wait to hear him raise his voice in objection to the violence and intimidation which have been perpetrated by a notoriously well-known left wing group against the members of the South African Embassy in Canberra. Of course, I have no doubt, as is true probably of any group from any nation or country that might migrate to Australia, that there are anti-social bigots amongst those immigrants and that South Africa has no less and no more than its share. But I find it absolutely repulsive that Mr Wright should, by his claims, tarnish and threaten the good and decent reputations of those South Africans who leave that country to come to our country for a better and more wholesome lifestyle.

Mr Wright says a very curious thing in this article. I have to assume, with respect, Mr President, that he is an anti-Christian, because he says that they are promoting a role for committed Christians to speak out against the evils of communism. I would have thought that the Labor Party was a bit more sophisticated than to raise the spectre of Christians arguing against communism. Mr Wright goes on to say that Hitler picked up the support of many Christians. Unless I am quite wrong, there are-perhaps not by accident but by design-a number of Christians in the Labor Party, and I would have thought that there was nothing improper about Christians having views on a whole range of things. To suggest that there is something reprehensible about a Christian being opposed to communism barks back to the archaic days of the 1950s. It shows all the prejudices, the bigotry, the racism, all those repulsive, revolting characteristics, which I thought were flushed out of the mainstream of Australia a decade ago.

I cannot imagine that Mr Wright would get the endorsement or support of his own Party to raise the spectre of something being wrong with being a Christian, something wrong with being a South African, and something wrong with coming to this country as a person seeking to have a new hope and a new life.

As I said at the outset, I await hearing him make some criticism of those left wing radical groups that have intimidated and terrorised and been charged because of their conduct in respect of their activities against the South African Embassy-and not only that, but in other elements of Australian society. I give no more condemnation to one group than the other, but I am not selective in my morality or my judgment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I conclude this debate without wishing to go into the specific matters that were raised by the honourable senators in debate. I simply want to make the general observation that I have been fortunate enough to have been able to assist a number of South African families to come to Australia, and in fact they have now settled in the Northern Territory. They came to Australia for the very positive reason of getting away from the particular system of government that exists in South Africa, rather than from any desire to support it.
